choices.text: Bilateral choanal atresia; provide an oral airway with a modified nipple (McGovern’s technique)
Unilateral choanal atresia; perform immediate CT scan and emergency tracheostomy
Bilateral membranous choanal atresia; wait till 1.5 years for transpalatal surgery
Congenital dacryocystocele; advise massage and monitor for spontaneous resolution

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with respiratory distress and cyclic cyanosis, which improves when crying. Examination reveals mucoid nasal discharge and absence of air bubbles. Attempts to pass a nasal catheter into the pharynx fail. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral choanal atresia; provide an oral airway with a modified nipple (McGovern’s technique)

 

  • Choanal atresia is due to persistence of the bucconasal membrane, and may be bony (90%) or membranous (10%).

 

 

  • It can be unilateral (more common) or bilateral.

 

 

  • Bilateral choanal atresia presents at birth, as neonates are obligate nasal breathers; they develop respiratory distress and cyanosis, especially during feeding.
  • Clinical findings include:
    • Mucoid discharge in the nose
    • Absence of air bubbles
    • Failure to pass nasal catheter into the pharynx
  • McGovern’s technique: Using a nipple with a large hole as an oral airway helps avoid tracheostomy.

 

 

  • Diagnosis can be confirmed by:
    • Methylene blue dye test
    • Flexible nasal endoscopy
    • CT scan (axial view is best)
    • Definitive treatment:
    • Endoscopic transnasal drilling
    • Transpalatal approach usually at 1.5 years (not in the newborn period)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Unilateral choanal atresia; perform immediate CT scan and emergency tracheostomy: Unilateral choanal atresia usually does not cause neonatal distress and is often diagnosed later in life. Emergency tracheostomy is not warranted in this setting.

 

Option C. Bilateral membranous choanal atresia; wait till 1.5 years for transpalatal surgery: Bilateral membranous choanal atresia does need surgery, but emergency airway management is critical immediately. Definitive surgery (transpalatal) is planned later, but cannot be the first step.

 

Option D. Congenital dacryocystocele; advise massage and monitor for spontaneous resolution: Congenital dacryocystocele presents with swelling over the medial canthus, not with respiratory obstruction. It does not cause failure to pass nasal catheters

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral choanal atresia presents with neonatal respiratory distress due to nasal airway obstruction and requires immediate airway support using McGovern’s technique.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: Bilateral choanal atresia
Congenital dacryocystocele
Unilateral choanal atresia
Neonatal nasal polyposis

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency department with difficulty in breathing, especially during feeding, and cyanosis that improves while crying. Examination reveals mucoid nasal discharge, and a nasogastric catheter cannot be passed through either nostril into the oropharynx. The baby was born to a mother treated with methimazole during pregnancy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilateral choanal atresia

 

Choanal atresia results from embryological persistence of the bucconasal membrane, preventing communication between the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.

 

 

  • It's associated with methimazole/carbimazole use during pregnancy, and with CHARGE syndrome.
  • It is of two types:
    • Bony (most common)
    • Membranous
  • Unilateral is more common but may be asymptomatic early in life.

 

 

  • Bilateral atresia presents at birth with:
    • Cyanosis relieved on crying (because neonates are obligate nasal breathers).
    • Mucoid discharge, absence of air bubbles, and inability to pass catheter.
  • Diagnosis includes:
    • Methylene blue dye test
    • Flexible nasal endoscopy
    • Axial CT scan
  • Emergency airway support can be provided with a large-holed feeding nipple (McGovern’s technique).

 

 

  • Definitive management is surgical correction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital dacryocystocele: Presents as a bluish swelling over the medial canthus and does not cause airway obstruction or failed nasal catheterization.

 

Option C. Unilateral choanal atresia: Usually asymptomatic in neonates and diagnosed later in childhood.

 

Option D. Neonatal nasal polyposis: Rare, often associated with cystic fibrosis; polyps do not block both nostrils at birth nor mimic the classic findings of choanal atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral choanal atresia presents with neonatal respiratory distress, especially during feeding, and is diagnosed by inability to pass a catheter and confirmed by CT or endoscopy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: CSF is secreted by the arachnoid villi and absorbed by the choroid plexus
Total volume of CSF in the body is around 500–600 mL
Normal CSF pressure during lumbar puncture is between 50–150 mm H₂O
Activities such as coughing or lifting weights help seal CSF leaks

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with clear, watery nasal discharge from one side, which increases when bending forward or straining. He has a history of recent head trauma. CSF analysis confirms the presence of beta-2 transferrin. Which of the following statements about cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and its physiology is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal CSF pressure during lumbar puncture is between 50–150 mm H₂O

 

  • CSF rhinorrhoea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose, and it may be clear or blood-tinged, especially in acute head injuries.
  • CSF is produced by the choroid plexus in the lateral, third, and fourth ventricles.
  • Arachnoid villi function as one-way valves: they absorb CSF into the dural venous sinuses, not secrete it.
  • The normal CSF volume is about 90–150 mL, and it's replaced 3–5 times daily at a rate of 20 mL/hour (350–500 mL/day).
  • Normal CSF pressure measured by lumbar puncture ranges from 50–150 mm H₂O.
  • Activities like coughing, sneezing, nose blowing, or straining increase CSF pressure and may worsen a CSF leak; they should be avoided during or after leak repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSF is secreted by the arachnoid villi and absorbed by the choroid plexus: CSF is secreted by the choroid plexus, not the arachnoid villi (which absorb it).

 

 

Option B. Total volume of CSF in the body is around 500–600 mL: Total CSF volume is 90–150 mL, not 500–600 mL (though the latter is the daily production, not volume).

 

Option D. Activities such as coughing or lifting weights help seal CSF leaks: Activities like coughing or lifting weights increase intracranial pressure and may worsen the leak, not help.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF rhinorrhoea is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose, and normal CSF pressure ranges from 50–150 mm H₂O.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: Trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy
Sinus mucocele with bone erosion
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
Meningoencephalocele

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with intermittent clear nasal discharge, especially when bending forward. He has no history of trauma, fever, or sinus infection. CSF analysis confirms a positive beta-2 transferrin test, and CT cisternography localizes the leak to the cribriform plate. Which of the following is NOT a known cause of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

CSF rhinorrhoea occurs when cerebrospinal fluid leaks through a defect in the skull base into the nasal cavity. Causes include:

 

  • Trauma – the most common cause, either accidental (e.g., head injury) or surgical trauma, such as:
    • Endoscopic sinus surgery
    • Trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy
    • Nasal polypectomy
    • Skull base surgeries
  • Inflammations like sinus mucoceles, fungal sinusitis, osteomyelitis, and nasal polyposis can erode bone and dura.
  • Neoplasms (benign or malignant) involving the skull base can lead to CSF leak.
  • Congenital lesions like meningoceles, meningoencephaloceles, and gliomas may be associated with skull base defects.
  • Idiopathic CSF rhinorrhoea occurs when the cause is unknown.

 

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma – Though vascular and destructive, it does not typically cause skull base erosion or CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy: Known to cause iatrogenic CSF leak through skull base.

 

Option B. Sinus mucocele: Can erode the bone and dura over time, causing CSF leak.

 

 

Option D. Meningoencephalocele: A congenital defect where brain tissue herniates through a skull base defect; CSF leak is common.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF rhinorrhoea is most commonly caused by trauma, but may also result from infections, skull base tumors, congenital defects, or occur idiopathically.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: Cribriform plate
Roof of ethmoid air cells
Frontal sinus
Mastoid air cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with clear nasal discharge following a motor vehicle accident. A CT scan of the skull base shows a fracture through the cribriform plate. Which of the following anatomic sites is least likely to be involved in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mastoid air cells

 

CSF rhinorrhoea results from leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nasal cavity due to a breach in the skull base. The site of leakage depends on the location of cranial fossa injury:

 

  • Anterior cranial fossa leaks reach the nose via:
  1. Cribriform plate
  2. Roof of the ethmoid air cells
  3. Frontal sinus
  • Middle cranial fossa injuries typically involve:
    • Sphenoid sinus (injury here can result in CSF rhinorrhoea)
  • In temporal bone fractures, CSF can enter the middle ear, travel via the Eustachian tube, and exit through the nasal cavity — this is called CSF otorhinorrhoea, though it still manifests as nasal discharge.
  • The mastoid air cells, while part of the temporal bone, do not directly communicate with the nasal cavity, and are not typical sites for CSF to leak through into the nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cribriform plate: Most common site of anterior skull base CSF leak.

 

 

Option B. Roof of ethmoid air cells: Close proximity to anterior cranial fossa; frequently involved.

 

 

Option C. Frontal sinus: Anterior cranial fossa CSF can track through this route to reach the nasal cavity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF can reach the nasal cavity from anterior or middle cranial fossa via cribriform plate, ethmoid roof, frontal or sphenoid sinuses, but mastoid air cells are not a common route for CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: Discharge is salty and slimy
Fluid has <10 mg/dL sugar content
Presence of β₂ transferrin in the discharge
Associated symptoms of sneezing and nasal itching

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with clear, watery nasal discharge from the right nostril, which started after he underwent endoscopic sinus surgery 3 weeks ago. He reports that the fluid increases on bending forward and cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following findings would be most suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhoea rather than nasal secretions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of β₂ transferrin in the discharge

 

To differentiate CSF rhinorrhoea from nasal secretions, key features include:

 

 

  • The presence of β₂ transferrin in nasal discharge is specific for CSF and is a definitive diagnostic marker.
  • The patient’s history (post-surgical), fluid quality (clear, watery), and positional worsening (bending forward) support CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discharge is salty and slimy: Salty, slimy discharge is more typical of nasal mucus, not CSF.

 

Option B. Fluid has <10 mg/dL sugar content: CSF has >30 mg/dL sugar; <10 mg/dL is suggestive of nasal secretions.

 

Option D. Associated symptoms of sneezing and nasal itching: Sneezing and itching are features of allergic rhinitis, not CSF leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presence of β₂ transferrin in nasal discharge is the most specific test to differentiate CSF rhinorrhoea from normal nasal secretions.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 164

choices.text: Allergic rhinitis; presence of eosinophils in nasal smear
Vasomotor rhinitis; bluish boggy turbinates
CSF rhinorrhoea; double target (halo) sign
Acute sinusitis; reservoir sign

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with a history of clear nasal discharge that appears suddenly in drops when bending forward, especially after getting out of bed in the morning. He has a history of head trauma two weeks ago. On examination, the discharge cannot be sniffed back, and when collected on filter paper, it shows a central red spot surrounded by a pale halo. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which sign supports it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CSF rhinorrhoea; double target (halo) sign

 

This patient’s symptoms are classic for CSF rhinorrhoea:

 

  • Reservoir sign: CSF that accumulates in sinuses (especially sphenoid sinus) overnight drains on bending the head in the morning.

     

 

  • Clear, watery nasal discharge that:
    • Occurs suddenly in drops
    • Increases with straining or bending
    • Cannot be sniffed back
  • Differentiating features:
    • Unlike nasal mucus, CSF does not stiffen a handkerchief.
  • Double target (halo) sign:
    • Seen when CSF mixed with blood is collected on filter paper
    • Appears as central red spot (blood) surrounded by a lighter peripheral ring (CSF)
  • Nasal endoscopy or otoscopy may help localize the leak (especially in otorhinorrhoea).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic rhinitis; presence of eosinophils in nasal smear: Allergic rhinitis presents with sneezing, itching, nasal congestion and mucus discharge, not clear fluid with positional variation.

 

Option B. Vasomotor rhinitis; bluish boggy turbinates: Vasomotor rhinitis also presents with nasal stuffiness and discharge, but no trauma or positional relation.

 

Option D. Acute sinusitis; reservoir sign: Reservoir sign is seen in CSF rhinorrhoea, not sinusitis. Acute sinusitis has purulent discharge, facial pain, and fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF rhinorrhoea is diagnosed clinically by positional clear nasal discharge that cannot be sniffed back and confirmed by double target sign or β₂ transferrin.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 164

choices.text: Glucose estimation using oxidase-peroxidase is the most reliable diagnostic test
Beta-2 transferrin is a highly specific and sensitive marker for CSF and found only in CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humour
Beta-trace protein is non-specific and also found in nasal secretions and saliva
A large quantity of nasal fluid is required for β₂ transferrin testing

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with clear, watery nasal discharge following a history of minor head trauma. The clinician suspects CSF rhinorrhoea and plans to confirm it using a laboratory test on the nasal sample. Which of the following statements regarding laboratory diagnosis of CSF leak is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta-2 transferrin is a highly specific and sensitive marker for CSF and found only in CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humour

 

  • Beta-2 transferrin:
    • Highly specific and sensitive for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
    • Found only in CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humour
    • Requires only a few drops of nasal discharge for testing
  • Beta-trace protein:
    • Another CSF-specific protein
    • Secreted by meninges and choroid plexus
    • More commonly used in Europe
  • Glucose estimation (oxidase-peroxidase or biochemical methods):
    • Outdated and no longer considered reliable or recommended
    • Glucose levels can be misleading due to contamination or infections

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose estimation using oxidase-peroxidase is the most reliable diagnostic test: Allergic rhinitis; presence of eosinophils in nasal smear: Glucose testing is no longer used due to poor reliability and lack of specificity.

 

Option C. Beta-trace protein is non-specific and also found in nasal secretions and saliva: CSF rhinorrhoea; double target (halo) sign: Beta-trace protein is specific for CSF, not found in nasal secretions or saliva.

 

Option D. A large quantity of nasal fluid is required for β₂ transferrin testing: Acute sinusitis; reservoir sign: Only a few drops of fluid are required for β₂ transferrin testing; a large quantity is not needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 transferrin is a highly specific and sensitive marker for CSF, present only in CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humour, and is used to confirm CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 164

choices.text: MRI T₂-weighted imaging
Intrathecal fluorescein endoscopy
High-resolution CT scan
CT cisternogram with intrathecal contrast

questions.text: A 33-year-old male with a history of endoscopic sinus surgery presents with persistent clear nasal discharge. CSF rhinorrhoea is confirmed by β₂ transferrin testing. The clinician now wants to localize the exact site of leak to plan surgical repair. Which of the following diagnostic methods is most appropriate for visualizing bony skull base defects in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High-resolution CT scan

 

Localization of a CSF leak is essential for surgical planning. The following investigations are used:

 

1. High-resolution CT scan:

  • First-line investigation
  • Cuts taken at 1–2 mm thickness
  • Coronal and axial views help detect bony defects of the frontal or sphenoid sinus, especially useful for skull base fractures

 

 

2. MRI (T₂-weighted):

  • Useful in depicting the site of leak
  • Requires active leak at the time of scan

  • Indicated if encephalocele or intracranial pathology is suspected

     

 

3. Intrathecal fluorescein study:

  • Invasive procedure
  • Used intraoperatively or preoperatively
  • Dye appears fluorescent green under blue filter
  • Patient kept in 10° head-down position
  • Helps visualize leak at cribriform plate, sphenoethmoidal recess, or torus tubarius

 

 

4. CT cisternogram:

  • Involves intrathecal injection of contrast (iohexol) and CT scan
  • Used when β₂ transferrin testing is not available
  • Not commonly used now

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI T₂-weighted imaging: Great for soft tissue or encephalocele, not bony defect visualization

 

Option B. Intrathecal fluorescein endoscopy: More invasive; used intraoperatively

 

Option D. CT cisternogram with intrathecal contrast: Older technique; less favored due to invasiveness and limited availability

 

Educational Objective:

 

High-resolution CT scan is the preferred initial modality to localize skull base defects in CSF rhinorrhoea due to its ability to visualize fine bony anatomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 164

choices.text: Immediate neurosurgical craniotomy with skull base reconstruction
Endoscopic transnasal repair with underlay fascia and mucosal graft
Conservative management with bed rest, acetazolamide, and head elevation
Frontal osteoplastic flap with sinus obliteration using abdominal fat

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea following a road traffic accident. The discharge is clear and positional. CT confirms a small skull base defect near the cribriform plate. He is stable and without signs of meningitis. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conservative management with bed rest, acetazolamide, and head elevation

 

  • Early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea (especially small leaks) are often managed conservatively with:
    • Bed rest
    • Elevating the head
    • Avoiding sneezing, nose blowing, straining
    • Stool softeners
    • Acetazolamide to reduce CSF production
    • Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent meningitis
    • Lumbar drain, if CSF pressure is high or conservative management fails
  • Surgical repair is indicated if:
    • Leak persists beyond 7–10 days
    • There is recurrent meningitis
    • The defect is large
  • Surgical options include:
    • Transnasal endoscopic repair (preferred for anterior fossa & sphenoid sinus leaks)
      • Underlay fascia graft extradurally
      • Mucosa flap (pedicled or free)
      • Surgicel, gelfoam, nasal packing
      • Cartilage for defects >2 cm
      • Fat may be used in place of fascia

 

    

 

  • Frontal sinus leaks: Often need osteoplastic flap with sinus obliteration using fat

 

  • Neurosurgical approaches: Reserved for large, complex, or failed cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate neurosurgical craniotomy with skull base reconstruction: Neurosurgical craniotomy Too aggressive for early or mild post-traumatic leaks; reserved for recurrent or inaccessible lesions.

 

Option B. Endoscopic transnasal repair with underlay fascia and mucosal graft: Endoscopic repair Excellent option, but typically used after failed conservative therapy or if leak is persistent/severe.

 

Option D. Frontal osteoplastic flap with sinus obliteration using abdominal fat: Frontal osteoplastic flap Specifically used for frontal sinus leaks, not first-line for cribriform plate defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea is initially managed conservatively with bed rest, head elevation, acetazolamide, and stool softeners before considering surgical repair.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 165

choices.text: Serum eosinophil count and nasal smear
Beta-2 transferrin testing of nasal discharge
Nasal endoscopy with biopsy of the lesion
Trial of intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with unilateral clear nasal discharge that increases when he bends forward. He had undergone endoscopic sinus surgery 10 days ago. The discharge has a sweet taste, and he notes it cannot be sniffed back. A filter paper test reveals a central red spot surrounded by a clear halo. What is the next best step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta-2 transferrin testing of nasal discharge

 

This patient presents with classic signs of CSF rhinorrhoea, including:

 

  • Clear, unilateral nasal discharge that worsens with head bending or straining
  • Sniff test: Discharge cannot be sniffed back (unlike mucus)
  • Sweet taste of the fluid
  • Double ring/target/halo sign: Central red (blood) + peripheral clear halo (CSF)
  • Reservoir sign: Sudden gush of CSF when rising from supine position

 

To confirm the diagnosis, the most specific and sensitive test is:

 

  • Beta-2 transferrin detection – found only in CSF, perilymph, and aqueous humor
  • Requires only a few drops of discharge
  • Not present in normal nasal secretions, making it diagnostic

 

Further localization may involve:

 

  • High-resolution CT (HRCT) for bony defects
  • MRI T2 for soft tissue defects/encephaloceles
  • Intrathecal fluorescein with endoscopy (if leak site is not obvious)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Conservative: Bed rest, head elevation, stool softeners, avoid straining
  • Surgical repair if leak persists: Endoscopic or external approach depending on site/size

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum eosinophil count and nasal smear: Relevant in allergic rhinitis, not CSF leak.

 

Option C. Nasal endoscopy with biopsy of the lesion: Nasal endoscopy with biopsy Useful if suspecting a tumor or polyp, not needed here.

 

Option D. Trial of intranasal corticosteroids and antihistamines: Trial of intranasal corticosteroids – Used in vasomotor or allergic rhinitis, not for CSF leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 transferrin testing of nasal discharge is the most specific and sensitive diagnostic test for confirming CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 163

choices.text: Samter’s triad
Kartagener syndrome
Young syndrome
Churg–Strauss syndrome

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with bilateral nasal obstruction, anosmia, and watery nasal discharge for 6 months. He has a history of asthma and frequent wheezing and reports severe episodes of nasal stuffiness after taking aspirin. On nasal endoscopy, multiple grape-like masses are seen arising from the middle meatus bilaterally. Which of the following syndromes most likely explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Samter’s triad

 

This patient’s presentation of bilateral ethmoidal nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin intolerance points strongly toward Samter’s triad, also known as aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD).

 

Associated conditions with nasal polyps include:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kartagener syndrome: Involves sinusitis and situs inversus but no aspirin intolerance or specific polyp triad.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Includes azoospermia, not seen here; rare.

 

Option D. Churg–Strauss syndrome: Can have asthma and eosinophilia, but typically includes vasculitis and systemic symptoms like fever, which are absent here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Samter’s triad is the association of nasal polyps, asthma, and aspirin intolerance, commonly leading to bilateral ethmoidal polyposis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis
Ciliated columnar epithelium covering dense fibrous stroma with neutrophilic infiltration
Oedematous submucosa with serous fluid, eosinophilic infiltration, and epithelial metaplasia
Hyperplastic squamous epithelium with keratin pearl formation and atypical mitoses

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a history of chronic rhinosinusitis and recurrent sneezing presents with nasal obstruction and hyposmia. On nasal endoscopy, bilateral ethmoidal polyps are seen hanging from the middle meatus. Which of the following best describes the underlying histopathological or pathophysiological process involved in polyp formation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oedematous submucosa with serous fluid, eosinophilic infiltration, and epithelial metaplasia

 

  • Pathogenesis of nasal polyps:
    • Starts with edema of the nasal mucosa, particularly near the middle meatus and turbinates
    • Extracellular fluid accumulates, causing polypoidal swelling
    • Initially sessile, polyps become pedunculated due to gravity and repeated sneezing
  • Histopathology:
    • Early polyps are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium, like normal nasal mucosa
    • Later undergo metaplasia to transitional or squamous epithelium due to atmospheric exposure
    • Submucosa shows:
      • Large intercellular spaces filled with serous fluid
      • Eosinophilic and round cell infiltration (lymphocytes/plasma cells)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis: Granulomatous inflammation with caseation is seen in tuberculosis, not nasal polyps.

 

Option B. Ciliated columnar epithelium covering dense fibrous stroma with neutrophilic infiltration: Neutrophilic infiltration is more typical of acute infections, not eosinophil-predominant polyps.

 

Option D. Hyperplastic squamous epithelium with keratin pearl formation and atypical mitoses: Keratin pearls and atypical mitoses suggest squamous cell carcinoma, not benign polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal polyps develop due to mucosal edema and serous fluid accumulation, with submucosal eosinophilic infiltration and epithelial metaplasia from ciliated to squamous type.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Hyperplasia of mucous glands leading to excessive mucus retention
Accumulation of extracellular fluid in the lamina propria causing polypoidal change
Fibrosis of the submucosa secondary to chronic inflammation
Vascular proliferation with angiomatous stroma forming a pedicle

questions.text: A 28-year-old atopic patient undergoes biopsy of bilateral ethmoidal nasal polyps. Histopathology shows surface epithelium similar to normal respiratory mucosa and marked submucosal edema with large intercellular spaces filled with serous fluid, along with eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis underlying these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Accumulation of extracellular fluid in the lamina propria causing polypoidal change

 

  • Pathogenesis of bilateral ethmoidal polyps involves oedematous swelling of the nasal mucosa, especially around the middle meatus and turbinate, due to collection of extracellular (serous) fluid in the submucosa, producing a sessile polyp that may become pedunculated under the influence of gravity and excessive sneezing.
  • Early pathology:
    • Surface lined by ciliated columnar epithelium (like normal nasal mucosa).
    • Submucosa shows large intercellular spaces filled with serous fluid.
    • Eosinophils and round-cell infiltrate are prominent.
  • Late changes (with atmospheric irritation):
    • Metaplasia of surface epithelium to transitional and then squamous type.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperplasia of mucous glands leading to excessive mucus retention: Mucous gland hyperplasia is not the primary driver; fluid accumulation, not mucus retention, forms the polyp.

 

Option C. Fibrosis of the submucosa secondary to chronic inflammation: Fibrosis may occur late, but the hallmark of early polyp formation is edema, not fibrosis.

 

Option D. Vascular proliferation with angiomatous stroma forming a pedicle: While polyps can become pedunculated, this is due to gravity on an oedematous base rather than true vascular stroma proliferation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral ethmoidal nasal polyps arise from extracellular fluid accumulation in the submucosa, leading to oedematous, polypoidal mucosal change.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Nasal septum
Middle meatus near uncinate process
Floor of the nasal cavity
Inferior turbinate

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with chronic nasal obstruction, hyposmia, and frequent sneezing. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals bilateral, pale, grape-like masses in the nasal cavity that are smooth, insensitive to touch, and do not bleed on probing. There is associated broadening of the nasal bridge, and CT scan shows multiple polypoidal masses arising from the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. Which of the following is the most likely site of origin of these polyps?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle meatus near uncinate process

 

  • Bilateral ethmoidal polyps:

    • Arise from the lateral wall of the nose, especially the middle meatus.

     

     

    • Common sites:
      • Uncinate process
      • Bulla ethmoidalis
      • Ostia of sinuses
      • Medial surface and edge of middle turbinate
  • Allergic nasal polyps:
    • Do not arise from the septum or the floor of the nose.
  • Symptoms include:
  1. Nasal obstruction (can be complete)
  2. Anosmia or hyposmia
  3. Sneezing and watery discharge
  4. Headache (due to associated sinusitis)
  5. Occasionally, visible mass protruding through the nostril
  • Signs:
    • Glistening, smooth, pale masses on anterior rhinoscopy

 

 

  • Non-tender, non-bleeding on probing
  • Broadening of nasal bridge, increased intercanthal distance in long-standing cases
  • May simulate tumor if vascular and exposed

  • Need to differentiate from turbinate hypertrophy or cystic middle turbinate

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal septum: Polyps almost never arise from the septum.

 

Option C. Floor of the nasal cavity: Rare site; not typical for allergic or 

ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option D. Inferior turbinate: Not a usual site of origin; polyps typically arise above this level in the middle meatus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral ethmoidal polyps typically arise from the middle meatus near the uncinate process and are characterized by pale, non-tender, non-bleeding, grape-like masses causing nasal obstruction and anosmia.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: CT scan of the paranasal sinuses to evaluate extent and exclude malignancy
Skin prick test to assess allergic sensitivity
Chest X-ray to rule out lower respiratory tract involvement
Pure tone audiometry to assess conductive hearing loss

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with chronic nasal obstruction, anosmia, and visible bilateral nasal masses on anterior rhinoscopy. The masses are pale, smooth, and non-bleeding on touch. To confirm the diagnosis and plan further management, which of the following investigations is most appropriate at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT scan of the paranasal sinuses to evaluate extent and exclude malignancy

 

  • Diagnosis of nasal polyps is often clinical, based on:
    • History (nasal obstruction, anosmia, sneezing)
    • Examination (anterior rhinoscopy showing pale, grape-like masses)
  • However, CT scan of the paranasal sinuses is essential for:
    • Evaluating the extent of polyps
    • Excluding bone erosion or expansion, which may suggest underlying malignancy
    • Planning surgical intervention
    • Important especially in patients >40 years, as polyps may occasionally hide malignancy underneath, requiring biopsy for histological confirmation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Skin prick test to assess allergic sensitivity: Skin prick test – Useful in allergic rhinitis, but does not evaluate extent or complications of polyps.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray to rule out lower respiratory tract involvement: Chest X-ray – May help in syndromes like Kartagener’s, but not helpful in routine nasal polyp workup.

 

Option D. Pure tone audiometry to assess conductive hearing loss: Pure tone audiometry – Relevant in middle ear pathology, not primary for nasal mass evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scan of paranasal sinuses is essential to evaluate extent, rule out bony erosion or underlying malignancy, and plan surgery in cases of nasal polyps.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Long-term oral corticosteroids with antihistamines
Transantral ethmoidectomy via Caldwell–Luc approach
Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)
Polypectomy using nasal snare under local anesthesia

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with bilateral ethmoidal nasal polyps presents with chronic nasal obstruction and hyposmia. He has a history of asthma and diabetes mellitus. Conservative treatment has failed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)

 

Treatment of nasal polyps depends on severity, number, extent, recurrence, and underlying comorbidities:

 

  • Conservative treatment:
  • Early stages with oedematous mucosa may improve with:
    • Antihistamines (especially in allergic rhinitis)
    • Short course of steroids (oral or topical), especially in patients with asthma
  • Steroids contraindicated in:
    • Hypertension, diabetes, peptic ulcer, pregnancy, TB
  • Surgical options:
  1. Polypectomy:
    • For few pedunculated polyps
    • Performed using snare or forceps
  2. Intranasal ethmoidectomy:
    • For multiple sessile polyps
    • Involves removal of ethmoidal air cells
  3. Extranasal ethmoidectomy:
    • For recurrent polyps
    • When anatomy distorted due to prior surgery
  4. Transantral ethmoidectomy:
    • When polypoidal changes and infection also involve the maxillary sinus
    • Via Caldwell–Luc approach
    • Now largely replaced by endoscopy
  5. Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS):
    • Current standard for multiple ethmoidal polyps
    • Done using angled endoscopes (0°, 30°, 70°)
    • Allows complete ethmoid clearance, improves sinus ventilation and drainage

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Long-term oral corticosteroids with antihistamines: Steroids are helpful but contraindicated in diabetes, and not definitive in extensive polyposis.

 

Options B. Transantral ethmoidectomy via Caldwell–Luc approach: Transantral approach is outdated and now superseded by FESS.

 

Options D. Polypectomy using nasal snare under local anesthesia: Simple polypectomy is inadequate for multiple sessile polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) is the treatment of choice for multiple ethmoidal nasal polyps, especially when conservative therapy fails.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Bilateral, multiple polyps with eosinophilic infiltration of the ethmoid
Polyp with an antral stalk, choanal globular part, and flat nasal portion
Arises from the ethmoidal bulla and presents as bilateral nasal masses
Common in elderly with a history of aspirin intolerance and asthma

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and snoring. On examination, a solitary, smooth mass is seen extending from the nasal cavity into the choana. CT scan reveals a lesion arising from the maxillary sinus near the accessory ostium. Which of the following best describes the features of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polyp with an antral stalk, choanal globular part, and flat nasal portion

 

 

The question describes a classic antrochoanal polyp (Killian’s polyp): 

 

  • Origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum, near the accessory ostium
  • Extension:
  1. Antral part – thin stalk
  2. Choanal part – round and globular
  3. Nasal part – flat from side to side
  • Typically:
    • Seen in children and young adults
    • Single and unilateral
    • Associated with nasal allergy and sinus infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral, multiple polyps with eosinophilic infiltration of the ethmoid: Describes bilateral ethmoidal polyps, often eosinophilic and related to allergy/asthma—not antrochoanal.

 

Option C. Arises from the ethmoidal bulla and presents as bilateral nasal masses: Ethmoidal bulla origin = ethmoidal polyps, usually bilateral, not antrochoanal.

 

Option D. Common in elderly with a history of aspirin intolerance and asthma: Aspirin intolerance and asthma are features of Samter’s triad, commonly associated with bilateral ethmoidal polyps, not Killian’s polyp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antrochoanal polyp is a single, unilateral polyp arising from the maxillary sinus near the accessory ostium, with three parts: antral stalk, choanal globular part, and nasal flat part.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Bilateral ethmoidal polyps; best seen on anterior rhinoscopy
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma; confirmed by biopsy and contrast MRI
Antrochoanal polyp; best visualized by posterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy
Adenoid hypertrophy; seen as a soft tissue shadow on lateral X-ray nasopharynx

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with progressive nasal obstruction, a thick and dull voice, and mucoid nasal discharge. Anterior rhinoscopy is inconclusive. Posterior rhinoscopy reveals a smooth, greyish, globular mass in the choana that can be moved with a probe. What is the most likely diagnosis, and how is it best visualized?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antrochoanal polyp; best visualized by posterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy

 

 

  • Antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp):
    • Common in children and young adults
    • Arises from maxillary sinus, grows through the accessory ostium
    • Extends into choana and nasopharynx
  • Symptoms:
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction
    • May become bilateral if the polyp obstructs both choanae
    • Hyponasal speech (thick/dull voice)
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
  • Signs:
    • May not be visible on anterior rhinoscopy if posterior
    • On posterior rhinoscopy or endoscopy:
      • Smooth grey mass in choana/nasopharynx
      • Can prolapse into the oropharynx
      • Mobile with probe
      • Exposed part may appear pink and congested
      • Endoscopy is especially useful to locate hidden posterior polyps

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral ethmoidal polyps; best seen on anterior rhinoscopy: Bilateral ethmoidal polyps are multiple and anterior; clearly seen on anterior rhinoscopy, unlike antrochoanal polyp.

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma; confirmed by biopsy and contrast MRI: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents differently — not mobile, not soft, often associated with epistaxis or neck nodes.

 

Option D. Adenoid hypertrophy; seen as a soft tissue shadow on lateral X-ray nasopharynx: Adenoid hypertrophy may cause nasal obstruction, but not a prolapsed polypoidal mass in oropharynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antrochoanal polyp presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, dull voice, and is best visualized using posterior rhinoscopy or nasal endoscopy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Mass disappears after blowing the nose
Mass is soft, mobile, and non-bleeding on probing
Mass arises from lateral nasal wall and is pale
Nasal obstruction with anosmia and hyponasal voice

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with nasal obstruction and a mass visible in the nasal cavity. On examination, a smooth greyish mass is seen, which is non-tender, does not bleed on probing, and can be moved freely. Which of the following findings would rule out a nasal polyp and suggest an alternate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mass disappears after blowing the nose

 

This question tests your understanding of the differential diagnoses of nasal polypoidal lesions:

 

 

Thus, a mass that disappears after nose blowing is not a true polyp—it's likely just a mucus blob, which can mimic a nasal polyp on initial inspection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass is soft, mobile, and non-bleeding on probing: These are typical features of a nasal polyp.

 

Option C. Mass arises from lateral nasal wall and is pale: Nasal polyps commonly arise from the lateral nasal wall, especially near the middle meatus.

 

Option D. Nasal obstruction with anosmia and hyponasal voice: These symptoms (obstruction, anosmia, hyponasal speech) are consistent with nasal polyposis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A nasal mass that disappears after nose blowing is a mucus blob and not a true polyp.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 174

choices.text: Ethmoidal polyps
Antrochoanal polyp
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
Allergic fungal sinusitis

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and mouth breathing. On posterior rhinoscopy, a smooth globular mass is seen hanging behind the soft palate. CT scan reveals a single polyp arising from the maxillary sinus, extending through the choana into the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antrochoanal polyp

 

The features are classic for an antrochoanal polyp:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethmoidal polyps: Typically bilateral, multiple, and occur in adults.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Seen in adolescent males, causes profuse epistaxis, firm and vascular on exam.

 

 

Option D. Allergic fungal sinusitis: Associated with allergy, often bilateral, and has hyperdense sinus opacities on CT.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antrochoanal polyps are solitary, unilateral polyps in children that arise from the maxillary sinus and grow into the choana and nasopharynx.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 176

choices.text: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
Antrochoanal polyp
Hypertrophied middle turbinate
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with nasal obstruction and a mass seen in the postnasal space on lateral X-ray of the nasopharynx. The lesion appears as a globular soft tissue shadow, with a column of air visible behind it. There is no epistaxis, and the mass is non-tender, does not bleed on probing, and can be moved. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antrochoanal polyp

 

 

This is a classic case of antrochoanal polyp:

 

  • Posterior extension of the polyp into the choana or nasopharynx
  • X-ray lateral view shows globular soft tissue mass in the nasopharynx
  • Column of air behind the mass is a key distinguishing feature from angiofibroma
  • Non-bleeding, soft, mobile on probing
  • Occurs in children or young adults

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

 

  • Common in adolescent males
  • Presents with profuse recurrent epistaxis
  • Firm, bleeds on probing, no column of air behind it on X-ray

 

 

Option C. Hypertrophied middle turbinate:

 

  • Appears pink, bony hard on probing, not mobile
  • Located anteriorly, not in postnasal space

 

 

concha bullosa

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

 

  • Seen in older adults, associated with neck lymphadenopathy, epistaxis, constitutional symptoms
  • Infiltrative, not mobile or soft

 

Educational Objective:

 

A soft, mobile mass in the postnasal space with a column of air behind it on lateral X-ray is most likely an antrochoanal polyp, not angiofibroma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 175

choices.text: Repeat simple polypectomy via nasal snare
Start oral corticosteroids to reduce the size of the polyp
Perform Caldwell–Luc operation to clear maxillary sinus
Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to remove the polyp at its origin

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is diagnosed with a unilateral antrochoanal polyp extending into the nasopharynx. It is avulsed completely via the nasal route. Two months later, he presents with similar symptoms and recurrence is confirmed. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to remove the polyp at its origin

 

  • Antrochoanal polyps are usually removed by avulsion (nasal or oral route).
  • Recurrence is uncommon if the entire polyp, including its antral origin, is removed.
  • In cases of recurrence, modern standard of care is:
    • Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS):
      • Accesses the maxillary sinus
      • Removes the site of origin (usually near accessory ostium)
      • Treats coexisting maxillary sinusitis
      • Minimally invasive, preserves normal anatomy
  • Caldwell–Luc operation:
  • Now largely avoided, especially in children, due to risk of damage to developing teeth and sinus walls
  • Previously used for recurrent cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat simple polypectomy via nasal snare: Repeat simple polypectomy Won’t address the origin in the maxillary sinus, so recurrence likely.

 

Option B. Start oral corticosteroids to reduce the size of the polyp: Corticosteroids Not first-line for antrochoanal polyps, which are usually non-inflammatory and non-eosinophilic.

 

Option C. Perform Caldwell–Luc operation to clear maxillary sinus: Caldwell–Luc operation Outdated; avoided in children and replaced by FESS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent antrochoanal polyps are best managed by functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to remove the polyp from its origin in the maxillary sinus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 175

choices.text: Start intranasal steroids and plan polypectomy under general anesthesia
Diagnose as nasal glioma and send for oncological referral
Suspect a meningoencephalocele; avoid surgical removal and consult neurosurgery
Remove the mass using snare through transnasal approach

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a unilateral, smooth nasal mass. Examination reveals a soft, polypoidal lesion arising from the nasal cavity. The child has no history of allergy or asthma. The mass is aspirated and found to contain clear fluid, with subsequent testing revealing beta-2 transferrin. What is the most appropriate conclusion or next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suspect a meningoencephalocele; avoid surgical removal and consult neurosurgery

 

This question integrates several key red flags when dealing with nasal polyps, especially in children:

 

  • A nasal mass in a child could be a glioma, encephalocele, or meningoencephalocele, especially if:
    • There is CSF-like fluid
    • The mass transilluminates
    • Beta-2 transferrin is present in aspirate (specific for CSF)
  • Careless removal of such a lesion without prior imaging or confirmation can lead to:
    • CSF rhinorrhoea
    • Meningitis
    • Potentially fatal complications

 

Always aspirate suspicious polyps in children and examine for CSF before any attempt at removal.

Additional red flags for malignancy in nasal polyp cases include:

 

  • Red, fleshy, friable, granular masses, especially in older patients
  • Epistaxis or orbital symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start intranasal steroids and plan polypectomy under general anesthesia: Steroids and polypectomy are contraindicated in suspected meningoencephaloceles.

 

Option B. Diagnose as nasal glioma and send for oncological referral: Glioma is a differential, but beta-2 transferrin positivity confirms CSF, ruling that out.

 

Option D. Remove the mass using snare through transnasal approach: Transnasal snare removal without ruling out a cranial communication is dangerous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A nasal polyp-like mass in a child must be aspirated to rule out CSF-containing lesions like encephaloceles before any surgical removal is attempted.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 175

choices.text: Strip off bone fragments from periosteum and discard them
Neurosurgical repair with duroplasty and obliteration of sinus
Elevate bone fragments while preserving periosteal attachment and inspect sinus cavity
Obliterate the sinus immediately with fat without further inspection

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with a depressed fracture over the forehead after a road traffic accident. CT scan reveals a comminuted anterior wall fracture of the frontal sinus, with no CSF leak. During surgery, the interior of the sinus is examined, and no posterior wall involvement is found. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevate bone fragments while preserving periosteal attachment and inspect sinus cavity

  • Frontal sinus fractures may involve:

 

 

  • Anterior wall
  • Posterior wall
  • Nasofrontal duct

 

Anterior wall fractures:

 

 

  • Usually cosmetic deformities
  • Can be depressed or comminuted
  • Managed via:
    • Brow incision or through existing wound
    • Bone fragments are elevated, but should not be stripped off periosteum
    • Always inspect sinus cavity for posterior wall involvement
    • Posterior wall fractures:

 

 

  • More serious: may cause dural tears, CSF rhinorrhoea, and brain injury
  • Require neurosurgical input
  • Dural defects can be repaired with temporalis fascia
  • Small sinuses can be obliterated with fat

 

Nasofrontal duct injury:

 

 

 

The frontal sinus drains via the frontal recess, shown by the curved lines. In image (a), the agger nasi cell (marked by an asterisk) is located anterior to the frontal recess. In image (b), the uncinate process (arrow) is seen attaching superiorly to the fovea ethmoidalis (arrowhead). This superior attachment directs the drainage pathway of the frontal recess into the infundibulum.

 

  • Causes drainage obstruction
  • Can lead to mucocele formation
  • Managed by creating a large communication with nasal cavity or obliterating the sinus (after removing mucosa)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strip off bone fragments from periosteum and discard them: Stripping bone from periosteum reduces vascularity → poor healing.

 

Option B. Neurosurgical repair with duroplasty and obliteration of sinus: Neurosurgical repair is needed only if posterior wall or dura is involved.

 

Option D. Obliterate the sinus immediately with fat without further inspection: Obliteration with fat is used only in select cases, especially small sinuses or when duct obstruction is unmanageable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior wall frontal sinus fractures, elevate bone fragments while preserving periosteum and always inspect the sinus for posterior wall involvement.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 181

choices.text: Conservative observation with head elevation and cold compresses
Immediate globe decompression via lateral canthotomy
Open reduction via brow or transverse forehead incision
Endoscopic sinus surgery to decompress the orbit

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following blunt trauma to the forehead. He has periorbital ecchymosis, flattening of the eyebrow, and mild proptosis with downward displacement of the globe. CT scan reveals a fracture of the supraorbital ridge with a bone fragment displaced into the orbit. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open reduction via brow or transverse forehead incision

 

  • Supraorbital ridge fractures are often caused by blunt trauma to the upper face.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Periorbital ecchymosis
    • Flattening of the eyebrow
    • Proptosis or downward displacement of the eye
    • In some cases, bone fragments may get impacted into the orbit
    • Definitive treatment:
    • Open reduction is the management of choice
    • Approach is through a brow incision or transverse forehead skin line
    • This allows proper visualization and repositioning of the bone fragment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conservative observation with head elevation and cold compresses: Observation is insufficient when there’s displacement or orbital involvement.

 

Option B. Immediate globe decompression via lateral canthotomy: Lateral canthotomy is done in orbital compartment syndrome, not bony ridge fractures.

 

Option D. Endoscopic sinus surgery to decompress the orbit: Endoscopic sinus surgery is not indicated for supraorbital ridge fractures—it’s used for sinus pathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supraorbital ridge fractures with orbital displacement require open reduction via brow or forehead incision to reposition impacted bone fragments.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 181

choices.text: Open-book fracture due to severe frontal blow
Depressed fracture of nasal bone with frontal process involvement
Angulated fracture due to lateral impact
Compound comminuted fracture with exposed bone fragments

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being punched in the face. He complains of nasal pain, swelling, and bleeding. On examination, there is periorbital ecchymosis, deviation of the nasal bridge, and crepitus on palpation. CT scan shows unilateral depression of the nasal bone with septal deviation. Which of the following is the most likely type of nasal fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angulated fracture due to lateral impact

 

  • Types of nasal fractures:

 

  1. Depressed fractures – Due to frontal blow, involve the lower part of nasal bones; severe trauma can cause open-book fracture with septal collapse and splaying of nasal bones.
  2. Angulated fractures – Due to lateral blow, causing:

 

  • Unilateral depression of nasal bone
  • Or bilateral fracture with septal deviation

 

 

Types of fractures. (A) Normal. (B) Frontal blow causing depressed fracture or open-book fracture. (C) Lateral blow causing deviation of nasal bridge or depression of one nasal bone.

 

  • Associated findings:
    • Swelling of nose (may obscure deformity)
    • Periorbital ecchymosis
    • Tenderness and crepitus
    • Deviation or depression of nasal bridge
    • Nasal obstruction (due to septal fracture or hematoma)
    • Epistaxis
    • Laceration and bone/cartilage exposure in compound fractures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open-book fracture due to severe frontal blow: Open-book fracture – Caused by severe frontal trauma, with nasal septum collapse and widely splayed bones — not seen here.

 

Option B. Depressed fracture of nasal bone with frontal process involvement: Depressed fracture with frontal process involvement – Requires greater force than lateral trauma.

 

Option D. Compound comminuted fracture with exposed bone fragments: Compound comminuted fracture – Would present with external lacerations and bone exposure, not mentioned here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral blows to the nose typically cause angulated fractures with unilateral depression and septal deviation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 182

choices.text: Reassure the patient as X-rays do not show a fracture
Wait 2 weeks for fracture healing before attempting reduction
Plan for closed reduction after edema subsides (in 5–7 days)
Immediate open reduction through external incision

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents 6 hours after a sports injury to the nose. He has swelling, epistaxis, tenderness, and deviation of the nasal bridge. X-rays (Waters' and lateral views) are inconclusive. What is the most appropriate management step at this point?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plan for closed reduction after edema subsides (in 5–7 days)

 

  • Diagnosis:
    • Primarily clinical: swelling, tenderness, nasal deformity, crepitus
    • X-rays may not always show fractures, so absence of findings does not rule it out
    • Views to be taken: Waters’, lateral views (right and left), and occlusal view

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Simple, non-displaced fractures → no intervention
    • Displaced or depressed fractures → require reduction
    • Timing is critical:
    • After oedema subsides in 5–7 days
    • >2 weeks: fracture healing begins, and closed reduction becomes difficult or impossible
    • Requires rhinoplasty or septorhinoplasty for deformity correction
  • Closed reduction:
    • Done with blunt elevators, digital pressure
    • Asch’s and Walsham’s forceps used for septal and bony alignment
    • Septal hematomas must be drained
    • Packing and splints used for unstable fractures
  • Open reduction:
    • Rarely needed early
    • Reserved for:
      • Failed closed reductions
      • Complex septal injuries

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure the patient as X-rays do not show a fracture: Diagnosis is not ruled out by normal X-rays; clinical findings matter more.

 

Option B. Wait 2 weeks for fracture healing before attempting reduction: Waiting 2 weeks results in healing, making reduction more difficult.

 

Option D. Immediate open reduction through external incision: Open reduction is not first-line unless closed reduction fails or in selected septal injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Closed reduction of nasal fractures is best performed before edema sets in or after it subsides in 5–7 days; normal X-rays do not exclude nasal fractures.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 183

choices.text: Le Fort II fracture
Naso-orbital fracture
Tripod fracture
Orbital floor blowout fracture

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with periorbital ecchymosis, CSF rhinorrhoea, and lateral displacement of the medial canthus. On examination, the bridge of the nose is flattened, and the nasal tip is turned upwards. CT scan reveals fractures of the nasal bones, ethmoid air cells, cribriform plate, and medial orbital walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naso-orbital fracture

 

 

 

This case presents with classic findings of a naso-orbital fracture:

 

  • Mechanism: Direct blow to the nasion, causing:
    • Fracture of nasal bones, ethmoid, medial orbital wall
    • Cribriform plate, frontal sinus, lacrimal apparatus, and medial canthal ligament may also be involved
  • Clinical features:
    • Telecanthus: Lateral displacement of the medial canthal ligament
    • Pug nose: Depressed nasal bridge with upturned tip
    • Periorbital ecchymosis
    • Orbital hematoma from anterior/posterior ethmoidal artery injury
    • CSF leak from cribriform plate/dural injury
    • Globe displacement
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT scan is the most accurate tool to assess bone injury extent
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction for uncomplicated cases using Asch’s forceps, wires, splints
    • Open reduction with H-type incision if:
      • Fractures are comminuted
      • Involves lacrimal system, medial canthus, frontal sinus
    • Restoration of canthal ligament and lacrimal system is prioritized over nasal contour in complex cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le Fort II fracture: Involves maxilla, infraorbital rim, nasal bones, but telecanthus and CSF rhinorrhoea are less prominent.

 

Option C. Tripod fracture: Involves zygoma, not nasal bones or medial orbit.

 

Option D. Orbital floor blowout fracture: Blowout fracture: Limited to orbital floor; presents with enophthalmos and diplopia, not telecanthus or CSF leak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naso-orbital fractures present with telecanthus, CSF leak, and pug nose deformity and require CT for diagnosis and surgical repair of canthal ligaments and lacrimal apparatus if injured.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 183–184

choices.text: Blow-out fracture of the orbital floor
Tripod fracture of the zygoma
Naso-orbital fracture
Le Fort II fracture

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents after blunt trauma to the left cheek. Examination reveals flattensing of the malar prominence, step deformity at the infraorbital margin, numbness of the cheek, and difficulty opening the mouth. CT imaging shows a fracture involving the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital rim, orbital floor, and anterior wall of the maxillary sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tripod fracture of the zygoma

 

 

 

A Tripod fracture (also known as zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture) involves:

 

  • Three key separations of the zygoma:
  1. Zygomaticofrontal suture
  2. Zygomaticotemporal suture
  3. Infraorbital rim and orbital floor (may involve the infraorbital foramen)

 

Fracture also affects the anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, allowing orbital contents to herniate into the sinus.

 

 

Clinical Features:

 

  1. Flattened malar prominence (due to medial and posterior displacement)
  2. Step deformity at infraorbital margin
  3. Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia (numbness over cheek)
  4. Trismus – due to impingement on the coronoid process
  5. Oblique palpebral fissure – due to lateral palpebral ligament displacement
  6. Diplopia/restricted eye movements – from inferior rectus entrapment
  7. Periorbital emphysema – air escape from maxillary sinus during nose blowing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blow-out fracture of the orbital floor: Blow-out fracture Limited to orbital floor and medial wall, causes diplopia and enophthalmos, but doesn’t involve malar flattening or trismus.

 

Option C. Naso-orbital fracture: Affects medial orbit, nasion, and canthal ligaments, presents with telecanthus, not malar flattening.

 

Option D. Le Fort II fracture: Involves maxilla and nasal bones, not isolated zygoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tripod fracture involves the zygoma at three sites—zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital rim/floor, and zygomaticotemporal suture—causing malar flattening, infraorbital numbness, and trismus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184–185

choices.text: Closed reduction with nasal packing and splinting
Open reduction with internal fixation via lateral brow and infraorbital incisions
Transantral approach with intranasal antrostomy
Conservative management with steroids and antibiotics

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with left-sided facial trauma after a road traffic accident. Examination reveals flattening of the malar prominence, infraorbital step deformity, and diplopia. X-ray Waters’ view shows opacification of the maxillary sinus and displacement of the zygomatic complex. CT confirms fracture of the orbital floor with herniation of contents. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Open reduction with internal fixation via lateral brow and infraorbital incisions

 

  • In tripod fracture, displaced zygomatic bone involving the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and zygomaticotemporal suture leads to:
    • Malar flattening
    • Step deformity
    • Diplopia (due to orbital floor fracture and inferior rectus entrapment)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Waters’ view: Shows sinus opacification and bony displacement
    • CT scan: Best to visualize orbital floor comminution and herniation of orbital contents
  • Treatment:
    • Only displaced fractures require intervention
    • Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF) is the treatment of choice:
      • Lateral brow incision for frontozygomatic suture exposure
      • Lower lid incision for infraorbital rim and orbital floor
  • Transantral approach is less favored nowadays, used only when other routes are contraindicated

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Closed reduction with nasal packing and splinting: Closed reduction with nasal packing – Insufficient for complex tripod fractures with orbital floor involvement.

 

Option C. Transantral approach with intranasal antrostomy: Transantral approach – Considered outdated and less favorable, not first-line.

 

Option D. Conservative management with steroids and antibiotics: Conservative management – Not suitable in displaced fractures with orbital involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Displaced tripod fractures of the zygoma require open reduction and internal fixation through lateral brow and infraorbital incisions, with CT used for orbital floor assessment.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184

choices.text: Waters’ view
Submentovertical view
Lateral view of skull
Caldwell’s view

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with pain over the left side of his face following trauma. He complains of pain while chewing and is unable to open his mouth fully. On examination, there is a depression in the region of the zygomatic arch and trismus. Which of the following is the best imaging view for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Submentovertical view

 

  • Fractures of the zygomatic arch typically break into two depressed fragments with three fracture lines—one at each end and one centrally.
  • Classical signs include:
    • Local pain over the arch
    • Trismus (due to impingement on coronoid/condylar process)
    • Depression in the arch area
  • Submentovertical view is the best radiographic angle to detect zygomatic arch fractures, as it gives a clear silhouette of the arch curvature.

 

 

  • Waters’ view may be used but is less sensitive for the arch specifically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waters’ view: Good for maxillary sinus and orbital floor, but not ideal for arch visualization.

 

Option C. Lateral view of skull: Lateral view Overlapping bones obscure the zygomatic arch.

 

Option D. Caldwell’s view: Best for frontal and ethmoidal sinuses, not the arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zygomatic arch fractures present with trismus and are best visualized on submentovertical radiographic view.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 185

choices.text: Zygomatic arch fracture
Le Fort I fracture
Orbital floor blow-out fracture
Nasal bone fracture

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents after being hit in the face with a cricket ball. Examination reveals periorbital ecchymosis, diplopia on upward gaze, enophthalmos, and loss of sensation over the cheek and upper lip. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orbital floor blow-out fracture

 

  • Blow-out fractures are isolated fractures of the orbital floor, typically caused by blunt trauma (e.g. ball injury).

 

 

 

  • Classical signs include:
    • Ecchymosis of eyelid, conjunctiva, and sclera
    • Enophthalmos with inferior displacement of the globe (due to herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus)
    • Diplopia, especially on upward gaze, due to entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique
    • Hypoaesthesia of cheek and upper lip due to infraorbital nerve injury
  • Zygomatic and Le Fort II fractures also involve the orbital floor, but isolated blow-out fracture is the classic presentation with these features after blunt trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zygomatic arch fracture: Presents with flattening of malar prominence and trismus, not enophthalmos/diplopia.

 

Option B. Le Fort I fracture: Horizontal maxillary fracture; no direct involvement of orbit.

 

Option D. Nasal bone fracture: Causes nasal deformity and epistaxis, not enophthalmos or diplopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blow-out fracture of the orbital floor presents with enophthalmos, diplopia due to muscle entrapment, and infraorbital hypoaesthesia following blunt trauma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184

choices.text: Reassurance and observation only
Transnasal orbital decompression
Infraorbital or transantral surgical approach to reduce the fracture
Exenteration of the orbit

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with diplopia and enophthalmos after being hit on the face by a cricket ball. Examination shows restricted upward gaze in the right eye and hypoaesthesia of the cheek. Waters’ view reveals a convex opacity bulging into the maxillary antrum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infraorbital or transantral surgical approach to reduce the fracture

 

  • This is a classic orbital floor blow-out fracture.
  • Waters’ view shows a tear-drop opacity—a hallmark of herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus.

 

 

  • Restricted upward gaze indicates entrapment of inferior rectus or inferior oblique, confirmed by traction test.
  • Indications for surgery: persistent diplopia, enophthalmos, and muscle entrapment.
  • Surgical options include:
    • Transantral approach (via maxillary sinus): used to elevate the floor and support with packing.
    • Infraorbital (lower lid) approach: often combined to access and repair floor fractures.
    • In comminuted fractures, bone grafts (from iliac crest, nasal septum, or anterior antral wall) or silicon/teflon implants may be used for orbital floor reconstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance and observation only: Reassurance and observation – Not sufficient here due to persistent diplopia and enophthalmos.

 

Option B. Transnasal orbital decompression: Used in thyroid orbitopathy, not for traumatic orbital floor fractures.

 

Option D. Exenteration of the orbit: Indicated for malignant orbital tumors, not trauma-related fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Persistent diplopia or enophthalmos after orbital floor fracture requires surgical repair via infraorbital or transantral approach; tear-drop opacity on Waters’ view is a key radiological clue.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184

choices.text: Le Fort I fracture
Le Fort II fracture
Le Fort III fracture
Zygomatic complex fracture

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department following a high-velocity road traffic accident. He complains of facial pain and has malocclusion of teeth, elongation of the midface, and CSF rhinorrhoea. On examination, mobility of the entire maxilla is noted. CT scan shows a fracture line extending through the root of the nose, ethmoidal region, superior orbital fissure, and frontozygomatic suture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Le Fort III fracture

 

  • The clinical features described — malocclusion, elongation of midface, mobility of maxilla, and CSF rhinorrhoea — suggest a high-level maxillary fracture.
  • The fracture line in Le Fort III involves root of the nose, ethmofrontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures, and upper pterygoid plates — causing craniofacial dysjunction.

 

  1. Le Fort I , B. Le Fort II , C. Le Fort III

 

  • Cribriform plate injury → CSF rhinorrhoea is a hallmark of Le Fort II and III fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le Fort I fracture: Transverse fracture above the alveolus, no CSF rhinorrhoea, no craniofacial separation.

 

Option B. Le Fort II fracture: Pyramidal fracture with possible CSF leak, but does not involve frontozygomatic sutures or full craniofacial disjunction.

 

Option D. Zygomatic complex fracture: Involves malar prominence, trismus, and infraorbital nerve anesthesia, but not midface mobility or CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Le Fort III fracture is a craniofacial dysjunction involving the ethmofrontal junction and frontozygomatic sutures, commonly associated with midface elongation, maxillary mobility, and CSF rhinorrhoea.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184

choices.text: Immediate open reduction and interosseous wiring
Fixation using interdental wiring
Ensure airway patency and control bleeding
Obtain a Waters’ view X-ray and proceed with intermaxillary fixation

questions.text: A 25-year-old male sustains maxillofacial trauma in a motorcycle accident. He has malocclusion, facial swelling, and difficulty breathing. On examination, active nasal bleeding and signs of midface mobility are noted. What is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ensure airway patency and control bleeding

 

  • Maxillary fractures can compromise the airway and cause life-threatening hemorrhage from branches of the maxillary artery.

 

A. Le Fort I , B. Le Fort II , C. Le Fort III

 

  • Hence, initial management focuses on airway stabilization and control of bleeding, which are essential before definitive fracture treatment.
  • Once stabilized, imaging like Waters’, PA, lateral views and CT scan help delineate fracture lines.
  • Definitive fixation options include:
    • Interdental wiring
    • Intermaxillary fixation (arch bars)
    • Open reduction with interosseous wiring
    • Wire slings to stable facial bones

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate open reduction and interosseous wiring: Immediate open reduction – Not done before airway and bleeding control, especially in acute trauma setting.

 

Option B. Fixation using interdental wiring: Interdental wiring – Part of definitive management, not the initial step.

 

Option D. Obtain a Waters’ view X-ray and proceed with intermaxillary fixation: 
X-ray and fixation – Imaging is important, but airway and bleeding take priority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of maxillary fractures prioritizes airway protection and hemorrhage control before imaging and surgical fixation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 184

choices.text: Immediate open reduction and plating of the condyle
Conservative management with intermaxillary fixation and jaw exercises
Mandibular osteotomy with condylectomy
External pin fixation through the zygomatic arch

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents after a road traffic accident with jaw pain, trismus, and tenderness near the preauricular region. On opening the mouth, there is deviation of the jaw to the left. X-ray shows a right condylar fracture without significant displacement. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conservative management with intermaxillary fixation and jaw exercises

 

  • Condylar fractures are the most common mandibular fractures.

 

 

  • If non-displaced, they usually present with pain, trismus, and tenderness over the condyle.
  • Displaced ones may show malocclusion and jaw deviation (typically to the opposite side on opening the mouth).
  • Initial treatment involves closed reduction with intermaxillary fixation (IMF) using arch bars and rubber bands.
  • Jaw exercises should be started after 3 weeks, as prolonged immobilization can cause temporomandibular joint ankylosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open reduction and plating: Reserved for edentulous patients with bilateral condylar fractures, not first-line in non-displaced unilateral fractures.

 

Option C. Osteotomy with condylectomy: Indicated in severe TMJ deformities or ankylosis, not in fresh condylar fracture.

 

Option D. External pin fixation: Used in unstable open fractures, not for condylar fractures managed conservatively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most condylar fractures of the mandible are managed conservatively with intermaxillary fixation followed by early mobilization to prevent TMJ ankylosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 185

choices.text: Acute maxillary sinusitis
Nasal vestibulitis
Oroantral fistula
Ethmoidal polyp

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with foul-smelling nasal discharge, regurgitation of fluids through the nose when drinking, and difficulty playing wind instruments. He had an upper molar extraction 3 weeks ago. On examination, a probe could be passed from the gingivolabial sulcus into the maxillary sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oroantral fistula

 

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Regurgitation of fluids from the mouth to the nose
  • Foul nasal discharge
  • Inability to build oral pressure (difficulty drinking through straw/wind instruments)
  • History of molar tooth extraction
