  • Positive probe test passing from the oral cavity to the maxillary antrum

 

All these point toward Oroantral Fistula, which is a communication between the oral cavity and the maxillary sinus, most commonly resulting from extraction of upper premolars and molars.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute maxillary sinusitis: Though sinus infection may coexist, this would not explain regurgitation of fluids or positive probe test.

 

Option B. Nasal vestibulitis: Presents with localized nasal pain and swelling, not oroantral communication.

 

Option D. Ethmoidal polyp: Causes nasal obstruction and discharge but doesn’t involve fluid regurgitation or oral cavity communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oroantral fistula presents with regurgitation of fluids, nasal discharge, and inability to build oral pressure, most commonly after upper molar extraction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 186

choices.text: Frontal sinus
Maxillary sinus
Anterior ethmoidal sinus
Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with chronic nasal blockage and postnasal drip. Nasal endoscopy shows mucopurulent discharge in the middle meatus. CT PNS reveals inflammation in the maxillary and frontal sinuses. Which of the following sinuses is LEAST likely to drain into the middle meatus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoid sinus

 

Sphenoid sinus – Correct. It drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess, and is classified under the posterior group of sinuses.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Chronic nasal obstruction
  • Mucopurulent discharge in the middle meatus
  • Imaging shows involvement of maxillary and frontal sinuses, which are known to drain into the middle meatus
  • The question tests the knowledge of paranasal sinus drainage anatomy, particularly the distinction between anterior and posterior sinus groups.
  • Frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses belong to the anterior group, and all open into the middle meatus. Their ostia are located anterior to the basal lamella of the middle turbinate.
  • The sphenoid sinus, however, is part of the posterior group and opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, not the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal sinus: Drains into the middle meatus via the frontonasal duct; part of the anterior group.

 

Option B. Maxillary sinus: Also drains into the middle meatus; commonly involved in sinusitis due to gravity-dependent drainage.

 

Option C. Anterior ethmoidal sinus: Part of the anterior group, drains into the middle meatus anterior to the basal lamella.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain into the middle meatus, whereas the sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

choices.text: Its floor lies above the floor of the nasal cavity
Its ostium opens into the inferior meatus
Its roof forms the floor of the orbit and transmits the infraorbital nerve
It is the smallest of the paranasal sinuses

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with right cheek swelling, postnasal drip, and dull pain over the maxillary region following recent dental extraction of the first molar. Imaging shows fluid level in the right maxillary sinus. Which of the following statements regarding the maxillary sinus is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Its roof forms the floor of the orbit and transmits the infraorbital nerve

 

The infraorbital nerve and vessels traverse the roof of the maxillary sinus, which is also the floor of the orbit.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Facial pain and cheek swelling suggestive of maxillary sinusitis
  • History of first molar extraction, a common predisposing factor for dental origin maxillary sinusitis due to close proximity of tooth roots to the sinus floor
  • CT shows a fluid level, confirming sinus involvement

 

The maxillary sinus is the largest paranasal sinus, occupying the body of the maxilla. It is pyramidal in shape, with the base towards the nasal wall and the apex towards the zygomatic process.

 

The roof of the sinus is formed by the floor of the orbit, and it is traversed by the infraorbital nerve and vessels, making option C correct.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its floor lies above the floor of the nasal cavity: Incorrect. The floor of the maxillary sinus lies about 1 cm below the nasal floor and is related to roots of molar and premolar teeth, predisposing to oroantral fistula.

 

Option B. Its ostium opens into the inferior meatus: Incorrect. The ostium opens into the posteroinferior part of the ethmoidal infundibulum which drains into the middle meatus, not the inferior meatus.

 

Option D. It is the smallest of the paranasal sinuses: Incorrect. The maxillary sinus is the largest of all paranasal sinuses, with an average adult volume of 15 mL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The roof of the maxillary sinus is formed by the floor of the orbit and is traversed by the infraorbital nerve and vessels.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

choices.text: Frontal sinus drains into the superior meatus through the nasofrontal duct
Frontal sinus lies below the supraorbital margin between the two plates of ethmoid bone
Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis
The intersinus septum of frontal sinuses is thick and centrally placed in all individuals

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with recurrent frontal headaches, especially in the mornings, and tenderness above the supraorbital margin. CT scan shows mucosal thickening in the frontal sinus and blockage of the frontal recess. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the anatomy and drainage of the frontal sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis

 

Frontal sinus drains into the superior meatus through the nasofrontal duct: Incorrect. It drains into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontal recess. The term “nasofrontal duct” is outdated and incorrect as no true duct exists.

 

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Morning frontal headaches
  • Tenderness above the supraorbital margin
  • CT evidence of frontal sinusitis with frontal recess obstruction

 

The frontal sinus lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, situated between the inner and outer tables of the frontal bone. Its drainage pathway is through the frontal ostium into the frontal recess, which is anatomically bounded by:

 

  • Middle turbinate (medially)
  • Lamina papyracea (laterally)
  • Agger nasi cells (anteriorly)
  • Bulla ethmoidalis (posteriorly)

 

Obstruction of this narrow and often tortuous drainage pathway by anterior ethmoidal cells can cause frontal sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal sinus lies below the supraorbital margin between the two plates of ethmoid bone: Incorrect. It lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, within the frontal bone, not ethmoid bone.

 

Option C. Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis: Correct. This relationship defines the anatomy of the frontal recess, and is crucial in understanding obstruction mechanisms in frontal sinusitis.

 

Option D. The intersinus septum of frontal sinuses is thick and centrally placed in all individuals: Incorrect. The septum is often thin, oblique, or even absent, and the two sinuses are often asymmetrical.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus drains into the middle meatus via the frontal recess, which is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

choices.text: Agger nasi cell
Ethmoid bulla
Onodi cell
Haller cell

questions.text: A 35-year-old man undergoing endoscopic sinus surgery for nasal polyps develops sudden visual loss during dissection near the sphenoid sinus. CT scan shows injury near a posterior ethmoid cell extending beyond the sphenoid. Which of the following anatomical structures is most likely involved in the complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Onodi cell

 

 

This is a posterior ethmoidal air cell, often extending posterior or superolateral to the sphenoid sinus. It may be intimately related to the optic nerve and carotid artery, risking injury during endoscopic dissection.

 

This patient presents with:

  • Sudden visual loss during endoscopic sinus surgery,
  • Surgery was being done near the posterior ethmoid region,
  • Imaging shows involvement of a posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends

 

superior or lateral to the sphenoid sinus, indicating an Onodi cell injury.

 

Onodi cell, or sphenoethmoid cell, is the most posterior ethmoidal air cell. It may extend lateral or superior to the sphenoid sinus and lie in close proximity to the optic nerve and sometimes the internal carotid artery, placing them at high risk during sinus surgery.

 

 

Arrow shows onodi cell and stars show sphenoid sinuses

 

Other Options:

 

Option Agger nasi cell:  An anterior ethmoid cell found in the agger nasi ridge, anterior to the bulla. It does not lie near the optic nerve or sphenoid sinus and is not responsible for visual complications during surgery.

 

 

Option B. Ethmoid bulla: Part of the anterior ethmoid group and forms the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris. It is unrelated to the optic nerve or sphenoid sinus.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell: An anterior ethmoid air cell, located in the floor of the orbit, not near the sphenoid sinus or optic nerve. Associated with obstruction of the infundibulum, not visual loss.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoid cell that lies close to the optic nerve and may lead to visual loss if injured during endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Frontal sinus
Ethmoidal sinus
Sphenoid sinus
Maxillary sinus

questions.text: A 42-year-old man undergoing nasal endoscopy is found to have a round opening high on the anterior wall of a sinus cavity located approximately 7 cm from the anterior nasal spine and 1.5 cm above the choana. The cavity is asymmetrical, and its septum is obliquely placed. Which of the following sinuses is being visualized?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sphenoid sinus

 

 

Occupies the body of the sphenoid, ostium lies in the anterior wall, opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, and is found approximately 1.5 cm above choana and 7 cm from the anterior nasal spine.

This patient presents with:

 

  • A sinus opening seen high up on the anterior wall
  • Located 1.5 cm above the choana and ~7 cm from the anterior nasal spine
  • The cavity has a thin, often oblique septum and is rarely symmetrical

 

These features are classic for the sphenoid sinus, which:

 

  • Occupies the body of the sphenoid
  • Has an ostium that opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess
  • Lies medial to the superior or supreme turbinate
  • Often shows asymmetry and an obliquely placed or deficient septum
  • In adults, it may be 2 cm in height, width, and depth, with variable pneumatization

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal sinus: Lies above the supraorbital margin, drains via the frontal recess, and is not located posteriorly or above the choana.

 

Option B. Ethmoidal sinus: Lies between the nasal cavity and orbit, consists of multiple small air cells. Ostia open into middle or superior meatus, not in the location described.

 

Option D. Maxillary sinus: Lies in the body of the maxilla, opens into the middle meatus, and is situated inferior and lateral, not near the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenoid sinus lies in the body of the sphenoid bone and opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, about 1.5 cm above the choana and 7 cm from the anterior nasal spine.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Injury to the maxillary nerve in the lateral wall
Compression of the optic chiasma lying above the anterior roof
Damage to the Vidian nerve traversing the posterior wall
Breach of the clivus posterior to the sinus leading to CSF leak

questions.text: A 50-year-old male undergoes endoscopic transnasal surgery for a pituitary adenoma. During dissection of the sphenoid sinus roof, he develops transient visual disturbances. Which of the following best explains the complication based on anatomical relations of the sphenoid sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Compression of the optic chiasma lying above the anterior roof

 

Compression of the optic chiasma lying above the anterior roof –Correct. The optic chiasma lies directly above the anterior roof of the sphenoid sinus and can be affected during dissection in this region.

 

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Endoscopic skull base surgery via sphenoid sinus route
  • Complication of transient visual disturbances, which implies involvement of optic apparatus
  • The roof of the sphenoid sinus is anatomically divided into two parts:
    • Anterior roof: related to the olfactory tract, optic chiasma, and frontal lobe
    • Posterior roof: related to the pituitary gland and cavernous sinus
  • Thus, manipulation near the anterior roof of the sphenoid sinus during surgery can affect the optic chiasma, explaining the visual symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Injury to the maxillary nerve in the lateral wall: The maxillary nerve (V2) may be related to the inferolateral part of the sinus wall, but injury would cause facial numbness, not visual disturbances.

 

Option C. Damage to the Vidian nerve traversing the posterior wall: The Vidian nerve runs in the floor of the sphenoid sinus, and injury to it may cause lacrimation issues, not visual loss.

 

Option D. Breach of the clivus posterior to the sinus leading to CSF leak: The clivus forms the posterior wall, and although it may lead to a CSF leak if breached, it is not associated with optic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior roof of the sphenoid sinus is related to the optic chiasma, and injury here during surgery can lead to visual disturbances.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: It is thicker and more vascular than nasal mucosa
It is lined by non-ciliated squamous epithelium
Cilia are most concentrated near the sinus ostia to aid mucus drainage
It is discontinuous with the nasal mucosa and ends blindly

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient is diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. Histological examination of the mucosa reveals ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the mucous membrane lining the paranasal sinuses?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cilia are most concentrated near the sinus ostia to aid mucus drainage

 

Cilia density is highest near the ostia, helping propel mucus towards the nasal cavity.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Chronic sinusitis involving the paranasal sinuses
  • Mucosa showing ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells, characteristic of respiratory epithelium
  • The mucous membrane of sinuses is continuous with the nasal mucosa via their ostia, and the ciliary activity is highest near the ostia, facilitating mucus drainage into the nasal cavity

 

This functional arrangement is essential in mucociliary clearance, and impaired ciliary function near the ostia can lead to sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is thicker and more vascular than nasal mucosa: Incorrect. The mucosa of paranasal sinuses is thinner and less vascular than that of the nasal cavity.

 

Option B. It is lined by non-ciliated squamous epithelium: Incorrect. It is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells, not squamous.

 

Option D. It is discontinuous with the nasal mucosa and ends blindly: Incorrect. The sinus mucosa is continuous with nasal mucosa via the ostia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paranasal sinuses are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells, and cilia are most concentrated near the ostia to aid mucus drainage into the nasal cavity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Frontal and sphenoid sinuses are not present at birth
Ethmoid sinuses should already be radiologically visible
Maxillary sinuses do not develop until after 1 year
Frontal sinuses are the first to be visible on imaging

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant undergoes a skull X-ray for suspected sinus infection. The radiologist identifies air-filled cavities in the maxilla but not in the frontal or sphenoid bones. Which of the following is the most likely explanation based on normal sinus development?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal and sphenoid sinuses are not present at birth

 

These sinuses begin development later, with no radiological evidence in infancy.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Imaging done at 6 months of age
  • Maxillary sinuses visible, consistent with their presence at birth
  • Frontal and sphenoid sinuses not seen, which aligns with their absence at birth
  • According to the normal development of paranasal sinuses:
  • Maxillary and ethmoid sinuses are present at birth, but only maxillary can be seen radiologically by 4–5 months
  • Frontal sinuses develop later, invade the frontal bone by age 4 and are radiologically visible by 6 years
  • Sphenoid sinuses reach sella turcica by age 7 and become radiologically visible around 4 years

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethmoid sinuses should already be radiologically visible: Incorrect. Though ethmoids are present at birth, radiological visibility occurs at 1 year, not at 6 months.

 

Option C. Maxillary sinuses do not develop until after 1 year: Incorrect. Maxillary sinuses are present at birth, with radiologic evidence seen as early as 4–5 months.

 

Option D. Frontal sinuses are the first to be visible on imaging: Incorrect. Frontal sinuses appear radiologically by 6 years, much later than maxillary and ethmoid sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At birth, only maxillary and ethmoid sinuses are present, but only the maxillary sinus is radiologically visible by 4–5 months, while frontal and sphenoid sinuses are absent.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Maxillary sinus mucus can be effectively drained through an inferior meatal antrostomy
Sinus ventilation is similar to the lungs — air enters during inspiration and exits during expiration
Frontal sinus mucus undergoes partial recycling within the sinus before exiting via the natural ostium
Mucociliary clearance from anterior ethmoid sinuses moves towards the sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: A 28-year-old man complains of chronic nasal congestion and postnasal drip. Diagnostic nasal endoscopy reveals mucopus in the middle meatus. Which of the following statements about paranasal sinus physiology and drainage is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal sinus mucus undergoes partial recycling within the sinus before exiting via the natural ostium

 

This recirculation occurs just above the ostium and in the frontal recess, making frontal sinus drainage unique.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Postnasal drip and mucus in middle meatus, suggesting involvement of maxillary, frontal, or anterior ethmoid sinuses
  • Understanding mucociliary clearance and ventilation helps identify affected sinuses and choose appropriate surgical approaches

 

Frontal sinus has a unique mucociliary pathway where mucus travels along the interfrontal septum, lateral roof, floor, and exits through the natural ostium. Importantly, some mucus recirculates within the sinus at two points—just above the ostium and within the frontal recess.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maxillary sinus mucus can be effectively drained through an inferior meatal antrostomy: Incorrect. Although inferior meatal antrostomy (as in Caldwell–Luc) may provide ventilation, mucociliary clearance continues to occur via the natural ostium in the middle meatus.

 

Option B. Sinus ventilation is similar to the lungs — air enters during inspiration and exits during expiration: Incorrect. Sinus ventilation is paradoxical: air exits during inspiration due to negative pressure and enters during expiration, the opposite of lungs.

 

Option D. Mucociliary clearance from anterior ethmoid sinuses moves towards the sphenoethmoidal recess: Incorrect. Anterior ethmoid mucus joins that of frontal and maxillary sinuses and passes in front of torus tubarius into the nasopharynx. It is the posterior ethmoids that drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus mucociliary clearance involves partial recycling of mucus within the sinus before draining through the natural ostium.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Facilitating mucociliary drainage of the nasal cavity
Reducing airflow resistance during nasal breathing
Acting as buffers against trauma to protect the brain
Providing venous drainage from the orbit to the cavernous sinus

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with a depressed skull fracture after a road traffic accident. Despite the impact over the frontal region, there is no intracranial injury. Which of the following is a likely protective role played by the paranasal sinuses in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acting as buffers against trauma to protect the brain

 

Sinuses help absorb and distribute mechanical forces, reducing the chance of direct brain injury, especially in the anterior cranial fossa.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • A frontal impact without brain injury, suggesting a protective mechanism
  • The paranasal sinuses, especially frontal, ethmoid, and sphenoid, are believed to act as shock absorbers or buffers, dispersing the force of trauma and shielding vital intracranial structures

 

This is one of several proposed physiological functions of the sinuses, although their exact purpose remains uncertain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facilitating mucociliary drainage of the nasal cavity: Incorrect. This is a physiological process, but not a function of sinuses themselves—it relates to mucosa and ciliary action, not structural protection.

 

Option B. Reducing airflow resistance during nasal breathing: Incorrect. Sinuses are non-ventilated spaces during normal respiration and do not play a role in airflow resistance.

 

Option D. Providing venous drainage from the orbit to the cavernous sinus: Incorrect. This is a role of venous channels like the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins, not a function of the paranasal sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paranasal sinuses function as buffers against trauma, protecting the brain and surrounding structures from direct injury.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 190

choices.text: Frontal sinus is the most commonly affected in acute sinusitis
Pansinusitis refers only to bilateral involvement of maxillary sinuses
Closed type sinusitis is less symptomatic due to lack of drainage
Maxillary sinus is the most commonly involved sinus in acute sinusitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with facial pain, nasal congestion, and purulent nasal discharge. Imaging confirms acute sinusitis affecting multiple sinuses on one side. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding acute sinusitis and its variants?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maxillary sinus is the most commonly involved sinus in acute sinusitis

 

 This is the most frequently affected sinus in acute infections.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Typical signs of acute sinusitis
  • Imaging shows multiple sinuses involved on one side, which is classified as unilateral pansinusitis

 

Acute inflammation of the sinus mucosa is termed acute sinusitis, and among all paranasal sinuses, the maxillary sinus is most commonly affected, followed by ethmoid, frontal, and sphenoid sinuses.
Sinusitis can be classified as:

 

  • Multisinusitis – involvement of more than one sinus
  • Pansinusitis – involvement of all sinuses on one or both sides

 

Sinusitis may also be:

 

  • Open type – when sinus contents drain freely
  • Closed type – when the natural ostium is blocked; more symptomatic and complication-prone due to pressure buildup and retained secretions

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal sinus is the most commonly affected in acute sinusitis: Incorrect. The maxillary sinus is most commonly affected, not frontal.

 

Option B. Pansinusitis refers only to bilateral involvement of maxillary sinuses: Incorrect. Pansinusitis means all sinuses are involved, unilaterally or bilaterally, not just the maxillary.

 

Option C. Closed type sinusitis is less symptomatic due to lack of drainage: Incorrect. Closed sinusitis causes more severe symptoms and is more likely to lead to complications due to trapped secretions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maxillary sinus is the most commonly involved sinus in acute sinusitis, and closed sinusitis is more symptomatic and prone to complications.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 191

choices.text: Swimming in chlorinated pools is the most common predisposing cause
Dental infections act as a predisposing cause, not an exciting cause
Allergic rhinitis can obstruct sinus drainage and act as a local predisposing factor
Sinusitis due to trauma is always bilateral and affects all paranasal sinuses equally

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with symptoms of maxillary sinusitis following extraction of an upper molar tooth. He has a history of allergic rhinitis and nasal congestion. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the factors contributing to his sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Allergic rhinitis can obstruct sinus drainage and act as a local predisposing factor

 

Allergic rhinitis causes edema of sinus ostia, leading to stasis of secretions, predisposing to sinus infection.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Acute maxillary sinusitis following tooth extraction (exciting cause: dental infection)
  • History of allergic rhinitis, which can lead to edema of sinus ostia, resulting in poor ventilation and stasis (local predisposing factor)
  • Sinusitis has multiple causes:
  • Exciting causes include viral rhinitis, dental infections, trauma, and chemical/physical irritation (e.g., swimming, barotrauma)
  • Predisposing causes can be local (e.g., deviated septum, allergic rhinitis, nasal polyps) or general (e.g., poor health, immune suppression, cold weather)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Swimming in chlorinated pools is the most common predisposing cause: Incorrect. Swimming is an exciting cause, not predisposing, and not the most common—viral rhinitis is.

 

Option B. Dental infections act as a predisposing cause, not an exciting cause: Incorrect. Dental infections, especially involving upper molars and premolars, are direct exciting causes of maxillary sinusitis.

 

Option D. Sinusitis due to trauma is always bilateral and affects all paranasal sinuses equally: Incorrect. Trauma usually causes localized sinusitis and may affect frontal, maxillary, or ethmoid sinuses depending on the site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic rhinitis can cause edema of sinus ostia, leading to obstruction and acting as a local predisposing factor for sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 191

choices.text: Sinus mucosa initially produces purulent discharge that later becomes serous
Suppurative sinusitis is usually self-limited and never affects bony structures
Serous exudation is the first step, followed by mucopurulent or purulent transformation
Dental infections usually result in non-suppurative sinusitis due to poor virulence

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with severe unilateral facial pain, purulent nasal discharge, and fever 3 days after upper molar extraction. CT shows opacification and bony wall erosion of the maxillary sinus. Which of the following best describes the likely pathological progression in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serous exudation is the first step, followed by mucopurulent or purulent transformation

 

This is the normal progression of inflammation in acute sinusitis, especially when ostial drainage is impaired.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Acute maxillary sinusitis after tooth extraction, a classic fulminant dental source
  • Clinical and radiologic signs of suppurative sinusitis with destruction of bony walls, indicating advanced infection
  • Pathologically, acute sinusitis begins as serous inflammation, then progresses to mucopurulent and eventually purulent depending on the host immune status, drainage through the ostium, and virulence of organisms.
  • If drainage is blocked, it leads to empyema and potentially erosion of sinus walls
  • Dental infections, in particular, tend to be highly virulent and often rapidly progress to suppuration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sinus mucosa initially produces purulent discharge that later becomes serous: Incorrect. The exudate starts as serous and becomes purulent if infection progresses, not the reverse.

 

Option B. Suppurative sinusitis is usually self-limited and never affects bony structures: Incorrect. Severe suppurative infections can cause empyema and destruction of bony walls, especially when drainage is blocked.

 

Option D. Dental infections usually result in non-suppurative sinusitis due to poor virulence: Incorrect. Dental infections are often fulminant and rapidly result in suppurative sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute sinusitis begins with serous exudation that may become mucopurulent or purulent, especially in fulminant cases like dental infections.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 191

choices.text: Pain aggravated by stooping, chewing, or coughing
Bilateral postauricular lymphadenopathy and otalgia
Nasal discharge seen in the superior meatus
Pain localized exclusively to the frontal region

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with facial pain, fever, and purulent nasal discharge. He recently had a dental extraction of the upper molar. Examination reveals tenderness over the upper jaw and pus in the middle meatus. Which of the following features best supports the diagnosis of acute maxillary sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain aggravated by stooping, chewing, or coughing

 

These actions increase sinus pressure, worsening pain in acute maxillary sinusitis.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Fever, facial pain, and nasal discharge following dental extraction
  • Tenderness over the maxilla, pus in the middle meatus, and pain aggravated by stooping or chewing

 

These are classic signs of acute maxillary sinusitis, the most commonly affected sinus in sinus infections.

 

  • Dental infections, especially of premolars and molars, are common causes due to their proximity to the sinus floor
  • Pain may refer to gums, teeth, or even supraorbital area, leading to misdiagnosis as frontal sinusitis
  • Postural changes and tapping over the cheek (anterior wall) may exacerbate pain

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bilateral postauricular lymphadenopathy and otalgia: Incorrect. These are features suggestive of otitis media or mastoiditis, not maxillary sinusitis.

 

Option C. Nasal discharge seen in the superior meatus: Incorrect. Maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus, not the superior meatus. Discharge here points to posterior ethmoid or sphenoid involvement.

 

Option D. Pain localized exclusively to the frontal region: Incorrect. Frontal pain alone without jaw tenderness is more typical of frontal sinusitis. Maxillary pain can radiate to supraorbital area, but the primary site remains the upper jaw/cheek.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pain aggravated by stooping, chewing, or coughing, with tenderness over the upper jaw, suggests acute maxillary sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 192

choices.text: Start oral amoxicillin and advise antral lavage immediately
Start erythromycin, give nasal decongestants, and advise steam inhalation
Begin IV cefuroxime and refer for surgical debridement
Prescribe only analgesics and monitor without antibiotics

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with facial pain, purulent nasal discharge, and tenderness over the right maxilla. Waters’ view shows fluid level in the right maxillary sinus. She is allergic to penicillin. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment strategy for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start erythromycin, give nasal decongestants, and advise steam inhalation

 

This approach aligns with recommended medical management, especially in penicillin-allergic patients.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Classic features of acute maxillary sinusitis
  • Confirmed sinus involvement on Waters' view X-ray
  • History of penicillin allergy, which excludes drugs like amoxicillin
  • Management of acute maxillary sinusitis is primarily medical, and includes:
  • Antibiotics: In penicillin-allergic patients, erythromycin, doxycycline, or cotrimoxazole are effective alternatives
  • Nasal decongestants: Like oxymetazoline or xylometazoline, help reduce ostial edema and promote drainage
  • Steam inhalation: Should be given 15–20 minutes after decongestants for better mucosal penetration
  • Analgesics and hot fomentation: Provide symptomatic relief
  • Antral lavage is rarely needed and reserved for cases not responding to medical therapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start oral amoxicillin and advise antral lavage immediately: Incorrect. Amoxicillin is contraindicated in penicillin-allergic patients, and antral lavage is not first-line unless medical therapy fails.

 

Option C. Begin IV cefuroxime and refer for surgical debridement: Incorrect. IV antibiotics and surgery are not required for uncomplicated acute sinusitis; cefuroxime may be considered only in β-lactamase resistance or complications.

 

Option D. Prescribe only analgesics and monitor without antibiotics: Incorrect. Symptomatic therapy alone is insufficient in bacterial sinusitis, especially with purulent discharge and radiological evidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute maxillary sinusitis is managed medically with antibiotics (e.g., erythromycin in penicillin allergy), nasal decongestants, steam inhalation, analgesics, and lavage only if conservative treatment fails.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 192

choices.text: Acute maxillary sinusitis
Acute frontal sinusitis
Migraine headache
Cluster headache

questions.text: A 35-year-old office worker complains of severe frontal headache that worsens by midday and subsides later in the evening. On examination, tenderness is noted above the medial canthus, and there is mild eyelid edema with conjunctival congestion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute frontal sinusitis

 

The hallmark features are periodic frontal headache, tenderness over the medial supraorbital area, eyelid edema, and nasal mucopurulent discharge high in the middle meatus.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Frontal headache with characteristic periodicity ("office headache") – begins on waking, peaks by midday, and subsides afterward
  • Tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus, correlating with the floor of the frontal sinus
  • Oedema of upper eyelid, conjunctival suffusion, and possible photophobia.

 

 

  • These are classic clinical features of acute frontal sinusitis

 

Etiology includes viral URTI followed by bacterial infection, entry of water during swimming, or trauma. It may also be secondary to ipsilateral ethmoid or maxillary sinusitis, due to obstruction of the frontal recess.

 

Nasal endoscopy may show vertical streak of mucopus in the anterior part of the middle meatus, and CT scan is the investigation of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute maxillary sinusitis: Incorrect. While it can present with headache, pain is localized to the maxilla, often radiating to upper teeth or gums, and worsens on stooping or chewing, not typically with periodicity.

 

Option C. Migraine headache: Incorrect. While migraine can present with photophobia and headache, it is usually pulsatile, often unilateral, may involve aura, and lacks nasal or sinus findings.

 

Option D. Cluster headache: Incorrect. Typically involves severe unilateral periorbital pain, lacrimation, and rhinorrhea, but does not show tenderness over sinus regions or mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute frontal sinusitis presents with periodic frontal headache, tenderness above the medial canthus, and mucopurulent discharge high in the middle meatus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 192

choices.text: Continue oral antibiotics for another 7 days
Begin high-dose antihistamines and corticosteroids
Perform external drainage via frontal sinus trephination
Refer for optic nerve decompression surgery

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with acute frontal sinusitis presents with worsening headache, fever, and increasing eyelid swelling despite 3 days of antibiotics and nasal decongestants. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform external drainage via frontal sinus trephination

 

 

Surgical intervention is indicated if pain and swelling worsen despite 48 hours of treatment, or complications are imminent.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Acute frontal sinusitis that is not responding to medical management after 48 hours
  • Presence of increasing lid edema, raising concern for orbital cellulitis, which is a complication of frontal sinusitis
  • Medical management includes:
  • Antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin/clavulanic acid or erythromycin in allergies)
  • Nasal decongestants (e.g., oxymetazoline, pseudoephedrine)
  • Steam inhalation, antihistamines, and analgesics
  • Local vasoconstrictor-soaked pledgets in the middle meatus

 

If there is no clinical improvement within 48 hours, or there is progressive swelling suggesting complications, surgical drainage is warranted. This is done by trephination of the frontal sinus through a small incision below the eyebrow, insertion of a tube for irrigation, and checking patency of the frontonasal duct with methylene blue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue oral antibiotics for another 7 days: Incorrect. Continuation without response risks complications like orbital cellulitis or intracranial spread.

 

Option B. Begin high-dose antihistamines and corticosteroids: Incorrect. These may relieve congestion but are not definitive when there's signs of worsening infection.

 

Option D. Refer for optic nerve decompression surgery: Incorrect. There is no indication of optic neuropathy or visual loss in this case. The primary issue is drainage of infected sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus trephination is indicated when acute frontal sinusitis does not respond to medical treatment within 48 hours or shows signs of complications like orbital cellulitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 192

choices.text: Perform frontal sinus trephination through a superomedial incision
Continue conservative therapy with nasal decongestants and antihistamines
Start intravenous corticosteroids to reduce mucosal edema
Refer for FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery) immediately

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient with acute frontal sinusitis presents with persistent pain and high-grade fever after 48 hours of medical therapy. He also develops progressive upper eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform frontal sinus trephination through a superomedial incision

 

Indicated for non-resolving or worsening frontal sinusitis after 48 hours, especially with signs of complications.

 

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Failure of medical therapy after 48 hours
  • Persistent frontal pain, pyrexia, and progressive eyelid swelling

 

These signs indicate impending orbital cellulitis, a known complication of frontal sinusitis, necessitating urgent drainage of the infected sinus.

Frontal sinus trephination is a traditional and effective surgical method used in such cases:

 

  • A 2 cm horizontal incision is made in the superomedial orbital region below the eyebrow
  • A hole is drilled in the floor of the frontal sinus
  • Pus is drained and sent for culture
  • A plastic drainage tube is inserted and sinus is irrigated regularly
  • Patency of the frontonasal duct is confirmed using methylene blue in the irrigating fluid
  • The tube is removed once the duct is confirmed patent

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continue conservative therapy with nasal decongestants and antihistamines: Incorrect. These are supportive, but in this case, surgical drainage is mandatory to avoid orbital or intracranial spread.

 

Option C. Start intravenous corticosteroids to reduce mucosal edema: Incorrect. Steroids may reduce inflammation but are contraindicated in active infection with worsening signs.

 

Option D. Refer for FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery) immediately: Incorrect. While FESS is used for chronic or refractory cases, external drainage via trephination is preferred in acute complicated frontal sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus trephination is indicated when acute frontal sinusitis worsens or fails to improve within 48 hours of medical treatment, especially with signs of orbital complications.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 192

choices.text: Acute maxillary sinusitis
Acute ethmoid sinusitis
Acute frontal sinusitis
Acute dacryocystitis

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, pain over the nasal bridge, swollen eyelids, increased tearing, and restricted eye movement. On anterior rhinoscopy, mucopurulent discharge is noted in the middle meatus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute ethmoid sinusitis

 

   

 

Pain over bridge of nose, periorbital swelling, discharge in middle/superior meatus, and early orbital complications are classic signs.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose, deep medial to the orbit, which is aggravated by eye movements
  • Puffy eyelids, excessive lacrimation, and discharge in the middle meatus
  • The age (6 years) and the involvement of the ethmoid sinuses, which are commonly affected in children, strongly point to acute ethmoid sinusitis

 

Ethmoid sinuses, located between the orbit and nasal cavity, are highly susceptible in infants and young children. Due to the thin lamina papyracea, infection can quickly spread to the orbit, leading to orbital cellulitis or abscess.

 

  • Anterior ethmoid involvement → discharge in middle meatus
  • Posterior ethmoid involvement → discharge in superior meatus

 

Visual symptoms and exophthalmos in complicated cases may necessitate external ethmoidectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute maxillary sinusitis: Incorrect. Pain is typically over the upper jaw or cheek, and there’s no direct early orbital involvement or worsening with eye movements.

 

 

Option C. Acute frontal sinusitis: Incorrect. Presents with frontal headache, tenderness above the medial canthus, and does not usually involve orbital swelling early.

 

 

Option D. Acute dacryocystitis: Incorrect. Involves swelling below the medial canthus, often with purulent discharge from the punctum, not associated with sinus findings or meatal discharge.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute ethmoid sinusitis in children presents with pain near the medial orbit, eyelid edema, and nasal discharge, with early risk of orbital complications.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 192

choices.text: Acute frontal sinusitis
Acute sphenoid sinusitis
Acute maxillary sinusitis
Posterior ethmoid mucocele

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with persistent occipital headache and postnasal drip for several days. Posterior rhinoscopy shows a streak of pus on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx. CT scan reveals fluid level in the sphenoid sinus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute sphenoid sinusitis

 

 

Characterized by occipital/vertex headache, postnasal drip, and pus visible on posterior rhinoscopy. Confirmed by fluid level on CT.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Headache localized to the occiput, which is a hallmark of sphenoid sinusitis
  • Postnasal discharge seen on posterior rhinoscopy as a streak of pus over the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx
  • CT scan showing fluid level in the sphenoid sinus, which confirms the diagnosis

 

Isolated sphenoid sinusitis is rare and often occurs with posterior ethmoiditis or pansinusitis. Due to its deep location, symptoms may be vague and commonly mistaken for other pathologies.

Lateral X-ray views (in supine or prone position) and CT scan are useful for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute frontal sinusitis: Incorrect. Presents with frontal headache, not occipital or vertex pain, and discharge is seen high in the middle meatus, not on posterior nasopharyngeal wall.

 

Option C. Acute maxillary sinusitis: Incorrect. Causes facial or upper jaw pain, discharge in the middle meatus, and does not present with occipital headache.

 

Option D. Posterior ethmoid mucocele: Incorrect. Though mucocele may mimic sinusitis, this case has acute symptoms and fluid level, suggesting active infection, not a cystic lesion like mucocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occipital headache with postnasal discharge seen on posterior rhinoscopy and CT evidence of fluid level suggests acute sphenoid sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 194

choices.text: Excessive mucus secretion due to overactive cilia
Chronic infection leads to mucosal atrophy and desquamation
Regeneration of squamous epithelium enhances mucociliary clearance
Sinusitis persists due to hypovascular submucosa and absence of inflammatory cells

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, thick postnasal discharge, and anosmia for the past several months. He has a history of recurrent acute sinus infections. Nasal endoscopy reveals polypoidal mucosa. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic infection leads to mucosal atrophy and desquamation

 

Chronic sinusitis is marked by atrophic or hypertrophic changes, epithelial damage, and persistent inflammation.

 

This patient presents with:

  • Persistent nasal obstruction, postnasal drip, and loss of smell, all classic signs of chronic sinusitis
  • History of recurrent acute sinusitis, suggesting unresolved acute infection progressing to chronic inflammation
  • Nasal endoscopy shows thickened, polypoidal mucosa, a hallmark of hypertrophic chronic sinusitis

Pathophysiology & Pathology Recap:

  • Chronic sinusitis often begins when an acute infection fails to resolve, leading to epithelial destruction, impaired mucociliary clearance, and stagnation of secretions
  • Long-term infection results in mucosal changes:
    • Loss of cilia
    • Oedema and polyp formation
    • Surface epithelium shows desquamation, regeneration, or metaplasia
    • Submucosa infiltrated with lymphocytes, plasma cells, fibrosis, and microabscesses

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive mucus secretion due to overactive cilia: Incorrect. Chronic sinusitis involves loss of cilia, not overactivity.

 

Option C. Regeneration of squamous epithelium enhances mucociliary clearance: Incorrect. Squamous metaplasia impairs clearance, as ciliated columnar epithelium is needed for mucociliary function.

 

Option D. Sinusitis persists due to hypovascular submucosa and absence of inflammatory cells: Incorrect. Chronic sinusitis involves inflammatory infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, and granulation tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic sinusitis results from unresolved acute infection, leading to epithelial desquamation, mucosal atrophy or hypertrophy, and persistent inflammation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 195

choices.text: Acute pain and tenderness over sinuses are always present in chronic sinusitis
Culture and sensitivity testing of discharge is not helpful in chronic cases
Endoscopic sinus surgery provides effective drainage and avoids external incisions
Plain X-ray is more accurate than CT in diagnosing ethmoid sinus involvement

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with long-standing nasal stuffiness, intermittent purulent nasal discharge, and reduced sense of smell. Examination reveals thick mucopurulent discharge. CT PNS shows mucosal thickening in the ethmoid sinuses. Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endoscopic sinus surgery provides effective drainage and avoids external incisions

 

ESS has become the treatment of choice for refractory chronic sinusitis and avoids disfiguring external approaches.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Chronic symptoms: nasal stuffiness, purulent discharge, and anosmia
  • Imaging shows ethmoidal sinus mucosal thickening, suggestive of chronic sinusitis
  • Key diagnostic and treatment points from the content:
  • Symptoms in chronic sinusitis are less severe than acute, often with vague pain, and purulent, sometimes foul-smelling discharge
  • CT scan is preferred, especially for ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses
  • Initial treatment is conservative with antibiotics, decongestants, antihistamines, and irrigations
  • If ineffective, endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS) is preferred as it restores ventilation and drainage while avoiding external scars

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute pain and tenderness over sinuses are always present in chronic sinusitis: Incorrect. Pain is often mild or absent in chronic cases unless there’s an acute exacerbation.

 

Option B. Culture and sensitivity testing of discharge is not helpful in chronic cases: Incorrect. Microbiological testing helps guide appropriate antibiotic therapy, especially for anaerobic or resistant infections.

 

Option D. Plain X-ray is more accurate than CT in diagnosing ethmoid sinus involvement: Incorrect. CT is superior, especially for visualizing ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses, and has replaced older contrast-based studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic sinus surgery is preferred for chronic sinusitis when conservative treatment fails, as it ensures good drainage while avoiding external incisions.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Antral puncture and irrigation via middle meatus
Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) targeting the frontal recess
Intranasal antrostomy via the middle turbinate
Caldwell–Luc operation with sublabial access and inferior meatal window

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic maxillary sinusitis has failed to improve with repeated sinus irrigations. CT scan shows persistent mucosal thickening and debris in the maxillary sinus. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate to ensure removal of irreversible disease and establish drainage into the inferior meatus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caldwell–Luc operation with sublabial access and inferior meatal window

 

 

This procedure allows surgical entry into the maxillary sinus, clearance of irreversible pathology, and creation of a drainage window into the inferior meatus.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Chronic maxillary sinusitis not resolving with conservative treatment
  • Failure of antral irrigation, indicating the need for definitive surgical intervention
  • Imaging suggests irreversible disease, requiring complete clearance of diseased mucosa

 

In such cases, the Caldwell–Luc operation is the surgery of choice:

 

  • Access is via a sublabial incision
  • Entry is made through the anterior wall of the maxillary sinus
  • All irreversible disease is cleared
  • A permanent window is created into the inferior meatus for ventilation and drainage

 

Other surgical options like antral puncture and intranasal antrostomy are less definitive and used in earlier or milder cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antral puncture and irrigation via middle meatus: Incorrect. Irrigation is done via the inferior meatus, not middle. Also, this is reserved for initial treatment, not for irreversible disease.

 

Option B. Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) targeting the frontal recess: Incorrect. FESS is effective for chronic sinusitis, especially ethmoid/frontal disease. It does not specifically address irreversible maxillary disease via inferior meatal route.

 

Option C. Intranasal antrostomy via the middle turbinate: Incorrect. Intranasal antrostomy is performed via the inferior meatus, not middle turbinate, and is used if irrigation fails, but not when full clearance is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caldwell–Luc operation is indicated in chronic maxillary sinusitis with irreversible disease, providing access via the anterior wall and drainage through the inferior meatus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Antral puncture through inferior meatus
External frontoethmoidectomy (Howarth’s or Lynch operation)
Osteoplastic flap operation with sinus obliteration using muscle
Caldwell–Luc operation via anterior wall of maxilla

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with chronic frontal sinusitis has failed to improve despite correction of nasal septal deviation and previous ethmoidectomy. CT scan shows extensive mucosal thickening and obliteration of the frontonasal duct. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate to create a new drainage pathway and clear diseased ethmoid cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External frontoethmoidectomy (Howarth’s or Lynch operation)

 

 

Provides direct access to frontal sinus, removes diseased mucosa, exenterates ethmoid cells, and reconstructs drainage pathway.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Refractory chronic frontal sinusitis
  • Failed conservative and intranasal procedures, including ethmoidectomy
  • Imaging shows blocked frontonasal duct and persistent disease

 

In such cases, external frontoethmoidectomy (Howarth’s or Lynch operation) is indicated:

 

  • A curvilinear incision is made around the inner orbital margin
  • The floor of the frontal sinus is opened
  • Diseased mucosa and ethmoid cells are removed
  • A new frontonasal duct is surgically created for effective drainage

 

It is ideal for patients with severe frontal and ethmoidal sinus disease not responsive to FESS or simpler drainage procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antral puncture through inferior meatus: Incorrect. This is used for maxillary sinus irrigation, not for treating frontal sinusitis.

 

 

Option C. Osteoplastic flap operation with sinus obliteration using muscle: Incorrect. Though effective, it is more radical, used when all else fails or if obliteration is intended. In this case, drainage can still be re-established.

 

Option D. Caldwell–Luc operation via anterior wall of maxilla: Incorrect. This procedure is used for chronic maxillary sinusitis, not frontal sinus disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

External frontoethmoidectomy is used for chronic frontal sinusitis unresponsive to conservative treatment, allowing removal of diseased ethmoid cells and creation of a new frontonasal duct.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Caldwell–Luc operation
Antral puncture and irrigation
Intranasal ethmoidectomy
Endonasal DCR (dacryocystorhinostomy)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with chronic nasal obstruction and anosmia is diagnosed with chronic ethmoid sinusitis associated with nasal polyps. Imaging shows extensive ethmoid air cell opacification. Which of the following surgical procedures is most appropriate for clearing ethmoid cells and potentially addressing associated frontal and sphenoid sinus disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intranasal ethmoidectomy

 

It is ideal for chronic ethmoiditis with polyp formation and can also facilitate frontal and sphenoid sinus drainage.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Chronic ethmoid sinusitis with nasal polyps, causing nasal obstruction and anosmia
  • Imaging confirms ethmoid air cell involvement

 

Intranasal ethmoidectomy is the preferred surgical procedure in such cases:

 

  • Involves removal of ethmoid air cells and polypoidal tissue
  • Accessed via the intranasal route, specifically between the middle turbinate and medial orbital wall
  • Can also be extended to drain the frontal and sphenoid sinuses, especially when disease is contiguous

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell–Luc operation: Incorrect. This is used for chronic maxillary sinusitis via sublabial approach, not for ethmoid disease.

 

 

Option B. Antral puncture and irrigation: Incorrect. This is a conservative procedure for maxillary sinus and does not address ethmoid or polypoid disease.

 

 

Option D. Endonasal DCR (dacryocystorhinostomy): Incorrect. This is an ophthalmic procedure for nasolacrimal duct obstruction, unrelated to sinus surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intranasal ethmoidectomy is the treatment of choice for chronic ethmoiditis with polyps and allows access to frontal and sphenoid sinuses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Caldwell–Luc operation
Transoral sphenoidotomy
External ethmoidectomy with removal of anterior sphenoid wall
Antral puncture via inferior meatus

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with chronic headache and postnasal drip is diagnosed with chronic sphenoid sinusitis. Imaging shows persistent opacification of the sphenoid sinus along with ethmoid sinus involvement. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical procedure to access and drain the sphenoid sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. External ethmoidectomy with removal of anterior sphenoid wall

 

Provides access to the sphenoid sinus, especially when ethmoid disease is also present.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Chronic sphenoid sinusitis with associated ethmoid disease, which is a common combination
  • CT shows persistent sphenoid opacification, suggesting failure of medical therapy
  • Definitive management requires surgical drainage of the sphenoid sinus

 

The best approach is sphenoidotomy, which involves:

 

  • Removal of the anterior wall of the sphenoid sinus
  • Most commonly performed through an external ethmoidectomy, as ethmoid disease often coexists
  • Alternatively, a trans-septal approach can be used, but external ethmoidectomy is preferred in the setting of combined disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell–Luc operation: Incorrect. This is indicated for maxillary sinusitis, not sphenoid sinus disease.

 

 

Option B. Transoral sphenoidotomy: Incorrect. Not a standard or safe approach; access to the sphenoid is best obtained nasally or via ethmoidectomy.

 

Option D. Antral puncture via inferior meatus: Incorrect. Used for maxillary sinus irrigation, not for sphenoid sinus access or treatment.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenoidotomy via external ethmoidectomy is the preferred surgical approach for chronic sphenoiditis, especially when coexisting with ethmoid sinus disease.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Invasive fungal sinusitis; start intravenous amphotericin B immediately
Fungal ball; surgical removal and drainage of sinus without antifungal therapy
Allergic fungal sinusitis; treat with corticosteroids and antifungals
Mucormycosis; perform emergency debridement and antifungal therapy

questions.text: A 45-year-old immunocompetent patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and facial heaviness. CT scan reveals a hyperdense lesion in the maxillary sinus without bone erosion. Histopathology confirms fungal elements. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fungal ball; surgical removal and drainage of sinus without antifungal therapy

 

FB = fungal ball 

 

This describes a fungal ball, a non-invasive form seen on CT as a hyperdense lesion in an otherwise healthy sinus.

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Unilateral sinus symptoms in an immunocompetent host
  • Hyperdense lesion on CT without bone erosion or sinus expansion
  • Most commonly involves the maxillary sinus, followed by sphenoid, ethmoid, and frontal

 

This is characteristic of a fungal ball, also known as mycetoma, caused by fungi such as Aspergillus.

 

  • There is no tissue invasion, hence it is a non-invasive fungal sinusitis
  • Treatment is surgical: removal of the fungal ball and adequate sinus drainage
  • No antifungal medications are needed if the patient is immunocompetent and infection is non-invasive

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive fungal sinusitis; start intravenous amphotericin B immediately: Incorrect. Invasive disease presents with bone erosion, necrosis, and typically occurs in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option C. Allergic fungal sinusitis; treat with corticosteroids and antifungals: Incorrect. Allergic fungal sinusitis shows allergic mucin, nasal polyps, and often multiple sinus involvement.

 

Option D. Mucormycosis; perform emergency debridement and antifungal therapy: Incorrect. Mucormycosis is a life-threatening invasive infection, typically seen in diabetics or immunosuppressed patients, with bone and tissue destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fungal ball is a non-invasive fungal sinusitis, commonly affecting the maxillary sinus, treated by surgical removal and sinus drainage without the need for antifungal therapy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Invasive fungal sinusitis
Allergic fungal sinusitis
Fungal ball
Mucormycosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction, nasal polyps, and thick tenacious nasal discharge. CT scan reveals multiple sinus opacifications with areas of mucosal thickening and central hyperdensities. Histopathology shows eosinophilic mucin containing Charcot-Leyden crystals and fungal hyphae, but no tissue invasion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allergic fungal sinusitis

 

This condition is a non-invasive, immune-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to fungal antigens. It presents with sinonasal polyposis, mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, and hyperdensities on CT due to allergic mucin. It affects multiple sinuses, often on both sides, and may cause bony remodeling or expansion but without actual tissue invasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive fungal sinusitis: Incorrect. This is a rapidly progressive and life-threatening condition seen in immunocompromised individuals. It shows mucosal invasion, often with tissue necrosis and bone destruction. In the given case, there's no invasion.

 

 

 

Option C. Fungal ball: Incorrect. A fungal ball (mycetoma) involves single sinus, usually maxillary, with dense fungal concretions seen on CT, but no allergic mucin or polyposis. There's no Charcot-Leyden crystals or eosinophilic predominance.

 

 

Option D. Mucormycosis: Incorrect. Like invasive fungal sinusitis, it is an invasive fungal infection, often with tissue infarction, necrosis, and seen in diabetics or immunosuppressed. This scenario does not match.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic fungal sinusitis presents with nasal polyps, eosinophilic mucin containing Charcot-Leyden crystals and fungal hyphae, affects multiple sinuses, and requires surgical clearance plus systemic steroids.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Endoscopic clearance with topical steroids
Oral itraconazole alone for 6 weeks
Surgical debridement followed by amphotericin B and oral itraconazole
Observation with serial CT follow-up

questions.text: A 45-year-old immunocompetent patient presents with chronic nasal obstruction and facial fullness. CT scan shows opacified sinuses with mucosal thickening and bony erosion. Histopathology reveals fungal invasion of the submucosa along with granulomatous inflammation and multinucleated giant cells. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical debridement followed by amphotericin B and oral itraconazole

 

Chronic invasive fungal sinusitis requires surgical removal of affected mucosa, bone, and soft tissue. This is followed by intravenous amphotericin B (2–3 g total) and oral itraconazole for at least 12 months, with monitoring via serial CT or MRI scans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic clearance with topical steroids: Incorrect. This approach is appropriate for allergic fungal sinusitis, not invasive types. Topical therapy is insufficient for cases with tissue invasion and bone erosion.

 

Option B. Oral itraconazole alone for 6 weeks: Incorrect. Oral antifungals alone are inadequate for chronic invasive fungal sinusitis, especially with bone erosion and potential intracranial/intraorbital spread. Also, duration of therapy must be prolonged and combined with surgery.

 

Option D. Observation with serial CT follow-up: Incorrect. This would be dangerous in invasive fungal infections which require aggressive management to prevent orbital or intracranial spread.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic invasive fungal sinusitis presents with mucosal invasion and bony erosion, requiring surgical debridement followed by IV amphotericin B and long-term itraconazole therapy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Allergic fungal sinusitis; oral corticosteroids
Acute invasive Aspergillus sinusitis; fluconazole therapy
Mucormycosis (rhinocerebral); surgical debridement with IV amphotericin B
Chronic fungal sinusitis; endoscopic clearance without antifungals

questions.text: A 58-year-old diabetic patient presents with rapidly progressive facial pain, nasal congestion, and proptosis. Examination shows a black eschar over the palate and inferior turbinate. CT shows sinus opacification with bone erosion and intracranial extension. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mucormycosis (rhinocerebral); surgical debridement with IV amphotericin B

Fulminant fungal sinusitis with black eschar in an immunocompromised or diabetic patient is classical for Mucor. Management is urgent surgical debridement plus IV amphotericin B.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic fungal sinusitis; oral corticosteroids: Incorrect. Allergic fungal sinusitis is non-invasive, typically seen in immunocompetent individuals, and presents with nasal polyposis and allergic mucin. There is no tissue necrosis or black eschar.

 

 

Option B. Acute invasive Aspergillus sinusitis; fluconazole therapy: Incorrect. Aspergillus can cause fulminant invasive sinusitis, but fluconazole is ineffective. Also, Aspergillus does not form black eschar—that’s characteristic of Mucor.

 

Option D. Chronic fungal sinusitis; endoscopic clearance without antifungals: Incorrect. This option applies to fungal ball, which is non-invasive and chronic, not fulminant. Fulminant cases need urgent, aggressive treatment.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fulminant fungal sinusitis caused by Mucor in diabetics presents with black eschar and requires prompt surgical debridement and IV amphotericin B.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Frontal sinus osteoma; surgical excision via bicoronal flap
Frontal sinus mucocele; frontoethmoidectomy with drainage
Ethmoidal polyp; endoscopic polypectomy
Maxillary mucous retention cyst; no treatment required

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a painless, slowly progressive swelling in the superomedial quadrant of the right orbit with forward and lateral displacement of the eyeball. Imaging reveals opacification of the frontal sinus with expansion and thinning of bony walls. What is the most likely diagnosis and best treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frontal sinus mucocele; frontoethmoidectomy with drainage

 

Frontal mucoceles commonly present in the superomedial orbital quadrant, causing proptosis and displacement of the globe. Imaging shows sinus expansion and bone thinning. Frontoethmoidectomy is the standard treatment to establish drainage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal sinus osteoma; surgical 

 

excision via bicoronal flap: Incorrect. Osteoma is a slow-growing bony lesion, often asymptomatic unless large. It does not present with cystic swelling, egg-shell crackling, or displacement of the eyeball.

 

 

Option C. Ethmoidal polyp; endoscopic polypectomy: Incorrect. Nasal polyps may cause nasal obstruction but do not lead to orbital displacement or frontal sinus opacification. Also, they arise from the middle meatus, not the frontal sinus.

 

 

Option D. Maxillary mucous retention cyst; no treatment required: Incorrect in this context. While asymptomatic mucous retention cysts are common and usually don’t require treatment, they do not cause eye symptoms or frontal sinus changes. The case described does not fit this diagnosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus mucocele presents with painless orbital swelling and proptosis, and is treated by frontoethmoidectomy to ensure free drainage.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 196

choices.text: Caldwell-Luc operation
Maxillectomy with reconstruction
High-dose antibiotics and drainage of abscess
Endoscopic sinus surgery only

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with swelling of the cheek, erythema, purulent nasal discharge, and low-grade fever. Examination reveals a tender infraorbital swelling and a sinus tract discharging pus. A diagnosis of osteomyelitis of the maxilla is made. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High-dose antibiotics and drainage of abscess

 

As per the text, the first line of treatment for osteomyelitis of the maxilla includes large doses of antibiotics, drainage of any abscess, and removal of sequestra if present. This conservative yet effective management is crucial in children to avoid complications like maldevelopment of the maxilla or tooth bud damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell-Luc operation: Incorrect. This is a procedure done in chronic maxillary sinusitis cases that are unresponsive to conservative therapy. It’s not the first step in osteomyelitis, especially in children, where bone is still developing.

 

 

Option B. Maxillectomy with reconstruction: Incorrect. This is an aggressive surgical option reserved for malignancies or extensive necrosis. It is not appropriate in a routine osteomyelitis case.

 

Option D. Endoscopic sinus surgery only: Incorrect. While ESS is useful in chronic sinusitis or for drainage of sinuses, it does not directly address osteomyelitis or subperiosteal abscess involving bone destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is treated with high-dose antibiotics, drainage of abscesses, and removal of sequestra if necessary.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 200

choices.text: Inflammatory oedema of the eyelids
Orbital cellulitis
Subperiosteal abscess
Orbital apex syndrome

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with swelling of both upper and lower eyelids, fever, proptosis, chemosis, and restricted eye movements. Vision in the affected eye is reduced. CT scan shows inflammation extending into the orbit from the ethmoid sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis

 

This is the most likely diagnosis here. It results from extension of ethmoidal infection through the lamina papyracea into the post-septal orbit. Clinical features include:

 

  • Lid edema with erythema
  • Proptosis
  • Chemosis
  • Restricted extraocular movements
  • Vision impairment
  • Systemic signs like fever
  • Risk of meningitis and cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory oedema of the eyelids: Incorrect. This is a reactionary preseptal swelling, without redness, tenderness, proptosis, or vision changes. The key differentiator is normal eyeball movements and vision, unlike in this case where there’s restricted movements and vision loss.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal abscess: Incorrect. In this, pus collects under the periosteum, and while it displaces the eyeball, eye movement and vision are usually not severely impaired unless it progresses. Also, the location of displacement depends on the sinus of origin, but the systemic signs are generally less severe compared to orbital cellulitis.

 

Option D. Orbital apex syndrome: Incorrect. This involves cranial nerves III, IV, VI, V1, and the optic nerve, presenting with vision loss and ophthalmoplegia, but is more common with sphenoid sinus infection. The clinical setting here favors orbital cellulitis due to ethmoid sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis presents with lid edema, proptosis, chemosis, restricted eye movements, and vision loss due to spread of ethmoid sinus infection into the orbit.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 200

choices.text: Meningitis
Subdural abscess
Brain abscess
Cerebellar infarction

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with a history of untreated chronic frontal sinusitis presents with high-grade fever, altered sensorium, and neck rigidity. MRI reveals inflammation of the meninges and pus collection in the subdural space. Which of the following intracranial complications is least likely to result from sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebellar infarction

 

Least likely. This is not a typical complication of sinusitis. Posterior fossa involvement, such as cerebellar infarction, would more commonly result from vertebrobasilar arterial pathology or posterior cranial fossa infections, not from paranasal sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningitis: Possible. Sinus infections, particularly from the frontal, ethmoid, and sphenoid sinuses, can spread to the anterior cranial fossa, leading to meningitis or encephalitis. This is a well-recognized intracranial complication.

 

Option B. Subdural abscess: Possible. This is a serious complication of sinusitis where infection breaches the dura and spreads into the subdural space, especially from frontal or ethmoid sinuses.

 

Option C. Brain abscess: Possible. Sinusitis, especially frontal sinusitis, can lead to localized frontal lobe abscess, or even temporal lobe or occipital lobe abscess in cases of sphenoid sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal, ethmoid, and sphenoid sinusitis may lead to intracranial complications such as meningitis, brain abscess, subdural and extradural abscess, and cavernous sinus thrombosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 201

choices.text: Normal cerebrospinal fluid examination
Involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI
Absence of optic disc changes
Unilateral symptoms with gradual onset

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of untreated ethmoid sinusitis presents with high-grade fever, proptosis, ptosis, and ophthalmoplegia. He has chemosis and decreased corneal sensation on the right side. Which of the following best supports the diagnosis of cavernous sinus thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI

 

The hallmark of cavernous sinus thrombosis is the sequential involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, VI, leading to total ophthalmoplegia. These nerves pass through the cavernous sinus and are vulnerable to inflammation or thrombosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal cerebrospinal fluid examination: This is often seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST), but not specific or diagnostic, as it may be normal in many intracranial infections. It supports the diagnosis but does not confirm it.

 

Option C. Absence of optic disc changes: Incorrect. In CST, the optic disc may show congestion and edema with diminished vision due to increased venous pressure and possibly optic nerve ischemia.

 

Option D. Unilateral symptoms with gradual onset: Incorrect. CST typically has abrupt onset with systemic signs like chills, rigors, high fever, and usually becomes bilateral due to intercavernous sinus communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is characterized by abrupt onset of fever, proptosis, chemosis, and total ophthalmoplegia due to involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 201

choices.text: Angular vein → ophthalmic veins
Petroclival venous sinus → internal jugular vein
Pharyngeal plexus → auditory tube
Lymphatic spread from preauricular nodes

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with high-grade fever, proptosis, chemosis, and ophthalmoplegia. He recently developed a furuncle on the upper lip. Which of the following is the most likely route of spread of infection leading to cavernous sinus thrombosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Angular vein → ophthalmic veins

 

Infections of the nose and “danger area” of the face (including furuncles of upper lip and medial cheek) can spread retrogradely via angular vein into ophthalmic veins, and from there into the cavernous sinus. This is a classical and important route in CST.

 

 

Other Options:
