Option B.Petroclival venous sinus → internal jugular vein: Incorrect. This describes a venous drainage pathway, not a source of CST. However, petrosal sinuses are involved in spread from the ear (petrositis), not from facial furuncles.

 

Option C. Pharyngeal plexus → auditory tube: Incorrect. While pharyngeal plexus may transmit infections like tonsillitis, it is unrelated to furuncular facial infections and doesn’t involve the auditory tube directly in CST.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread from preauricular nodes: Incorrect. Lymphatic spread does not lead directly to cavernous sinus thrombosis; CST occurs due to venous connections, not lymphatics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infections from the danger area of the face can spread to the cavernous sinus via the angular and ophthalmic veins, causing cavernous sinus thrombosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 201

choices.text: Orbital cellulitis
Preseptal cellulitis
Cavernous sinus thrombosis
Allergic conjunctivitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with high-grade fever, chills, bilateral eyelid swelling, chemosis, and proptosis. He is drowsy and shows signs of sequential cranial nerve palsies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

Characterized by:

 

  • Abrupt onset with high fever and chills
  • Signs of toxaemia
  • Bilateral eye involvement
  • Oedema of eyelids, chemosis, proptosis
  • Sequential involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, VI This clinical picture is textbook for CST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital cellulitis: Incorrect. While it presents with eyelid edema, proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia, it usually starts slowly, involves one eye, and cranial nerves are affected simultaneously. This patient has abrupt onset, bilateral involvement, and sequential nerve palsy, which favors CST.

 

 

Option B. Preseptal cellulitis: Incorrect. Involves only eyelid swelling, with no proptosis, chemosis, or ophthalmoplegia. Vision and ocular movements are normal. This is a milder, pre-orbital infection.

 

 

Option D. Allergic conjunctivitis: Incorrect. Presents with bilateral itching, tearing, mild lid swelling, but no fever, proptosis, or cranial nerve palsies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with abrupt onset, high fever, bilateral orbital involvement, and sequential cranial nerve palsies.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 201

choices.text: Otitis externa
Acute epiglottitis
Lateral pharyngitis
Retropharyngeal abscess

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with chronic sinusitis presents with unilateral hypertrophy of the lateral pharyngeal band behind the posterior pillar and recurrent sore throat. Which of the following is the most likely associated condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral pharyngitis

 

In chronic sinusitis, especially with constant postnasal discharge, inflammation can descend into the pharynx, leading to hypertrophy of the lateral pharyngeal bands behind the posterior pillars. It may be unilateral, correlating with the side of sinus involvement.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa: Incorrect. This is an infection of the external auditory canal, unrelated to sinus drainage or pharyngeal involvement.

 

 

Option B. Acute epiglottitis: Incorrect. Presents with high fever, drooling, stridor, and muffled voice, not lateral pharyngeal band hypertrophy. It’s usually not associated with chronic sinusitis.

 

 

 

Option D. Retropharyngeal abscess: Incorrect. This is a deep neck space infection typically seen in younger children, associated with high fever, drooling, and neck stiffness. It is acute and more severe, not a common complication of postnasal drip.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic sinusitis may lead to lateral pharyngitis characterized by hypertrophy of the lateral pharyngeal band on the same side as the affected sinus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 201

choices.text: This lesion most likely arises from the maxillary sinus
It is typically managed with immediate surgical excision
It may cause symptoms by obstructing sinus ostium or compressing adjacent structures
It is most commonly malignant in origin

questions.text: A 35-year-old male undergoes a CT scan for chronic frontal headache and is incidentally found to have a dense, bony lesion within the frontal sinus. He is asymptomatic. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It may cause symptoms by obstructing sinus ostium or compressing adjacent structures

 

 

While often asymptomatic, sinonasal osteomas can become symptomatic due to mechanical obstruction of sinus drainage or mass effect on the orbit, nose, or intracranial structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. This lesion most likely arises from the maxillary sinus: Incorrect. Osteomas most commonly arise from the frontal sinus, followed by ethmoid and then maxillary sinuses.

 

Option B. It is typically managed with immediate surgical excision: Incorrect. Most osteomas are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. Treatment is only indicated if symptomatic, such as in cases causing obstruction, mucocele formation, or pressure symptoms.

 

Option D. It is most commonly malignant in origin: Incorrect. Osteomas are benign tumors of bone and are not malignant. Malignant bony tumors in paranasal sinuses are rare and have a different radiological and clinical profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteomas are benign tumors most commonly seen in the frontal sinus and are treated only when symptomatic due to obstruction or pressure effects.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 205

choices.text: Nickel refining – squamous cell carcinoma of the maxillary sinus
Leather industry – melanoma of the sphenoid sinus
Hardwood furniture work – adenocarcinoma of the ethmoid sinus
Snuff inhalation – adenoid cystic carcinoma of the frontal sinus

questions.text: A 54-year-old male woodworker presents with nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Imaging reveals a mass in the ethmoid sinus. Biopsy shows adenocarcinoma. Which of the following occupational exposures is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hardwood furniture work – adenocarcinoma of the ethmoid sinus

 

This is a well-established association. Wood dust exposure is linked to adenocarcinoma, especially affecting the ethmoid sinuses and upper nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nickel refining – squamous cell carcinoma of the maxillary sinus: Partially correct. Nickel refining is associated with squamous cell and anaplastic carcinomas, but typically affects the upper nasal cavity and ethmoid, not specifically the maxillary sinus alone.

 

Option B. Leather industry – melanoma of the sphenoid sinus: Incorrect. Though leather work is a known risk factor for sinonasal cancers, melanoma of the sphenoid sinus is rare and not classically linked to leather industry exposure.

 

Option D. Snuff inhalation – adenoid cystic carcinoma of the frontal sinus: Incorrect. Snuff use (rich in nickel and chromium) in South African Bantus is linked to maxillary sinus cancer, but not specifically adenoid cystic carcinoma of the frontal sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma of the ethmoid sinus is commonly associated with occupational exposure to hardwood dust in furniture workers.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 205

choices.text: Invasive fungal sinusitis
Carcinoma of the maxillary sinus
Chronic maxillary sinusitis
Dentigerous cyst

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, intermittent epistaxis, swelling of the cheek, and loosening of upper molar teeth. Examination reveals proptosis and trismus. CT scan shows an irregular mass in the maxillary sinus with erosion of surrounding bony walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma of the maxillary sinus

 

This condition:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive fungal sinusitis: Incorrect. Typically occurs in immunocompromised patients with rapid progression, necrosis, and black eschar, not slowly progressive symptoms with orbital and dental involvement in a healthy adult.

 

 

  • Commonly affects males aged 40–60
  • Presents early with vague sinus-like symptoms: nasal stuffiness, blood-stained discharge, facial pain, epiphora
  • Later features depend on direction of spread:
    • Medial: Nasal obstruction, epistaxis
    • Anterior: Cheek swelling, facial skin invasion
    • Inferior: Dental symptoms, gingival ulceration, palatal swelling
    • Superior: Orbital involvement – proptosis, diplopia
    • Posterior: Trismus (pterygoid plate/muscle invasion)
  • Lymph nodes and distant metastasis are usually late features

 

 

 

Option C. Chronic maxillary sinusitis: Incorrect. While this can cause facial pain and discharge, it does not cause proptosis, trismus, or bone destruction. Also lacks signs like loosening of teeth or orbital symptoms.

 

 

Option D. Dentigerous cyst: Incorrect. Typically associated with impacted teeth, found in younger patients, and located around the crown of unerupted tooth in mandible or maxilla. Doesn’t cause extensive bony erosion or orbital symptoms.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoma of the maxillary sinus often presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, cheek swelling, orbital symptoms, and dental changes due to local invasion.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 206

choices.text: Caldwell–Luc operation
CT scan of the paranasal sinuses
Diagnostic nasal endoscopy
Waters' view X-ray of paranasal sinuses

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with persistent nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, and facial pain. Clinical suspicion of maxillary sinus malignancy is made. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for both visualization and biopsy of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diagnostic nasal endoscopy

 

Endoscopy allows direct visualization of the tumor in the nasal cavity or sinus and enables an accurate, minimally invasive biopsy. It is preferred over Caldwell–Luc for early diagnosis and biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell–Luc operation: Invasive. While it can be used to explore the sinus and take biopsy, it is not preferred in early cases. It’s now largely replaced by endoscopic methods due to morbidity and invasiveness.

 

Option B. CT scan of the paranasal sinuses: Though excellent for staging and assessing bony involvement, CT is a noninvasive imaging tool, not diagnostic or therapeutic for taking biopsies.

 

Option D. Waters' view X-ray of paranasal sinuses: Waters' view X-ray – Only provides a plain radiograph, which may show opacity or bone destruction, but is inferior to CT in determining extent and has no role in biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnostic nasal endoscopy is the preferred approach for direct visualization and biopsy in suspected sinonasal malignancies.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 206

choices.text: The tumor lies in the infrastructure and has a favorable prognosis
The tumor lies in the suprastructure and has a poorer prognosis
This line demarcates anterior and posterior maxillary walls
Ohngren’s line is used only for orbital tumors

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with biopsy-proven carcinoma of the maxillary sinus is found on imaging to have a tumor located above a line drawn from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. According to Ohngren’s classification, what does this imply?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The tumor lies in the suprastructure and has a poorer prognosis

 

According to Ohngren’s classification, tumors above the imaginary line drawn from the medial canthus to the angle of the mandible involve the suprastructure (orbit, ethmoid, skull base), which are more difficult to access surgically and have a worse prognosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The tumor lies in the infrastructure and has a favorable prognosis: Incorrect. This applies to tumors below Ohngren’s line, not above it.

 

Option C. This line demarcates anterior and posterior maxillary walls: Incorrect. Ohngren’s line is an oblique line and does not divide anterior vs posterior, but rather suprastructure vs infrastructure.

 

Option D. Ohngren’s line is used only for orbital tumors: Incorrect. While the orbit may be involved in suprastructural tumors, Ohngren’s classification is specifically for maxillary sinus carcinomas to predict prognosis based on anatomical location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ohngren’s line divides the maxillary sinus into suprastructure and infrastructure; tumors above this line have poorer prognosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 207

choices.text: Mesostructure includes ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses
Infrastructure includes olfactory epithelium and frontal sinus
Suprastructure includes ethmoid, frontal, sphenoid sinuses and olfactory area
Maxillary sinus is part of the infrastructure according to Lederman’s classification

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the anatomical divisions used in Lederman’s classification of sinonasal tumors?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suprastructure includes ethmoid, frontal, sphenoid sinuses and olfactory area

 

According to Lederman’s classification, the area above the floor of orbits (Sebileau’s upper line) includes the ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses, and olfactory part of nose, collectively referred to as the suprastructure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mesostructure includes ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses: Incorrect. These are part of the suprastructure, not mesostructure. Mesostructure includes the maxillary sinus and respiratory part of the nose.

 

Option B. Infrastructure includes olfactory epithelium and frontal sinus: Incorrect. Olfactory area and frontal sinus are part of the suprastructure. Infrastructure refers to alveolar process below the floor of the antra.

 

Option D. Maxillary sinus is part of the infrastructure: Incorrect. Maxillary sinus lies between the two horizontal lines and is part of the mesostructure, not infrastructure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lederman’s classification defines the suprastructure as comprising the ethmoid, frontal, sphenoid sinuses and olfactory area of the nose.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 207

choices.text: Surgery alone
Chemoradiation or combined surgery and radiation
Radiotherapy alone with 2000 cGy
Observation and follow-up only

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with biopsy-confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of the maxillary sinus is staged as T4. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chemoradiation or combined surgery and radiation

 

For T3 and T4 carcinomas of the maxillary sinus: Combined surgery + radiation is standard Radiation may be given preoperatively (5500 cGy) or postoperatively (5000–5500 cGy) Chemoradiation is used for inoperable or large tumors, often using cisplatin or 5-FU Advanced radiation techniques like IMRT reduce side effects on optic structures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Surgery alone: Incorrect. Surgery alone is suitable for early-stage tumors (Stage I and II). T4 lesions (advanced disease) require multimodal treatment, not monotherapy.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy alone with 2000 cGy: Incorrect. This dose is inadequate for therapeutic effect. Standard curative doses are 5000–5500 cGy, especially in combination settings.

 

Option D. Observation and follow-up only: Incorrect. T4 disease is aggressive and advanced, requiring active treatment. Observation is never appropriate for malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T3 and T4 carcinomas of the maxillary sinus require combined modalities such as surgery and radiation or chemoradiation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 207

choices.text: Endoscopic sinus surgery
Total maxillectomy
Craniofacial resection
Caldwell–Luc operation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, retro-orbital pain, and lateral displacement of the eyeball. CT scan shows a mass arising from the ethmoid sinus with suspected cribriform plate involvement. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Craniofacial resection

 

For primary ethmoid sinus malignancies involving the cribriform plate or anterior cranial fossa, the preferred treatment is craniofacial resection, performed jointly by an ENT surgeon and neurosurgeon. This ensures en bloc removal of the tumor to reduce recurrence risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic sinus surgery: Incorrect. While used for benign ethmoid lesions or early-stage tumors, it is not suitable when cribriform plate or anterior cranial fossa involvement is suspected.

 

Option B. Total maxillectomy: Incorrect. This is indicated for maxillary sinus malignancies, not primary ethmoid tumors unless there's extensive invasion into the maxilla.

 

Option D. Caldwell–Luc operation: Incorrect. This is a surgical approach to the maxillary sinus and is not appropriate for ethmoid sinus malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethmoid sinus malignancies with cribriform plate involvement are best treated with craniofacial resection for complete tumor removal.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 208

choices.text: Endoscopic sinus surgery alone
Preoperative radiotherapy followed by frontal sinusotomy with ethmoid and orbital exenteration
Caldwell–Luc operation
Antibiotic therapy followed by nasal polypectomy

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with pain and a firm swelling over the forehead above the medial canthus. Imaging reveals a mass in the frontal sinus eroding through the posterior wall and extending into the anterior cranial fossa. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Preoperative radiotherapy followed by frontal sinusotomy with ethmoid and orbital exenteration

 

This is the standard treatment for frontal sinus malignancies. If the dura is involved, neurosurgical resection of anterior cranial fossa dura may also be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic sinus surgery alone: Incorrect. This is insufficient for malignant frontal sinus tumors, especially those invading the orbit or cranial fossa. Open surgical access is necessary.

 

Option C. Caldwell–Luc operation: Incorrect. This procedure is for maxillary sinus access, not indicated for frontal sinus malignancy.

 

Option D. Antibiotic therapy followed by nasal polypectomy: Incorrect. This is for benign inflammatory or infective conditions, not malignancies involving bone erosion and cranial extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus malignancies are treated with preoperative radiation followed by surgery including sinusotomy with ethmoid and orbital exenteration; neurosurgical help is needed if dura is involved.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 209

choices.text: Caldwell–Luc surgery
Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS)
Radiotherapy
Chemotherapy alone

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with deep-seated headache and visual disturbances. Imaging shows a mass in the sphenoid sinus. Biopsy via sphenoidotomy confirms malignancy. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiotherapy

 

Radiotherapy is the mainstay of treatment for primary sphenoid sinus malignancies, especially given the complexity and critical surrounding structures (optic nerve, pituitary, ICA), making extensive surgical resection challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell–Luc surgery: Incorrect. This approach is used for maxillary sinus pathology, not the sphenoid sinus. It offers no access to the sphenoid region.

 

Option B. Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS): Incorrect as definitive therapy. While FESS or sphenoidotomy may help in obtaining a biopsy, it is not the primary treatment modality for malignancy.

 

Option D. Chemotherapy alone: Incorrect. Chemotherapy may be used in combination in certain advanced malignancies, but radiation is the primary treatment for localized sphenoid malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary sphenoid sinus malignancy is rare and primarily treated with radiotherapy after diagnosis is confirmed through CT scan and biopsy via sphenoidotomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 209

choices.text: Endocrinal cause due to Graves’ disease
Neoplastic invasion from a paranasal sinus tumor
Vascular cause such as carotid-cavernous fistula
Idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive unilateral proptosis. CT scan shows a mass in the ethmoid sinus with extension into the orbit. Biopsy confirms inverted papilloma. Which of the following best explains the mechanism of her proptosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neoplastic invasion from a paranasal sinus tumor

 

Neoplastic includes tumors of paranasal sinuses like inverted papilloma, which can invade the orbit and cause proptosis. Ethmoidal sinus tumors are particularly close to the orbit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endocrinal cause due to Graves’ disease: Incorrect. Graves’ disease can cause bilateral or unilateral proptosis, but is not linked to ethmoidal masses like inverted papilloma.

 

Option C. Vascular cause such as carotid-cavernous fistula: Incorrect. This causes pulsatile proptosis, usually with bruit or chemosis, and is unrelated to a sinus-originating mass.

 

Option D. Idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome: Incorrect. This is a diagnosis of exclusion and would not be associated with a biopsy-confirmed tumor from the ethmoid sinus. Here’s a simple and easy-to-remember explanation of the VEIN mnemonic for causes of proptosis:

 

VEIN = Vascular, Endocrine, Inflammatory/Infectious, Neoplastic

V – Vascular

 

Caused by abnormal blood vessels or blood flow:

 

  • Venous varix
  • Cavernous haemangioma
  • Carotid-cavernous fistula

 

These can lead to pulsatile or sudden proptosis.

E – Endocrinal

Most commonly due to Graves’ disease (Thyroid eye disease):

 

  • May cause bilateral or unilateral proptosis
  • Due to enlargement of orbital muscles and fat

 

I – Inflammatory/Infectious

Infections or inflammation in or near the orbit:

 

  • Orbital cellulitis, abscess
  • Idiopathic orbital inflammation (pseudotumor)
  • Fungal infections (e.g. mucormycosis, aspergillosis)
  • Wegener’s granulomatosis

 

Often presents with painful, red, acute proptosis

N – Neoplastic

Tumors from orbit, sinuses, brain, or metastatic sites:

 

  • Primary orbital tumors (e.g. lymphoma, glioma)
  • Tumors of paranasal sinuses (e.g. inverted papilloma)
  • Intracranial tumors (e.g. meningioma of sphenoid ridge)

  • Metastases (e.g. from breast, lung, thyroid)

     

Painless, progressive proptosis is common In short:

 

  • V – Vessels
  • E – Endocrine (Graves’)
  • I – Infection/Inflammation
  • N – Neoplasms (tumors)

 

Tip for NEET-PG:

 

"VEIN" helps you categorize all major causes of proptosis – remember direction (sudden vs progressive), pain, and associated systemic clues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neoplastic invasion from paranasal sinus tumors like inverted papilloma can cause proptosis by extending into the orbit.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 211

choices.text: Perform Valsalva maneuver to rule out venous varix
FNAC or biopsy of the lesion for histopathological diagnosis
Start empirical antibiotics for orbital cellulitis
Order thyroid profile to rule out Graves’ disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive right-sided proptosis and retro-orbital pain. On examination, there is chemosis, restriction of ocular movement, and visual blurring. CT scan shows an extraconal infiltrative mass with bone erosion. What is the next best step in evaluating the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) FNAC or biopsy of the lesion for histopathological diagnosis

 

Given the CT findings of infiltrative extraconal mass with bony erosion, this suggests a neoplastic or granulomatous lesion (e.g., lymphoma, granulomatosis). Hence, FNAC or biopsy is essential for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform Valsalva maneuver to rule out venous varix: Incorrect. Valsalva helps in pulsatile or intermittent proptosis, such as venous varix, not in progressive mass with bone erosion.

 

Option C. Start empirical antibiotics for orbital cellulitis: Incorrect. Orbital cellulitis typically presents acutely with fever, rapid swelling, and no bony erosion. Empirical antibiotics are not appropriate without evidence of infection.

 

Option D. Order thyroid profile to rule out Graves’ disease: Incorrect. While thyroid disease is a cause of proptosis, the infiltrative mass with bony erosion is not typical of Graves’ orbitopathy, which shows muscle belly enlargement without bone erosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FNAC or biopsy is essential in evaluating proptosis with an infiltrative orbital mass to establish the definitive diagnosis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 212

choices.text: Orbital cellulitis; treat with intravenous antibiotics
Cavernous haemangioma; excisional biopsy via lateral orbitotomy
Orbital lymphoma; treat with radiotherapy
Pseudotumour of orbit; treat with high-dose steroids

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with painless, slowly progressive unilateral proptosis. Imaging reveals a well-circumscribed, encapsulated intraconal orbital mass. What is the most likely diagnosis and preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cavernous haemangioma; excisional biopsy via lateral orbitotomy

 

In adults, the most common benign orbital tumor is cavernous haemangioma. It is encapsulated, well-circumscribed, and typically located intraconally, for which lateral orbitotomy is the surgical approach of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital cellulitis; treat with intravenous antibiotics: Incorrect. Cellulitis presents acutely with pain, fever, and erythema. This case is painless, slow-growing, and well-encapsulated, not consistent with infection.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma; treat with radiotherapy: Incorrect. Although orbital lymphoma is the most common malignant orbital tumor in adults, it is not well-encapsulated, and biopsy (not excision) followed by radiation/chemotherapy is the preferred treatment.

 

Option D. Pseudotumour of orbit; treat with high-dose steroids: Incorrect. Pseudotumour presents painfully and acutely with swelling, often bilateral, and is not encapsulated. Steroids are used here but the case described is not suggestive of pseudotumour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavernous haemangioma is the most common benign orbital tumor in adults; it presents as a slow-growing, painless, intraconal mass best treated with excisional biopsy via lateral orbitotomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 213

choices.text: It is done through the middle meatus under general anesthesia in adults
It is contraindicated in chronic maxillary sinusitis due to risk of osteomyelitis
The puncture is made through the medial wall of the maxillary sinus via the inferior meatus
Sitting position is avoided in adults when using local anesthesia

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with chronic maxillary sinusitis is planned for diagnostic and therapeutic antral lavage through inferior meatal antrostomy approach. Which of the following statements regarding the procedure is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The puncture is made through the medial wall of the maxillary sinus via the inferior meatus

 

The procedure involves puncturing the medial wall of the maxillary sinus through the inferior meatus to access and irrigate the sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is done through the middle meatus under general anesthesia in adults: Incorrect. The puncture site is the inferior meatus, and local anesthesia is preferred in adults.

 

Option B. It is contraindicated in chronic maxillary sinusitis due to risk of osteomyelitis: Incorrect. It is actually indicated in chronic and subacute maxillary sinusitis. Acute maxillary sinusitis is the contraindication due to risk of osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Sitting position is avoided in adults when using local anesthesia: Incorrect. Sitting position is preferred in adults under local anesthesia to allow better control and drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proof puncture (antral lavage) is done by puncturing the medial wall of the maxillary sinus through the inferior meatus, especially in chronic maxillary sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 408

choices.text: 1.5–2 cm posterior to the middle turbinate, directed medially
1.5–2 cm from the anterior end of the inferior turbinate, directed towards the homolateral ear
Below the superior turbinate, directed posteriorly
At the junction of nasal floor and nasal septum, directed inferiorly

questions.text: During antral lavage (Proof Puncture), which of the following is the correct site and direction of insertion of Lichtwitz trocar and cannula?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.5–2 cm from the anterior end of the inferior turbinate, directed towards the homolateral ear

 

This is the ideal puncture site, as the bone is thinnest here. The trocar and cannula are inserted towards the homolateral ear, and a "crack" is felt as the nasoantral wall is pierced.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1.5–2 cm posterior to the middle turbinate, directed medially: Incorrect. The middle turbinate is not the target site for puncture in antral lavage. The correct site is near the anterior end of the inferior turbinate.

 

Option C. Below the superior turbinate, directed posteriorly: Incorrect. This area is not used for antral lavage. Superior turbinate is related to the sphenoid sinus and olfactory area.

 

Option D. At the junction of nasal floor and nasal septum, directed inferiorly: Incorrect. This site is unrelated to the maxillary sinus entry point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antral lavage is performed by puncturing the lateral wall of the inferior meatus 1.5–2 cm from the anterior end of the inferior turbinate and directing the cannula towards the homolateral ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 408

choices.text: Suppurative maxillary sinusitis
Hyperplastic sinusitis
Antral cyst
Mucocele of frontal sinus

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient undergoes an antral lavage (Proof Puncture) for suspected chronic maxillary sinusitis. During the procedure, amber-colored fluid containing cholesterol crystals flows immediately from the cannula. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antral cyst

 

The presence of thin amber-colored fluid containing cholesterol crystals upon puncture is characteristic of an antral cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suppurative maxillary sinusitis: Incorrect. Suppurative sinusitis is suggested by foul-smelling pus that mixes easily with the irrigating fluid, not amber-colored fluid with crystals.

 

Option B. Hyperplastic sinusitis: Incorrect. This is indicated by blobs of mucopus in the washings, not clear amber fluid with crystals.

 

Option D. Mucocele of frontal sinus: Incorrect. While mucoceles can produce mucus, this diagnosis is related to the frontal sinus, not the maxillary sinus evaluated during antral lavage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate outflow of amber-colored fluid containing cholesterol crystals during antral lavage indicates the presence of an antral cyst.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 409

choices.text: It is preferred over middle meatal antrostomy as it is more physiological
It is contraindicated in chronic purulent maxillary sinusitis
The opening is made in the nasoantral wall via the inferior meatus
The most common complication is injury to the optic nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding Intranasal Inferior Meatal Antrostomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The opening is made in the nasoantral wall via the inferior meatus

 

 

The technique involves creating a 1.5–2 cm opening in the nasoantral wall through the inferior meatus, near the floor of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is preferred over middle meatal antrostomy as it is more physiological: Incorrect Middle meatal antrostomy is now preferred because it is more physiological, allowing drainage through the natural ostium and is done via endoscopic techniques.

 

Option B. It is contraindicated in chronic purulent maxillary sinusitis: Incorrect. Chronic purulent maxillary sinusitis is actually an indication for this procedure.

 

Option D. The most common complication is injury to the optic nerve: Incorrect. Optic nerve injury is not a known complication of this procedure. Postoperative bleeding and nasolacrimal duct injury are more relevant risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intranasal inferior meatal antrostomy involves creating an opening in the nasoantral wall through the inferior meatus, mainly for chronic purulent maxillary sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 410

choices.text: It is performed through a transnasal approach via the inferior meatus
It is contraindicated in patients above the age of 17
It provides access to the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall via the canine fossa
It is the preferred procedure for acute maxillary sinusitis in children

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Caldwell–Luc operation is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It provides access to the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall via the canine fossa

 

This is the hallmark of the procedure – anterior antrostomy through the canine fossa, allowing entry to the maxillary sinus to deal with various pathologies.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is performed through a transnasal approach via the inferior meatus: Incorrect That describes inferior meatal antrostomy, not the Caldwell–Luc procedure. Caldwell–Luc is performed via a sublabial (buccogingival) incision accessing the anterior wall of the maxillary sinus.

 

Option B. It is contraindicated in patients above the age of 17: Incorrect The operation is actually contraindicated in children below 17 years due to risk of damaging developing tooth buds and maxillary growth centers.

 

Option D. It is the preferred procedure for acute maxillary sinusitis in children: Incorrect It is contraindicated in children and not indicated for acute infections. Conservative management or other less invasive approaches are preferred.

 

Educational Objective: Caldwell–Luc operation provides anterior access to the maxillary sinus via the canine fossa and is contraindicated in children below 17 years.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 411

choices.text: Facial nerve palsy
Anaesthesia of the cheek due to infraorbital nerve injury
Injury to the optic nerve
CSF rhinorrhea due to cribriform plate breach

questions.text: Which of the following is a recognized complication of the Caldwell–Luc operation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anaesthesia of the cheek due to infraorbital nerve injury

 

This is a common complication due to stretching or trauma to the infraorbital nerve, which traverses the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sensory loss may extend to the cheek or upper teeth, and may persist for weeks or months.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Facial nerve palsy: Incorrect Facial nerve is not in proximity to the surgical field of Caldwell–Luc. It is not a known complication of this procedure.

 

Options C. Injury to the optic nerve: Incorrect Optic nerve lies posteriorly and superiorly; it is not commonly affected in anterior antrostomy procedures like Caldwell–Luc.

 

Options D. CSF rhinorrhea due to cribriform plate breach: Incorrect Cribriform plate is involved in surgeries of ethmoid sinus or skull base, not typically in Caldwell–Luc which targets the maxillary sinus via the anterior wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the infraorbital nerve causing cheek anaesthesia is a common complication of Caldwell–Luc operation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 412

choices.text: DNS causing recurrent sinusitis
Patient aged 15 years
Septal spur causing epistaxis
DNS as part of approach for trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for performing a Submucous Resection (SMR) operation of the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patient aged 15 years

 

Contraindicated as SMR is avoided in patients <17 years to prevent interference with nasal growth centers. In such cases, septoplasty is preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNS causing recurrent sinusitis: Incorrect This is a valid indication for SMR surgery as DNS may obstruct sinus ventilation, leading to recurrent sinusitis.

 

Option C. Septal spur causing epistaxis: Incorrect This is an accepted indication for SMR surgery, especially if bleeding is recurrent and originates from contact trauma due to a spur.

 

Option D. DNS as part of approach for trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy: Incorrect SMR is often performed as a preliminary step in surgeries like trans-septal hypophysectomy or vidian neurectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients younger than 17 years are not suitable for SMR; septoplasty is preferred to preserve nasal growth.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 413

choices.text: Infection of septal haematoma
Over-removal of cartilage along dorsal border
Inadequate packing post-surgery
Retention of caudal septal strip

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of a supratip depression following a Submucous Resection (SMR) surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Over-removal of cartilage along dorsal border

 

This results in depression of nasal bridge, especially the supratip area, due to lack of support from dorsal septal cartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infection of septal haematoma: Incorrect This can lead to a septal abscess, not supratip depression.

 

Option C. Inadequate packing post-surgery: Incorrect This may contribute to septal haematoma or bleeding, but not specifically to supratip depression.

 

Option D. Retention of caudal septal strip: Incorrect This is actually preventive against columellar retraction. Loss of this strip causes retraction, not depression of the bridge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Excessive removal of dorsal septal cartilage during SMR can cause supratip depression of the nasal bridge.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 413

choices.text: It involves bilateral elevation of mucoperichondrial flaps and complete removal of the septal framework
It is contraindicated in sleep apnea patients
It is the preferred technique over SMR for septal deviation correction
It is done only for cosmetic nasal deformity correction

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding septoplasty?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the preferred technique over SMR for septal deviation correction

 

Septoplasty has almost replaced SMR because it’s less invasive and tissue-sparing, making it the procedure of choice for symptomatic DNS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It involves bilateral elevation of mucoperichondrial flaps and complete removal of the septal framework: Incorrect That describes SMR (Submucous Resection). Septoplasty is more conservative — only one side's flap is usually elevated, and most of the septal framework is retained.

 

Option B. It is contraindicated in sleep apnea patients: Incorrect In fact, septoplasty is sometimes indicated in patients with sleep apnoea or hypopnoea syndrome due to nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. It is done only for cosmetic nasal deformity correction: Incorrect Septoplasty has both functional and aesthetic indications, including nasal obstruction, headache, sinusitis, and as an approach in endoscopic surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septoplasty is a conservative procedure that has replaced SMR and is the preferred surgical method for correcting symptomatic septal deviation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 415

choices.text: Septal perforation
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhoea
Columellar retraction
Saddle nose deformity

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare but serious complication of septoplasty due to avulsion of the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhoea

 

This is a rare but serious complication, occurring if the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid is avulsed during surgery, potentially breaching the cribriform plate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septal perforation: Incorrect This is a common complication and usually results from tears on opposing mucosal sides during surgery.

 

Option C. Columellar retraction: Incorrect Occurs when the caudal strip of cartilage is not preserved, leading to cosmetic deformity, but not life-threatening.

 

Option D. Saddle nose deformity: Incorrect Caused by excessive removal of dorsal cartilage, commonly seen in both SMR and septoplasty if not conservatively performed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhoea is a rare complication of septoplasty that occurs due to avulsion of the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid bone.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 415

choices.text: Use of microdebriders to minimize bleeding
Removal of large portions of sinus bone to access disease
Computer-assisted image-guided navigational surgery
Improved optics and brighter illumination

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage or advancement that has contributed to the success of modern endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Removal of large portions of sinus bone to access disease

 

This refers to older conventional surgeries (like Caldwell–Luc) and is not a feature of endoscopic surgery, which aims to preserve mucosa and minimize bone removal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Use of microdebriders to minimize bleeding: Incorrect Microdebriders (powered tissue shavers) are used for precise tissue removal and are one of the major advancements in reducing intraoperative bleeding during endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

Option C. Computer-assisted image-guided navigational surgery: Incorrect This is a recent and important advancement, especially helpful in difficult or revision surgeries where normal anatomical landmarks are distorted.

 

Option D. Improved optics and brighter illumination: Incorrect Development of better optics and brighter illumination has significantly enhanced the precision and safety of endoscopic procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic sinus surgery is a minimally invasive technique that preserves mucosa and avoids extensive bone removal, aided by advanced optics, powered instruments, and image-guided navigation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 419

choices.text: Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to medical therapy
Diffuse nasal polyposis
Deviated nasal septum without sinus involvement
Mucocele of sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Which of the following is not a recognized indication for Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deviated nasal septum without sinus involvement

 

While endoscopic septoplasty can be done using endoscopes, FESS itself is not indicated solely for septal deviation unless it obstructs access to the sinuses or contributes to sinus disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to medical therapy: Incorrect. This is one of the primary indications for FESS when conservative management fails.

 

Option B. Diffuse nasal polyposis: Incorrect. Also known as polypoid rhinosinusitis, this is a classic indication for FESS to restore ventilation and drainage of sinuses.

 

Option D. Mucocele of sphenoid sinus: Incorrect. This condition requires surgical drainage and is a clear indication for endoscopic sinus surgery, especially given the deep location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FESS is indicated in chronic or recurrent sinus pathologies, nasal polyps, fungal sinusitis, mucoceles, epistaxis, and foreign body removal, but not for isolated septal deviation without sinus involvement.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 419

choices.text: Maxillary ostium lies anterior to the uncinate process and is opened using a Kerrison punch.
Onodi cell is an anterior ethmoid cell that increases risk to the optic nerve during ethmoidectomy.
Frontal sinusotomy should always be done, regardless of CT findings.
Basal lamella separates anterior and posterior ethmoid cells and must be penetrated medially and inferiorly for access to posterior ethmoid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the steps of Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal lamella separates anterior and posterior ethmoid cells and must be penetrated medially and inferiorly for access to posterior ethmoid cells.

 

This is the correct surgical step in FESS. The basal lamella is a thin bony septum dividing the anterior and posterior ethmoids and is penetrated medially and inferiorly using a curette.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maxillary ostium lies anterior to the uncinate process and is opened using a Kerrison punch: Incorrect. The maxillary ostium lies posterior to the lower third of the uncinate process and is usually enlarged with a backbiting forceps or through-cut straight forceps, not a Kerrison punch.

 

Option B. Onodi cell is an anterior ethmoid cell that increases risk to the optic nerve during ethmoidectomy: Incorrect. The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoid cell that extends into the sphenoid bone and lies close to the optic nerve, hence its significance. Calling it an anterior ethmoid cell is incorrect.

 

Option C. Frontal sinusotomy should always be done, regardless of CT findings: Incorrect. If the frontal sinus is clear and the patient does not complain of frontal headaches, no surgical intervention is needed in the frontal sinus during FESS.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In FESS, the basal lamella is penetrated medially and inferiorly to access the posterior ethmoid cells.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 419

choices.text: Periorbital ecchymosis
Orbital haemorrhage
Hyposmia
Postoperative infection

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient underwent Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) for chronic rhinosinusitis. Postoperatively, he developed restricted eye movement, proptosis, and diplopia. Which of the following is the most likely major complication responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital haemorrhage

 

This is a major complication of FESS that can cause proptosis, diplopia, and even vision loss if not managed promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Periorbital ecchymosis: This is a minor complication. It may cause bruising but not restricted eye movement or diplopia.

 

Option C. Hyposmia: A minor complication affecting smell; it doesn’t explain diplopia or restricted movement.

 

Option D. Postoperative infection: While a known minor complication (rhinitis or sinusitis), it usually does not present with acute orbital signs like proptosis or ophthalmoplegia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Orbital haemorrhage is a major complication of endoscopic sinus surgery that can cause proptosis, diplopia, and vision loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg. 421

choices.text: Ethmoid sinus
Maxillary sinus
Mastoid air cells
Petrous part of the temporal bone

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with recurrent maxillary sinusitis undergoes an X-ray in which his nose and chin are placed against the film, and the X-ray beam is projected from behind. Which of the following structures is BEST visualized in this radiographic view?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary sinus

 

This is the best visualized structure in Waters’ view (occipitomental view), especially useful for detecting sinusitis, fluid levels, and fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethmoid sinus: Better seen on Rhese view or CT scan. Not the primary target of Waters' view.

 

 

Option C. Mastoid air cells: Best seen in lateral or Towne’s view, not Waters’.

 

 

Option D. Petrous part of the temporal bone: In Waters’ view, petrous ridges are projected below the maxillary antra and are not the primary focus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Waters’ view (occipitomental) is the best radiographic view for visualizing maxillary sinuses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 433

choices.text: Sphenoid sinus
Maxillary sinus
Frontal sinus
Mastoid air cells

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with recurrent frontal headache undergoes an X-ray with her nose and forehead resting against the film. The X-ray beam is angled 15–20° caudally. Which of the following is the best visualized structure in this view?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal sinus

 

Caldwell view is ideal for visualizing frontal sinuses due to the nose-forehead positioning and caudally angled beam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sphenoid sinus: Not well seen in Caldwell view; better seen in basal view or pierre view (water view with open mouth).

 

 

Option B. Maxillary sinus: Is visible in Caldwell view, but not the best seen. Maxillary sinus is best seen in Waters’ view.

 

 

Option D. Mastoid air cells: Best evaluated using lateral view or Towne’s view; not targeted in Caldwell view.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Caldwell view (occipitofrontal) is the best radiographic view for visualizing frontal sinuses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

choices.text: Inferior turbinate
Cribriform plate
Sella turcica
Lamina papyracea

questions.text: A lateral X-ray of the skull is taken in a patient presenting with suspected sphenoid sinusitis. The patient's head is positioned with one side against the film, and the beam is projected perpendicular from the opposite side. Which of the following structures is best evaluated in this view?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sella turcica

 

Clearly seen in lateral view as a depression in the sphenoid bone housing the pituitary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior turbinate: Best visualized on coronal or axial CT of paranasal sinuses, not lateral view.

 

Option B. Cribriform plate: Difficult to evaluate on plain X-rays; better assessed on coronal CT.

 

Option D. Lamina papyracea: Very thin orbital wall, better seen in coronal CT scan than lateral X-ray.

 

The lateral view is useful in showing:

 

  • Anterior and posterior extent of frontal, maxillary, and sphenoid sinuses.
  • Sella turcica (key landmark for pituitary lesions).
  • Ethmoid sinuses, alveolar process, and mandibular condyle.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Lateral skull X-ray is the best view to visualize the sella turcica and the anterior-posterior extent of paranasal sinuses.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

choices.text: Frontal sinus
Sphenoid sinus
Cribriform plate
Nasolacrimal duct

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient is being evaluated for posterior ethmoid sinusitis. An X-ray is taken with the head extended such that the vertex touches the film and the beam is directed from below the mandible. This radiographic view is called the submentovertical view. Which of the following structures is best visualized in this view?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sphenoid sinus

 

Best visualized in the submentovertical (basal) view, followed by posterior ethmoid and maxillary sinuses.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal sinus: Best seen in Caldwell or Waters’ view, not submentovertical.

 

 

Option C. Cribriform plate: Seen in high-resolution CT, not well-demonstrated on standard X-ray views.

 

Option D. Nasolacrimal duct: Best seen in CT-Dacryocystography or direct imaging of lacrimal system.

 

The submentovertical view (also called basal view) shows:

 

  • Sphenoid > Posterior ethmoid > Maxillary sinuses clearly.
  • Zygoma and zygomatic arch.
  • Mandible including coronoid and condyloid processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Submentovertical (basal) view is the best radiographic projection to visualize the sphenoid sinus and zygomatic arches.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

choices.text: Blurring of the maxillary sinus wall
Radiolucent line across the lower nasal bone with depression of the bony contour
Opacification of the frontal sinus
Increased soft tissue shadow in the nasolabial fold

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with nasal trauma following a road traffic accident. A lateral view X-ray of the nasal bones is obtained. Which of the following radiological findings is most suggestive of a nasal bone fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radiolucent line across the lower nasal bone with depression of the bony contour

 

This is the hallmark of a nasal bone fracture on lateral nasal bone X-ray. The lower part of the nasal bone is thinner and more prone to fractures. Depressed fragments confirm displacement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blurring of the maxillary sinus wall: More commonly associated with sinusitis or facial bone fractures other than nasal bone.

 

Option C. Opacification of the frontal sinus: Seen in frontal sinusitis or trauma to the frontal bone, not typically indicating nasal bone fracture.

 

Option D. Increased soft tissue shadow in the nasolabial fold: Can occur in facial trauma but is not specific or diagnostic of nasal bone fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In lateral nasal bone X-ray, a radiolucent line with contour depression of the lower nasal bone is diagnostic of a nasal bone fracture.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

choices.text: Tilley’s forceps – used for nasal packing removal
Freer elevator – used for septoplasty dissection
Lichtwitz trocar and cannula – used for proof puncture in the inferior meatus
Hartmann’s nasal dressing forceps – used for nasal foreign body removal

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its correct use:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lichtwitz trocar and cannula – used for proof puncture in the inferior meatus

 

This is the classic instrument used for antral lavage (proof puncture) via the inferior meatus. The trocar pierces the thin lateral wall of the inferior meatus and the cannula allows saline irrigation of the maxillary sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tilley’s forceps – used for nasal packing removal: Tilley’s forceps: These are long forceps used to pack or remove gauze from the nasal cavity. Not used for sinus puncture.

 

 

Option B. Freer elevator – used for septoplasty dissection: Freer elevator: A flat double-ended instrument used for mucoperichondrial flap elevation in septoplasty—not for sinus puncture.

 

 

Option D. Hartmann’s nasal dressing forceps – used for nasal foreign body removal: Hartmann’s nasal dressing forceps - Angled forceps used primarily for dressing and foreign body removal, not for antral procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichtwitz trocar and cannula is used for proof puncture or antral lavage of the maxillary sinus via the inferior meatus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 453

choices.text: Freer’s elevator – used for mucoperichondrial flap elevation
Killian’s gouge – used for bone removal in SMR
Tilley’s harpoon – used for intranasal antrostomy in inferior meatus
Luc’s forceps – used for removing polyps

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its correct usage:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tilley’s harpoon – used for intranasal antrostomy in inferior meatus

 

This curved sharp instrument is used for creating an opening in the lateral wall of inferior meatus (intranasal antrostomy). Its hook-like tip allows removal of bone chips on withdrawal, avoiding bone fragments falling into the sinus cavity. Though effective, it is rarely used nowadays due to more advanced FESS techniques.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Freer’s elevator – used for mucoperichondrial flap elevation: Freer’s elevator - Flat, blunt-ended instrument for lifting the mucoperichondrium in septal surgeries—not used for bone perforation.

 

 

Option B. Killian’s gouge – used for bone removal in SMR: Killian’s gouge - A bony instrument for chiseling bone in SMR or frontal sinusotomy—not suitable for puncturing the antrum.

 

 

Option D. Luc’s forceps – used for removing polyps: Luc’s forceps - Used for grasping and removing nasal polyps or tissues, not for making antrostomy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tilley’s harpoon is a curved sharp instrument used for creating intranasal antrostomy in the inferior meatus by puncturing the lateral wall and removing bone chips.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 453

choices.text: Caldwell–Luc operation
Septoplasty
Intranasal inferior meatal antrostomy
Endoscopic ethmoidectomy

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is primarily used for which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intranasal inferior meatal antrostomy

 

The instrument shown is Tilley’s antral burr, historically used to enlarge and smoothen the bony opening created during intranasal inferior meatal antrostomy. It followed the use of Tilley’s harpoon, which made the initial entry.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell–Luc operation: This involves entering the maxillary sinus via the anterior wall through a sublabial approach, not typically requiring this instrument.

 

Option B. Septoplasty: Used to correct deviated nasal septum; this instrument is not used in the procedure.

 

Option D. Endoscopic ethmoidectomy: Modern FESS procedures use endoscopic tools, not this traditional burr.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Tilley’s antral burr was used to enlarge and smoothen the hole in the inferior meatus during intranasal antrostomy, though it is rarely used now.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 453

choices.text: Lichtwitz trocar – Proof puncture of maxillary sinus
Rose's sinus douching cannula – Irrigation of maxillary sinus through nasoantral window
Tilley's antral burr – Enlargement of nasoantral window
Endoscopic suction cannula – Clearance of ethmoidal sinus

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its most appropriate use.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rose's sinus douching cannula – Irrigation of maxillary sinus through nasoantral window

 

It is used to irrigate the maxillary sinus once a nasoantral window is already present—either due to Caldwell–Luc surgery or intranasal antrostomy. The hook near the handle indicates the direction of the tip inside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichtwitz trocar – Proof puncture of maxillary sinus: Lichtwitz trocar is used for initial puncture (proof puncture) of the maxillary sinus through the inferior meatus, not for irrigation after a window is made.

 

 

Option C. Tilley's antral burr – Enlargement of nasoantral window: Tilley’s antral burr is used to enlarge and smoothen the bony opening during inferior meatal antrostomy, not for irrigation.

 

 

Option D. Endoscopic suction cannula – Clearance of ethmoidal sinus: Endoscopic suction cannula is used for debridement or suctioning in functional endoscopic sinus surgery, not in irrigation via a previously created nasoantral window.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Rose’s sinus douching cannula is used for irrigating the maxillary sinus through a nasoantral window created during procedures like Caldwell–Luc or intranasal antrostomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 453

choices.text: Luc’s forceps – Used for grasping and avulsing nasal polyps
Tilley’s harpoon – Used for Caldwell–Luc operation
Killian’s nasal speculum – Used for SMR to visualize septum
Blakesley forceps – Used for inferior turbinectomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and match it to its most appropriate clinical use.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Luc’s forceps – Used for grasping and avulsing nasal polyps

 

The instrument shown is Luc’s forceps, a versatile tool used in Caldwell–Luc operation to remove the diseased sinus mucosa, in SMR to remove bony/cartilaginous septal segments, and also commonly for avulsing nasal polyps during polypectomy. It is also employed for taking biopsies from nasal and pharyngeal masses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tilley’s harpoon – Used for Caldwell–Luc operation: Tilley’s harpoon – used in intranasal antrostomy, not for grasping polyps or removal of mucosa.

 

 

Option C. Killian’s nasal speculum – Used for SMR to visualize septum: Killian’s nasal speculum – used for visualization, not removal, especially in procedures like SMR or septoplasty.

 

 

Option D. Blakesley forceps – Used for inferior turbinectomy: Blakesley forceps – Though also used for polypectomy, Blakesley’s forceps are angled and used with endoscopes in FESS, not open surgeries like Caldwell–Luc.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Luc’s forceps are used in ENT surgeries like Caldwell–Luc operation, SMR, polypectomy, and biopsy for grasping, avulsing, and removing tissue.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 453

choices.text: Ballenger’s swivel knife – Used in SMR for cartilage removal
Krause’s nasal snare – Used for avulsion of nasal polyps
Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula – Used for antral lavage
Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to enlarge antrostomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its primary use.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Krause’s nasal snare – Used for avulsion of nasal polyps

 

The instrument in the image is Krause’s nasal snare, primarily used for removal of nasal polyps. The polyp is engaged in the wire loop (30 SWG) and avulsed by tightening the loop. Though its use has declined with the advent of endoscopic techniques, it is a classical instrument used for nasal polypectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ballenger’s swivel knife – Used in SMR for cartilage removal: Ballenger’s swivel knife is used for excising septal cartilage during SMR (submucous resection), not for polyp removal.

 

 

Option C. Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula – Used for antral lavage: Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula is used for proof puncture (antral lavage) via the inferior meatus, not for nasal polypectomy.

 

 

Option D. Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to enlarge antrostomy: Killian’s nasal gouge is used to enlarge the bony window during antrostomy, not for polyp avulsion.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Krause’s nasal snare is a classical instrument used to avulse nasal polyps by tightening a wire loop around their stalk.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 453

choices.text: Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to remove bony spur during antrostomy
Thudicum’s nasal speculum – Used in anterior rhinoscopy
St. Clair Thomson’s nasal speculum – Used in nasal surgeries like SMR and septoplasty
Boyle-Davis mouth gag – Used for exposure of oropharynx during tonsillectomy

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its primary use:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) St. Clair Thomson’s nasal speculum – Used in nasal surgeries like SMR and septoplasty

 

The instrument shown is St. Clair Thomson’s nasal speculum, easily recognized by its long, concave blades designed to retract the nasal cavity during intranasal surgeries like SMR (submucous resection) or septoplasty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to remove bony spur during antrostomy: (Killian’s nasal gouge) is used for enlarging bony openings in antrostomy, not for nasal cavity exposure.

 

 

Option B. Thudicum’s nasal speculum – Used in anterior rhinoscopy: (Thudicum’s nasal speculum) use in anterior rhinoscopy has shorter blades, and is not suitable for surgical exposure.

 

 

Option D. Boyle-Davis mouth gag – Used for exposure of oropharynx during tonsillectomy: (Boyle-Davis mouth gag) is used for oropharyngeal exposure, especially in tonsillectomy, and is unrelated to nasal procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

St. Clair Thomson’s nasal speculum, with its long, concave blades, is primarily used to retract nasal structures during SMR or septoplasty.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 453

choices.text: St. Clair Thomson’s speculum – Used for anterior nasal examination
Killian’s long-bladed nasal speculum – Used in SMR or septoplasty to keep mucoperiosteal flaps away
Thudicum’s speculum – Used in posterior rhinoscopy
Boyle-Davis gag – Used in endoscopic sinus surgery

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown and its primary use in nasal surgery:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Killian’s long-bladed nasal speculum – Used in SMR or septoplasty to keep mucoperiosteal flaps away

 

The instrument shown is Killian’s long-bladed nasal speculum, characterized by long, narrow blades and a strong handle. It is specifically used in Submucous Resection (SMR) or septoplasty procedures to hold apart the mucoperiosteal flaps for proper visualization and access to the septal cartilage and bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. St. Clair Thomson’s speculum – Used for anterior nasal examination: St. Clair Thomson’s speculum is also used in nasal surgery, but it has broader, concave blades and is mainly used for initial exposure, not for deep retraction during flap elevation.

 

 

Option C. Thudicum’s speculum – Used in posterior rhinoscopy: Thudicum’s speculum is used for anterior rhinoscopy, not surgical access.

 

 

Option D. Boyle-Davis gag – Used in endoscopic sinus surgery: Boyle-Davis gag is an oral instrument used for tonsillectomy and oropharyngeal surgeries, not nasal procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Killian’s long-bladed nasal speculum is used in septal surgeries like SMR and septoplasty to retract mucoperiosteal flaps and expose the nasal septum.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 454

choices.text: Luc’s forceps – For avulsing nasal polyps during polypectomy
Tilley’s dressing forceps – For nasal packing, ear dressing, and foreign body removal
Hartmann’s forceps – For grasping tonsillar tissue
Wilde’s forceps – For foreign body removal in the external auditory canal

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its correct use in ENT practice:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tilley’s dressing forceps – For nasal packing, ear dressing, and foreign body removal

 

The instrument shown is Tilley’s dressing forceps, a box-joint, curved forceps with serrated jaws. It is specifically designed for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removing foreign bodies from the nasal cavity or ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luc’s forceps – For avulsing nasal polyps during polypectomy: Luc’s forceps are larger, have a heavier build, and are used for grasping and removing polyps or nasal mucosa, especially in Caldwell–Luc operation or polypectomy, not for delicate packing.

 

 

Option C. Hartmann’s forceps – For grasping tonsillar tissue: Hartmann’s forceps are similar to tilley forceps. It has a screw joint. The jaw is serrated and grooved.

 

 

Option D. Wilde’s forceps – For foreign body removal in the external auditory canal: Wilde’s forceps are fine and angled, primarily used for packing the nasal cavity or ear canal. It acts on spring action.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tilley’s dressing forceps are commonly used ENT instruments for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removing foreign bodies from the nose.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 454

choices.text: Luc’s forceps – Fenestrated tip, used for mucosal removal
Wilde’s forceps – Long, slender shaft, used for aural foreign body removal
Hartmann’s dressing forceps – Screw joint with serrated, grooved jaws
Tilley’s dressing forceps – Box joint with smooth jaws

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its distinctive features:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hartmann’s dressing forceps – Screw joint with serrated, grooved jaws

 

The instrument shown is Hartmann’s dressing forceps, used in ENT for nasal packing, ear dressing, and removal of foreign bodies. It resembles Tilley’s dressing forceps but is distinguished by its screw joint and serrated, grooved jaws, offering a better grip

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luc’s forceps – Fenestrated tip, used for mucosal removal: Luc’s forceps are broader and fenestrated, used in Caldwell–Luc operation or for polyp removal, not for nasal packing.

 

 

Option B. Wilde’s forceps – Long, slender shaft, used for aural foreign body removal:  Wilde’s forceps are primarily used for ear procedures and are more delicate with a straight, narrow design.

 

 

Option D. Tilley’s dressing forceps – Box joint with smooth jaws: Tilley’s forceps are similar in function but have a box joint, not a screw joint.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hartmann’s dressing forceps are identified by their screw joint and serrated, grooved jaws, and are used for nasal packing and foreign body removal.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 454

choices.text: Hartmann’s dressing forceps – Screw joint with serrated jaws
Wilde’s dressing forceps – Spring action, used for nasal or aural packing
Tilley’s dressing forceps – Box joint, used for nasal foreign body removal
Luc’s forceps – Fenestrated jaws, used for polyp removal

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its main usage:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wilde’s dressing forceps – Spring action, used for nasal or aural packing

 

is correct: The instrument shown is Wilde’s dressing forceps, which is distinguished by its slender, curved profile and spring action mechanism. It is commonly used for nasal and aural packing, especially in narrow cavities like the external auditory canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hartmann’s dressing forceps – Screw joint with serrated jaws: Hartmann’s forceps has a screw joint and serrated jaws but lacks spring action

 

 

Option C. Tilley’s dressing forceps – Box joint, used for nasal foreign body removal: Tilley’s forceps are similar in appearance but are longer, have a box joint, and are more commonly used for removal of nasal foreign bodies.

 

Option D. Luc’s forceps – Fenestrated jaws, used for polyp removal:  Luc’s forceps have broad, fenestrated jaws and are used in Caldwell–Luc operation, SMR, and nasal polypectomy, not for packing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilde’s dressing forceps are spring action forceps used for packing the nasal cavity or ear canal.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 454

choices.text: Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to remove bony spurs of the septum
Ballenger swivel knife – Used for septal cartilage removal in SMR
Luc’s forceps – Used for avulsing nasal polyps
Freer’s elevator – Used for elevating mucoperichondrial flap

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its primary use:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ballenger swivel knife – Used for septal cartilage removal in SMR

 

The instrument is Ballenger’s swivel knife, designed with a revolving blade that adjusts direction while cutting cartilage during Submucous Resection (SMR) operation. It’s specifically used for harvesting and removing septal cartilage, which can also be used for grafting in reconstructive surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to remove bony spurs of the septum: Killian’s nasal gouge is used for removing septal bony spurs, not cartilage, and does not have a rotating blade.

 

 

Option C. Luc’s forceps – Used for avulsing nasal: Polyps Luc’s forceps are fenestrated and used in polypectomy or Caldwell–Luc operation, not for septal cartilage.

 

 

Option D. Freer’s elevator – Used for elevating mucoperichondrial flap: Freer’s elevator is used in elevating mucoperichondrial flap, not for cutting cartilage.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ballenger swivel knife is used for removal and graft harvest of septal cartilage in SMR surgery.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 454

choices.text: Asch’s forceps – Used for nasal septal fracture reduction
Luc’s forceps – Used for removing nasal polyps
Walsham’s forceps – Used for disimpaction and reduction of nasal bone fractures
Killian’s nasal gouge – Used for septal spur removal

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image and its primary use:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Walsham’s forceps – Used for disimpaction and reduction of nasal bone fractures

 

The instrument shown is Walsham’s forceps, which is designed with a smooth rubber-covered blade to reduce and disimpact nasal bone fractures. It is especially useful for externally manipulating the nasal bones after trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asch’s forceps - Used for nasal septal fracture reduction: Particularly in the case of buckled septum, not for nasal bone manipulation.

 

 

Option B. Luc’s forceps – Used for removing nasal polyps: Luc’s forceps are fenestrated and used in procedures like polypectomy or for removing mucosal lining in Caldwell–Luc operation, not for reducing nasal fractures.

 

 

Option D. Killian’s nasal gouge – Used for septal spur removal: Killian’s nasal gouge is used for removing bony spurs of the septum, not for managing nasal bone fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Walsham’s forceps are used to disimpact and reduce nasal bone fractures externally.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 454

choices.text: Killian’s nasal gouge – Used for septal spur removal
Asch’s septum forceps – Used for reducing fractures of nasal septum
Walsham’s forceps – Used for reducing nasal bone fractures
Luc’s forceps – Used for removal of nasal polyp

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown and its most appropriate use:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asch’s septum forceps – Used for reducing fractures of nasal septum

 

The instrument shown is Asch’s septum forceps, used to reduce fractures of the nasal septum, particularly in cases of post-traumatic buckling. The blades are angled and grooved in such a way that both mucoperichondrial flaps are preserved while straightening the septal cartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killian’s nasal gouge – Used for septal spur removal: Killian’s nasal gouge is a curved instrument used to remove bony septal spurs, not for septal fracture reduction.

 

 

Option C. Walsham’s forceps – Used for reducing nasal bone fractures: Walsham’s forceps are designed to reduce displaced nasal bones, not the septum.

 

 

Option D. Luc’s forceps – Used for removal of nasal polyp: Luc’s forceps are used to grasp and remove nasal polyps or mucosa from sinuses in Caldwell–Luc operation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asch’s septum forceps are used for reducing fractures of the nasal septum by preserving both mucosal flaps.

 

P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 454

choices.text: Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to remove septal bony spur
Ballenger swivel knife – Used for septal cartilage removal
Freer’s elevator – Used to elevate mucoperichondrial flap in septal surgeries
Luc’s forceps – Used for avulsion of nasal polyps

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown and its most appropriate use:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Freer’s elevator – Used to elevate mucoperichondrial flap in septal surgeries

 

The image shows Freer’s double-ended elevator, a commonly used ENT instrument in septoplasty and SMR (submucous resection). It is used to carefully elevate the mucoperichondrium or mucoperiosteum from the septal cartilage or bone. Its curved ends allow atraumatic dissection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killian’s nasal gouge – Used to remove septal bony spur: Killian’s nasal gouge is a curved instrument used to remove bony septal spurs, not for flap elevation.

 

 

Option B. Ballenger swivel knife – Used for septal cartilage removal: Ballenger swivel knife is used to cut septal cartilage, particularly in SMR, not for elevating mucosal flaps.

 

 

Option D. Luc’s forceps – Used for avulsion of nasal polyps: Luc’s forceps are used to remove polyps or biopsy tissue, not for flap elevation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Freer’s double-ended elevator is used to elevate mucoperichondrium or periosteum during septoplasty or SMR procedures.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 455

choices.text: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
Sphenoid sinus
Anterior ethmoidal sinus
Nasolacrimal duct

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with nasal congestion and dull facial pain. On evaluation, inflammation of the maxillary and frontal sinuses is diagnosed. Which of the following is also likely to be affected due to its drainage pattern and anatomical grouping?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior ethmoidal sinus

 

 

  • The paranasal sinuses are grouped based on their drainage pathways:
    • Anterior group: Maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses (drain into the middle meatus)
