    • Posterior group: Posterior ethmoidal and sphenoid sinuses (drain into superior meatus or sphenoethmoidal recess)
  • In the setting of sinusitis involving maxillary and frontal sinuses, it's reasonable to expect anterior ethmoidal sinus involvement as well, since it belongs to the same anterior group and shares drainage into the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior ethmoidal sinus: Belongs to the posterior group, drains into the superior meatus, and is not typically affected in anterior sinusitis.

 

Option B. Sphenoid sinus: Also a posterior group sinus, drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess; anatomically and pathophysiologically unrelated to anterior group pathology.

 

Option D. Nasolacrimal duct: Drains tears into the inferior meatus, not part of the paranasal sinus system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior group of paranasal sinuses includes the maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoid sinuses, which drain into the middle meatus and are often involved together in sinusitis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

choices.text: Periorbital cellulitis
Oro-antral fistula
Cavernous sinus thrombosis
Mucormycosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with unilateral facial pain, nasal congestion, and postnasal drip for the past 4 days. On clinical examination, there is tenderness over the cheek, and CT PNS shows mucosal thickening in the maxillary sinus. He also reports a recent dental extraction of the right first molar tooth. Which of the following complications is he most at risk of developing due to anatomical proximity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oro-antral fistula

 

 

Due to the close anatomical relationship of the maxillary sinus floor with the roots of the maxillary molars, especially the first molar, dental procedures like extraction can create a pathological communication between the oral cavity and the maxillary sinus.

 

  • The maxillary sinus is pyramidal in shape and its floor lies just above the roots of the upper 2nd premolar and 1st molar teeth. Dental extractions in this region can breach the thin bone separating the sinus from the oral cavity, resulting in oro-antral fistula.
  • The roof of the maxillary sinus forms the floor of the orbit and transmits the infraorbital nerve and vessels.
  • It is the earliest developing sinus and the most commonly infected paranasal sinus.
  • The opening of the maxillary sinus is into the infundibulum of the middle meatus—hence infection may be associated with other anterior group sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Periorbital cellulitis: While this is more commonly a complication of ethmoidal sinusitis, it is less likely to arise directly from maxillary sinusitis unless there is spread superiorly, which is rare.

 

Option C. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Usually a complication of frontal or ethmoidal sinusitis, not directly linked to maxillary sinus pathology.

 

Option D. Mucormycosis: While maxillary sinus involvement is common in mucormycosis (especially in diabetics), the clinical context here doesn't suggest immunocompromise or necrosis. It's not the most direct complication in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The floor of the maxillary sinus lies in close proximity to the roots of the 1st molar and 2nd premolar, making oro-antral fistula a common complication following dental extractions in this region.

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

choices.text: Their drainage into the superior meatus
Their close proximity to the optic nerve
Their presence and pneumatisation at birth
Their location in the posterior cranial fossa

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, nasal congestion, and pain between the eyes. On examination, there is periorbital swelling and tenderness over the nasal bridge. CT PNS reveals opacification of the ethmoid air cells. Which of the following features best explains the early involvement of ethmoid sinuses in pediatric sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Their presence and pneumatisation at birth

 

Ethmoidal sinuses are already well-pneumatised at birth, unlike other sinuses that develop later. This anatomical maturity explains why ethmoid sinusitis is more common in children.

 

  • The ethmoid sinus is located in the ethmoidal labyrinth and is divided into anterior and posterior groups by the ground lamella.
  • Agger nasi is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell and part of the anterior group, which drains into the middle meatus.
  • Onodi cells (close to the optic nerve) and Haller cells (related to the orbital floor) are part of the posterior ethmoidal air cells, which drain into the superior meatus.
  • Among all the sinuses, the ethmoids are the most pneumatised at birth, making them the most commonly involved sinuses in children with acute sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Their drainage into the superior meatus: Incorrect. Only the posterior ethmoidal cells drain into the superior meatus, whereas anterior cells (more commonly infected) drain into the middle meatus.

 

Option B. Their close proximity to the optic nerve: Seen in Onodi cells, but this explains potential optic nerve involvement, not the early age of infection.

 

Option D. Their location in the posterior cranial fossa: Incorrect. Ethmoid sinuses are located between the nose and the orbit, not in the posterior cranial fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ethmoid sinuses are the most pneumatised at birth, making them the most frequently involved paranasal sinuses in children with acute sinusitis.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

choices.text: Its opening into the superior meatus
The hour-glass shape of its drainage tract
Its presence and pneumatisation at birth
Its location within the ethmoidal labyrinth

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presents with recurrent headaches localized over the forehead, particularly worsening in the mornings. CT PNS reveals opacification of the frontal sinus with a bony lesion near its floor. Which of the following anatomical features of the frontal sinus best explains the delayed onset of symptoms in childhood and the radiological finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The hour-glass shape of its drainage tract

 

This configuration (frontal infundibulum → ostium → frontal recess) predisposes to obstruction and infection. Also, osteomas near the floor or ostium can worsen drainage due to narrowing at the hour-glass constriction.

 

 

  • The frontal sinus drains into the middle meatus via the frontal recess, through a narrowing termed the frontal infundibulum leading to the ostium, and then widening again as the frontal recess/frontonasal duct — together forming an hour-glass shape configuration.
  • The ostium is located at the posterior part of the sinus floor, and obstruction here can lead to frontal sinusitis.
  • The frontal sinus is absent at birth and is the last to develop, which explains why frontal sinusitis is not commonly seen in infants and young children.
  • Osteoma, the most common benign tumor of the paranasal sinuses, most frequently arises from the frontal sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its opening into the superior meatus: Incorrect. The frontal sinus opens into the middle meatus, not the superior.

 

Option C. Its presence and pneumatisation at birth: Incorrect. The frontal sinus is not present at birth; it is the last sinus to develop, often not fully pneumatized until adolescence.

 

Option D. Its location within the ethmoidal labyrinth: Incorrect. The ethmoidal labyrinth houses the ethmoid sinuses, not the frontal sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The frontal sinus develops last and drains via a narrow frontal infundibulum and ostium into the frontal recess, forming an hour-glass-shaped tract that predisposes to obstruction and osteoma formation.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Opening into the middle meatus
Relationship with the internal jugular vein
Presence of a carotico-optic recess
Sellar type is the least common pattern of pneumatisation

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with deep-seated retro-orbital headache and visual disturbances. Nasal endoscopy and CT PNS reveal isolated sphenoid sinusitis with mucosal thickening and close proximity of the lesion to the optic nerve. Which of the following anatomical features of the sphenoid sinus best explains his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of a carotico-optic recess

 

The optic nerve and internal carotid artery are separated by a bony recess within the sphenoid sinus called the carotico-optic recess. This explains visual symptoms in isolated sphenoid sinusitis.

 

 

Sphenoid sinus inside view from anterior

 

  • The sphenoid sinus is located within the body of the sphenoid bone and opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess.
  • It shows three types of pneumatisation:
  • Conchal – rudimentary
  • Presellar – anterior to sella turcica
  • Sellar – extends beneath sella (= most common)
  • The lateral wall of the sphenoid sinus is intimately related to the optic nerve (superiorly) and the internal carotid artery (inferiorly). The recess between them is called the carotico-optic recess, an important site for spread of infection or tumors.
  • It is the least commonly infected sinus, but when infected, it can cause serious complications due to its vital neurovascular relations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opening into the middle meatus: Incorrect. The sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, not the middle meatus.

 

Option B. Relationship with the internal jugular vein: Incorrect. The internal jugular vein is not anatomically related to the sphenoid sinus; instead, the internal carotid artery lies in close proximity.

 

Option D. Sellar type is the least common pattern of pneumatisation: Incorrect. The sellar type is actually the most common pattern of pneumatisation of the sphenoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, and its lateral wall forms the carotico-optic recess between the optic nerve and internal carotid artery—explaining the risk of visual and vascular complications.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 188

choices.text: Poor vascular supply to the sinus mucosa
Close proximity to the optic nerve
Ostium located superior to the sinus floor
Lack of pneumatisation at birth

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, thick nasal discharge, postnasal drip, and pain over his upper jaw for the past 5 days. He also reports that the pain worsens when bending forward. Which of the following factors best explains the high prevalence of the affected sinus in adult sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ostium located superior to the sinus floor

 

In the maxillary sinus, the ostium is situated high on the medial wall, causing poor drainage due to gravity-defying flow, predisposing it to frequent infections.

 

 

  • Sinusitis is the inflammation of the paranasal sinuses, which may be acute or chronic (>12 weeks), and bacterial, fungal, allergic, or non-allergic in origin.
  • The most common causative organisms in acute bacterial sinusitis include Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Staphylococcus aureus.
  •  Maxillary sinusitis is the most common type in adults because the ostium is located high on the medial wall, above the level of the sinus floor—making drainage against gravity. This leads to stasis and frequent infection. Pain is felt over the upper jaw or infraorbital area.
  • Ethmoid sinusitis is more common in children and causes pain over the nasal root and between the eyes.
  • Frontal sinusitis causes “office headache”—worse in the morning and relieved by evening.
  • Sphenoid sinusitis, the least common, presents with occipital or vertex pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poor vascular supply to the sinus mucosa: Incorrect. The paranasal sinuses have rich vascular supply, and vascular compromise is not the primary reason for sinus infection.

 

Option B. Close proximity to the optic nerve: This is relevant to sphenoid and posterior ethmoid sinuses, not to the maxillary sinus, and doesn’t explain frequency of infection.

 

Option D. Lack of pneumatisation at birth: This is true for frontal and sphenoid sinuses, not the maxillary sinus, which is well pneumatized early in life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maxillary sinusitis is most common in adults due to the high position of its ostium above the floor, resulting in poor drainage and frequent infections.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 189

choices.text: Allergic mucin with eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals
Non-invasive fungal ball in an immunocompetent host
Invasive fungal infection with bone destruction
Chronic bacterial sinusitis with orbital spread

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic male presents with facial pain, nasal congestion, and recent onset of right-sided proptosis. CT PNS shows opacification and bony erosion of the right maxillary sinus. Histopathology reveals branching septate hyphae suggestive of Aspergillus. Which of the following best explains the likely pathogenesis of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive fungal infection with bone destruction

 

  • In diabetics, invasive aspergillosis may involve the maxillary sinus, causing bony erosion and orbital invasion, leading to proptosis and potentially life-threatening complications.

 

  • Fungal sinusitis is most commonly caused by Aspergillus fumigatus and presents in two forms:
  • Non-invasive – Occurs in immunocompetent individuals as either a fungal ball or Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS).
  •  Invasive – Seen in immunocompromised (e.g., diabetics) and involves aggressive tissue invasion, bone destruction, and potential orbital or intracranial extension.
  • In invasive aspergillosis, the maxillary sinus is often affected first and may erode surrounding bone, invading the orbit, leading to proptosis.
  • AFRS presents with thick eosinophilic mucin, Charcot-Leyden crystals, and unilateral nasal obstruction, but without invasion or bone destruction.
  • Treatment includes antifungals like voriconazole and surgical debridement via FESS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic mucin with eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals: Seen in AFRS, a non-invasive form, usually in immunocompetent individuals. There is no bony erosion or orbital invasion in this type.

 

Option B. Non-invasive fungal ball in an immunocompetent host: Also incorrect here. Fungal balls do not invade bone or orbit. Commonly seen incidentally in immunocompetent patients.

 

Option D. Chronic bacterial sinusitis with orbital spread: Orbital complications are more typical of ethmoidal sinusitis in children, and bacterial infections rarely cause bone erosion like fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive fungal sinusitis due to Aspergillus fumigatus commonly affects diabetics, causing bone destruction and orbital invasion, often starting from the maxillary sinus.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187, 211

choices.text: Presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals
Bone erosion on CT
Positive fungal stain
Unilateral nasal disease

questions.text: A 25-year-old immunocompetent male presents with recurrent nasal obstruction and thick, peanut butter-like nasal discharge from the right nostril. Nasal endoscopy reveals polyps, and CT PNS shows heterogenous opacities with areas of bone remodeling. Histopathology of mucin shows eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals. Which of the following features is considered a major diagnostic criterion for Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (Afrs)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive fungal stain

 

This is one of the major diagnostic criteria and confirms the fungal origin of the disease.

 

  • The diagnosis of Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS) is based on a combination of major and minor criteria. Given by Bent and Kuhn.

 

 

  • Mnemonic for major criteria: PEN1S:
    • P → Pathology (fungal stain)
    • E → Eosinophilic mucin
    • N → Nasal polyposis
    • 1 → Type (1) hypersensitivity
    • S → Scans (CT findings).
  • Mnemonic for minor criteria: ABCDEF:
    • A → Asthma
    • B → Bony erosion
    • C → Charcot-Leyden crystals
    • D → Directionality (ie. unilateral disease)
    • E → Eosinophilia (serum)
    • F → Fungal cultures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals: Incorrect. These are minor criteria, indicative of eosinophilic inflammation but not essential for diagnosis.

 

Option B. Bone erosion on CT: Incorrect. Bone erosion is a minor criterion and can be present due to pressure effect of mucin but is not specific to AFRS.

 

Option D. Unilateral nasal disease: Incorrect. Though often seen in AFRS, unilateral disease is a minor criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis is based on major criteria such as type I hypersensitivity, nasal polyposis, eosinophilic mucin without invasion, characteristic CT findings, and a positive fungal stain.
 

Ref: Glass D, Amedee RG. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis: a review. Ochsner J. 2011 Fall;11(3):271-5. PMID: 21960761; PMCID: PMC3179194.

choices.text: Oral voriconazole and observation
Urgent surgical debridement with intravenous amphotericin B
Endoscopic sinus washout and oral antibiotics
Wait for fungal culture and sensitivity before starting treatment

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a recent history of severe COVID-19 treated with high-dose corticosteroids presents with facial swelling, nasal obstruction, blackish discharge from the right nostril, and right eye proptosis. On nasal endoscopy, a black eschar is noted over the middle turbinate. MRI reveals non-enhancing mucosa in the nasal cavity (black turbinate sign). What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urgent surgical debridement with intravenous amphotericin B

 

This is the mainstay of treatment, especially when there are signs of necrosis or orbital involvement. Early surgical debridement improves survival.

 

  • Mucormycosis is an aggressive, life-threatening angioinvasive fungal infection caused primarily by Mucor and Rhizopus species.
  • It most commonly affects immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with uncontrolled diabetes, steroid use, or COVID-19-associated immunosuppression.
  • Rhinocerebral mucormycosis presents with black eschar, typically on the inferior turbinate, palate, or middle turbinate, along with facial pain/swelling, proptosis, and cranial extension.
  • MRI may reveal the black turbinate sign, indicating non-enhancing necrotic mucosa.

 

 

  • Diagnosis is by biopsy of necrotic tissue and demonstration of broad, non-septate hyphae.
  • Treatment is urgent — surgical debridement + IV amphotericin B. Delay may result in rapid orbital and cerebral extension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral voriconazole and observation: Incorrect. Voriconazole is ineffective against Mucor species and delay in initiating amphotericin B can be fatal.

 

Option C. Endoscopic sinus washout and oral antibiotics: Incorrect. Bacterial superinfection is not the primary concern here. Mucormycosis requires aggressive antifungal and surgical management.

 

Option D. Wait for fungal culture and sensitivity before starting treatment: Incorrect. Empirical treatment must be started immediately in suspected mucormycosis; cultures take time and delay is dangerous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis is a rapidly invasive fungal infection requiring urgent surgical debridement and intravenous amphotericin B, especially in immunocompromised or post-COVID-19 patients presenting with black eschar and orbital involvement.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 211

choices.text: Mucosal thickening with air-fluid levels on Water’s view
Radiopaque densities with bony erosion on NCCT PNS
Opacification of maxillary sinuses on open-mouth Water’s view
Frontal sinus opacity on Caldwell’s view

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, facial heaviness, and foul-smelling nasal discharge for the past 3 weeks. Diagnostic nasal endoscopy reveals thick debris and suspected fungal material in the nasal cavity. A CT PNS is ordered. Which of the following findings on imaging would most strongly support fungal sinusitis and aid in surgical planning?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radiopaque densities with bony erosion on NCCT PNS

 

This is characteristic of fungal sinusitis. CT can also detect extension to orbit or brain and is crucial for planning endoscopic debridement.

 

  • Investigations for sinusitis and fungal sinusitis include:
    • Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy – to visualize fungal debris, mucosal changes, or black eschar
    • Non-contrast CT (NCCT) Nose and PNS – the gold standard for evaluation, especially in fungal sinusitis:
      • Shows hyperdense (radiopaque) material within sinuses (suggestive of fungal balls)


         
      • Detects bony erosions
      • Assesses extension into orbit or cranium
      • Useful for surgical planning (e.g., FESS)
    • X-rays (used rarely nowadays):
      • Water’s view (occipitomental) – shows maxillary, frontal, and ethmoid sinuses
      • Open-mouth Water’s view – additionally visualizes the sphenoid sinus

      • Caldwell’s view (occipitofrontal) – best for frontal sinuses

         

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucosal thickening with air-fluid levels on Water’s view: Seen in bacterial sinusitis, but Water’s view is now obsolete for detailed assessment and cannot detect bone erosion or hyperdense fungal debris.

 

Option C. Opacification of maxillary sinuses on open-mouth Water’s view: Can suggest sinusitis, but it’s non-specific and offers limited anatomical detail compared to CT.

 

Option D. Frontal sinus opacity on Caldwell’s view: Also non-specific and limited in scope. It’s an older method for assessing frontal sinus, but does not provide information about fungal debris or bony erosion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NCCT Nose & PNS is the investigation of choice in fungal sinusitis, showing radiopaque densities, bony erosions, and orbital or cranial extension to guide surgical planning.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

choices.text: Caldwell’s view (Occipitofrontal)
Rhese’s view (Lateral oblique)
Water’s view (Occipitomental)
Submentovertex view

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with facial pain, nasal obstruction, and thick nasal discharge for the past 5 days. On examination, there is tenderness over the maxillary region. The physician suspects acute maxillary sinusitis. Which of the following radiographic views would best visualize the affected sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Water’s view (Occipitomental)

 

This is the standard and best view to assess the maxillary sinuses, especially in acute sinusitis with suspected air-fluid levels.

 

Radiographic views for paranasal sinuses are chosen based on which sinus is being assessed:

 

  • Water’s view (Occipitomental) – best for maxillary sinus, also shows frontal and ethmoid to some extent

 

 

  • Caldwell’s view (Occipitofrontal) – best for frontal sinus

     

 

  • Rhese’s view (Lateral oblique) and lateral view – used to assess ethmoid sinuses

 

 

  • Submentovertex view and Pierre’s view (Occipitomental with mouth open) – used for visualizing the sphenoid sinus

 

 

  • Air-fluid level on X-ray = acute sinusitis
  • Mucosal thickening = chronic sinusitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell’s view (Occipitofrontal): Incorrect. Best used for frontal sinuses, not the maxillary.

 

Option B. Rhese’s view (Lateral oblique): Incorrect. Primarily used to assess ethmoid sinuses, not the maxillary.

 

Option D. Submentovertex view: Incorrect. Used for evaluating the sphenoid sinus, not the maxillary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Water’s view (Occipitomental) is the best radiographic view to evaluate the maxillary sinus, particularly useful in detecting air-fluid levels in acute sinusitis.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 434

choices.text: Apply Mitomycin-C to the bleeding point
Perform lateral canthotomy for orbital decompression
Pack the middle meatus and continue surgery
Observe for spontaneous resolution over 2 hours

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with chronic rhinosinusitis unresponsive to medical management undergoes Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS). During the procedure, sudden brisk orbital bleeding occurs. The surgeon suspects anterior ethmoidal artery injury. What is the most appropriate immediate next step to prevent permanent vision loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform lateral canthotomy for orbital decompression

 

This is lifesaving in cases of retrobulbar hematoma from anterior ethmoidal artery injury. Delaying >90 minutes can lead to irreversible vision loss.

 

Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is performed to restore natural drainage and ventilation of the sinuses by removing anatomical obstructions and disease—hence termed "functional."

 

Initial steps include:

 

  • Uncinectomy (removal of uncinate process)
  • Middle meatal antrostomy
  • Removal of diseased mucosa/polyps
  • Opening of ethmoidal bulla and anterior ethmoid cells
  • Fracturing ground lamella inferomedially to access posterior ethmoids
  • Widening of sphenoid ostium

 

Key complications include:

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery injury – may retract into orbit and bleed → ↑ orbital pressure → optic nerve compression
    ⟶ Emergency: Lateral canthotomy must be done within 90 minutes to prevent permanent vision loss
  • Cribriform plate injury → CSF rhinorrhoea, anosmia
  • Nasolacrimal duct injury → epiphora
  • Injury to optic nerve/internal carotid near sphenoid sinus lateral wall
  • Post-op synechiae – preventable with Mitomycin-C

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apply Mitomycin-C to the bleeding point: Incorrect. Mitomycin-C is used to prevent synechiae, not to manage orbital bleeding.

 

Option C. Pack the middle meatus and continue surgery: Incorrect. Bleeding from an ethmoidal artery injury that enters the orbit will not be controlled by nasal packing.

 

Option D. Observe for spontaneous resolution over 2 hours: Incorrect. Vision-threatening orbital hemorrhage requires immediate decompression; waiting worsens prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior ethmoidal artery injury during FESS can cause retro-orbital bleeding and vision loss; urgent lateral canthotomy within 90 minutes is required to decompress the orbit.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 435

choices.text: Superior orbital fissure syndrome
Cavernous sinus thrombosis
Orbital cellulitis
Orbital apex syndrome

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with fever, proptosis, and painful limitation of eye movements following an episode of acute ethmoidal sinusitis. On examination, he has diplopia, ophthalmoplegia, and corneal hypoesthesia. His vision is also impaired. Which of the following is the most likely complication of sinusitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orbital apex syndrome

 

This syndrome involves all SOF nerves plus the optic nerve, causing visual loss, ophthalmoplegia, and sensory deficits, which matches this clinical picture.

 

Complications of sinusitis are classified as:

  • 1. Orbital (most common) – seen especially with ethmoid sinusitis due to its thin bony separation (lamina papyracea) from the orbit:
    • Periorbital edema
    • Orbital cellulitis
    • Subperiosteal/orbital abscess
    • Superior orbital fissure syndrome (SOFS):
      • Involves III, IV, VI, and V1 cranial nerves
      • Presents with ophthalmoplegia, diplopia, and corneal anesthesia
    • Orbital apex syndrome (OAS):
      • Involves SOF nerves + optic nerve (CN II)
      • Presents with visual loss in addition to the features of SOFS
  • 2. Osteomyelitis of frontal bone – leads to Pott's puffy tumor
  • 3. Intracranial complications – include:
    • Meningitis (most common)
    • Epidural/subdural abscess
    • Frontal lobe brain abscess
    • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • 4. Mucocele – due to chronic obstruction, most common in frontal sinus
    • Frontal mucocele: displaces orbit downward, forward, outward
    • Ethmoidal mucocele: displaces orbit forward and outward

  • 5. Pyocele – infected mucocele

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior orbital fissure syndrome: Incorrect. While SOFS presents with III, IV, V1, VI nerve involvement, it does not include optic nerve (CN II) involvement. This patient has visual impairment, so OAS is more likely.

 

Option B. Cavernous sinus thrombosis: Incorrect. Presents with bilateral signs, chemosis, papilledema, and signs of sepsis. Also includes CN VI palsy, but usually later and more systemic.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis: Incorrect. Presents with proptosis and pain, but nerve involvement and visual impairment point to a deeper complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital apex syndrome is a serious orbital complication of ethmoid sinusitis involving cranial nerves II, III, IV, V1, and VI, leading to vision loss and ophthalmoplegia.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 435

choices.text: Defective alpha-1 antitrypsin enzyme
Primary ciliary dyskinesia
Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation
Chronic granulomatous disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of nasal congestion, productive cough, and sinus infections since childhood. He also reports a chronic wet cough and occasional hemoptysis. Chest X-ray reveals dextrocardia, and HRCT shows bilateral lower lobe bronchiectasis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary ciliary dyskinesia

 

Kartagener syndrome is a form of PCD. Ciliary immotility leads to recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.

 

  • Kartagener syndrome is a subset of Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD), an autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective dynein arms in cilia, leading to immotile cilia.
  • Classic triad of Kartagener syndrome includes:

 

  1. Recurrent sinusitis – due to impaired mucociliary clearance
  2. Bronchiectasis – chronic infection and airway damage
  3. Situs inversus – due to abnormal organ placement during embryogenesis

 

  • **Patients may also present with infertility (due to immotile sperm or fallopian tube dysfunction), nasal polyps, and otitis media in children.
  • Diagnosis involves clinical suspicion, imaging (e.g., dextrocardia on chest X-ray), and confirmation via nasal nitric oxide testing, electron microscopy, or genetic testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defective alpha-1 antitrypsin enzyme: Seen in panacinar emphysema, especially in lower lobes, but doesn’t cause situs inversus or sinusitis.

 

Option C. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation: A congenital lung lesion that may cause respiratory distress in neonates, not associated with sinusitis or situs inversus.

 

Option D. Chronic granulomatous disease: A disorder of neutrophil oxidative burst, presents with recurrent infections and granuloma formation, but does not cause situs inversus or bronchiectasis in this pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is a form of primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the triad of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Kartagener syndrome
Cystic fibrosis
Young syndrome
Chronic granulomatous disease

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent nasal congestion and productive cough since adolescence. He and his wife have been unable to conceive, and a semen analysis reveals azoospermia with low sperm count. High-resolution CT chest shows bilateral lower lobe bronchiectasis. He has normal situs and no history of childhood respiratory distress. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Young syndrome

 

Presents with recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and obstructive azoospermia with normal situs and normal ciliary function.

 

Young syndrome is characterized by the triad of:

 

  1. Recurrent sinusitis
  2. Bronchiectasis
  3. Infertility due to obstructive azoospermia (inspissated mucus in vas deferens)

 

  • Unlike Kartagener syndrome, patients have normal situs and normal ciliary motility, but there is abnormal thick mucus obstructing the epididymis and sinopulmonary tracts.
  • Differentiated from cystic fibrosis, where sweat chloride levels are elevated, and pancreatic insufficiency is common.
  • **Exact etiology is unclear, but it is likely related to a post-infectious or environmental mucous abnormality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kartagener syndrome: Includes situs inversus, immotile cilia, and infertility, but in this case, situs is normal, and ciliary function is not impaired.

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Causes bronchiectasis and infertility, but typically has positive sweat chloride test and other features like pancreatic insufficiency, which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. Chronic granulomatous disease: Affects phagocyte function, causes recurrent infections, but does not explain infertility or bronchiectasis due to mucus dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Young syndrome presents with the triad of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and infertility due to obstructive azoospermia, without situs inversus or ciliary dyskinesia.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 172

choices.text: Ethmoidal nasal polyposis
Antrochoanal polyp
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
Hypertrophied middle turbinate (concha bullosa)

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, snoring, and postnasal drip for several months. On nasal endoscopy, a single polypoidal mass is seen arising from the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and extending into the nasopharynx. CT scan reveals a mass arising from the maxillary sinus extending posteriorly. A small crescent of air is seen between the mass and the posterior nasopharyngeal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antrochoanal polyp

 

Classic presentation of single, unilateral polyp in a young person extending from maxillary sinus to nasopharynx with crescent sign on imaging.

 

 

  • Nasal polyposis refers to the growth of benign edematous mucosa into the nasal cavity. Causes include:
    • Allergies, infections, cystic fibrosis, Kartagener syndrome, Young syndrome
  • Two main types of nasal polyps:
    • Ethmoidal polyposis:
      • Multiple, bilateral, allergic in origin
      • Arise from ethmoid sinuses, managed medically (steroids, antihistamines)
      • Surgical option: FESS, but recurrence is common
    • Antrochoanal polyp (Killian’s polyp):
      • Single, unilateral, infective or allergic in origin
      •  Arises from maxillary sinus, extends posteriorly to nasopharynx
      • Crescent/Dodd sign: Air column between polyp and posterior wall
      • Diagnosis: NCCT PNS, Rx: FESS + medical therapy
  • Bernoulli phenomenon explains how high velocity air in the narrow middle meatus pulls mucosa outward, contributing to polyp formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethmoidal nasal polyposis: Incorrect. These are bilateral, multiple, and allergic in origin. The clinical picture (unilateral, posterior extension) does not fit.

 

Option C. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Incorrect. Also occurs in young males but arises from the nasopharyngeal wall, not maxillary sinus. There is no air gap (crescent sign is absent), and presents with epistaxis.

 

Option D. Hypertrophied middle turbinate (concha bullosa): Incorrect. Appears similar to a polyp, but can be differentiated by probe test (can’t pass around it). Also, it’s not associated with posterior extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antrochoanal polyp is a single, unilateral polyp arising from the maxillary sinus, extending into the nasopharynx and identified radiologically by the crescent (Dodd) sign.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 148

choices.text: The tumor is most likely caused by prolonged exposure to nickel
Tumors arising below Ohngren’s line have a poorer prognosis
Surgical management involves lateral rhinotomy with neck dissection
Adenocarcinoma in this location is classically associated with wood dust exposure

questions.text: A 58-year-old male woodworker presents with progressive nasal obstruction, occasional epistaxis, and swelling over the right cheek for the past 2 months. On examination, there is a firm mass in the right nasal cavity with decreased sensation over the right cheek. CT imaging shows a mass involving the maxillary sinus with extension toward the orbit. Biopsy reveals adenocarcinoma. Which of the following statements regarding his condition is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenocarcinoma in this location is classically associated with wood dust exposure

 

Chronic exposure to hardwood dust is a known occupational risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the maxillary sinus.

 

  • Maxillary sinus is the most common site of sinonasal malignancy.
  • Common risk factors include:
    • Nickel exposure → Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Hard wood dust exposure (e.g., furniture industry, carpenters) → Adenocarcinoma (also known as “woodworker’s cancer”)
  • Clinical features include:
    • Nasal obstruction, epistaxis, cheek swelling
    • Infraorbital nerve involvement → loss of cheek sensation
    • Orbital invasion → proptosis, vision loss (due to optic nerve involvement)
  • Management:
    • Total maxillectomy + post-op radiotherapy
    • Surgical approach: Weber-Ferguson incision

  • Ohngren’s line (from medial canthus to angle of mandible) helps predict prognosis:

    • Above line → Poor prognosis
    • Below line → Better prognosis

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. The tumor is most likely caused by prolonged exposure to nickel: Incorrect. Nickel exposure is associated with squamous cell carcinoma, not adenocarcinoma.

 

Option B. Tumors arising below Ohngren’s line have a poorer prognosis: Incorrect. Tumors above Ohngren’s line (i.e., involving orbit, ethmoid, skull base) have worse prognosis due to vital structure involvement.

 

Option C. Surgical management involves lateral rhinotomy with neck dissection: Incorrect. The standard approach for maxillary sinus malignancy is total maxillectomy via Weber-Ferguson incision. Neck dissection is not routinely done unless there is nodal involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma of the maxillary sinus is commonly associated with chronic exposure to wood dust and presents with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and sometimes orbital symptoms.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 222

choices.text: Le Fort I fracture
Le Fort II fracture
Le Fort III fracture
Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a high-speed road traffic accident. He has severe midface trauma, periorbital ecchymosis, bilateral subconjunctival hemorrhage, CSF rhinorrhea, and mobility of the entire midface upon examination. CT imaging shows a fracture line extending through the ethmoid bone, superior orbital fissure, frontozygomatic sutures, and the upper part of the pterygoid plates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Le Fort III fracture

 

Involves craniofacial dysjunction with fracture line through the ethmoids, superior orbital fissure, zygomatic arches, and pterygoid plates. Leads to entire midface mobility and CSF leak.

 

 

Le Fort Fracture Classification Summary:

 

Le Fort I – Transverse fracture:

  • Horizontal line above the palate
  • Involves lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, pterygoid plates
  • Seen as floating palate

Le Fort II – Pyramidal fracture:

  • Fracture through root of nose, lacrimal bone, infraorbital rim, maxillary sinus, pterygoid plates
  • Seen as floating maxilla

Le Fort III – Craniofacial dysjunction:

  • Fracture through nasofrontal suture, ethmoid, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, zygomatic sutures, pterygoid plates
  • Entire midface separates from skull base
  • Associated with CSF rhinorrhea due to skull base breach

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le Fort I fracture: Incorrect. It is a low transverse fracture, does not involve orbit or skull base, and presents as mobile upper alveolus (floating palate).

 

Option B. Le Fort II fracture: Incorrect. Pyramidal fracture involving nasal bridge, infraorbital rim, and maxilla, but does not involve lateral orbital wall or zygomatic sutures.

 

Option D. Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture: Incorrect. Involves zygomatic bone, lateral orbit, infraorbital rim, and maxilla, but not the skull base or pterygoid plates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Le Fort III fracture involves craniofacial dysjunction with fracture lines through the ethmoid, orbital walls, zygomatic sutures, and pterygoid plates, leading to CSF rhinorrhea and entire midface mobility.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 185

choices.text: Subcondylar fracture of mandible
Zygomatic (tripod) fracture
Le Fort I fracture
Angle of mandible fracture

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He complains of difficulty opening his mouth and numbness over his right cheek. On examination, there is trismus, flattened right malar eminence, and a palpable step deformity at the infraorbital rim. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zygomatic (tripod) fracture

 

Involves the zygomatic arch, infraorbital rim, and lateral maxillary wall, leading to:

Flat cheek

Step deformity

Trismus

Cheek numbness (infraorbital nerve)

Key Concepts:

Mandibular Fractures:

 

  • Subcondylar region is the most common site due to anatomical weakness.
  • Angle of the mandible is another common fracture site.
  • Symptoms: malocclusion, trismus, pain near TMJ, deviation of jaw on opening.
  • Treatment: Usually open or closed surgical reduction.

 

Zygomatic Fracture (Tripod fracture):

 

  • Second most common facial bone fracture.
  • Involves zygomatic arch, infraorbital rim/floor, and zygomaticomaxillary suture.
  • Classic signs:
    • Flat malar eminence
    • Step deformity at infraorbital rim
    • Trismus (due to impingement on coronoid process)
    • Infraorbital nerve injury → numbness over cheek, upper lip, and upper gum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subcondylar fracture of mandible – Incorrect. Most common mandibular fracture but presents with pain near TMJ, malocclusion, and jaw deviation, not infraorbital numbness or malar flattening.

 

Option C. Le Fort I fracture – Incorrect. Involves the lower part of the nasal septum and maxilla, and presents with floating palate, mobility of upper teeth, but not malar flattening or trismus.

 

Option D. Angle of mandible fracture – Incorrect. Common mandibular fracture, but presents with posterior jaw pain, malocclusion, and trismus, without infraorbital symptoms or malar deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zygomatic (tripod) fractures involve the zygomatic arch, infraorbital rim, and maxilla, presenting with malar flattening, infraorbital nerve numbness, trismus, and step deformity.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 185

choices.text: Nasal swab glucose estimation
Handkerchief stiffening test
Detection of Beta-2 transferrin
Reservoir sign on head flexion

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of persistent clear nasal discharge from the right nostril following a head injury 2 weeks ago. The discharge increases when he bends forward and has a salty taste. On examination, the fluid cannot be sniffed back and does not stiffen a handkerchief. What is the most specific test to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Detection of Beta-2 transferrin

 

This is the most specific and confirmatory lab test for CSF rhinorrhoea. It is only present in CSF and inner ear fluid.

 

Key Points: CSF Rhinorrhoea

 

  • Causes:
    • Trauma (most common – accidental/surgical)
    • Infection (fungal sinusitis, osteomyelitis)
    • Neoplasm, Congenital, or Idiopathic
  • Clinical Features:
    • Unilateral, clear, watery discharge, especially on head bending/straining
    • Sniff test: Cannot be sniffed back
    •  Sweet/salty taste, often described
    • Reservoir sign: Sudden gush of fluid when neck is flexed (e.g., sphenoid sinus collection)
  • Signs:
    • Double ring / Target / Halo sign on filter paper: central blood spot with outer CSF ring
    • Handkerchief test: CSF doesn’t stiffen the cloth, unlike mucus
  • Investigations:
    • Most specific: Beta-2 transferrin (only found in CSF and perilymph)
    • High glucose levels in discharge may suggest CSF
    • Imaging: HRCT to identify bony defect; CT cisternography or MRI for localization
    • Localizing test: Intrathecal fluorescein with endoscopic visualisation (green dye)
  • Treatment:
    • Conservative: Bed rest, head elevation, stool softeners, avoid nose blowing
    • Surgical repair (endoscopic or external) if persistent

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal swab glucose estimation: Has limited sensitivity and specificity, especially if blood or mucus contaminates the sample. Useful as a screening tool, not confirmatory.

 

Option B. Handkerchief stiffening test: Helps differentiate CSF from mucus, but not diagnostic. Mucus stiffens the cloth; CSF does not.

 

Option D. Reservoir sign on head flexion: A clinical indicator of CSF leak from sphenoid sinus, but not a diagnostic test.

Educational Objective:

 

The most specific diagnostic test for CSF rhinorrhoea is the detection of Beta-2 transferrin in nasal discharge.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 178

choices.text: Persistence of Rathke’s pouch
Persistence of bucconasal membrane
Failure of nasal placode fusion
Defective development of Meckel’s cartilage

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate presents with cyanosis that improves when the baby cries. Examination reveals bilateral nasal obstruction with mucoid discharge. Attempts to pass a nasogastric tube through either nostril fail. CT scan confirms a bony obstruction at the posterior choanae. Which of the following best explains the underlying embryological cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Persistence of bucconasal membrane

 

Choanal atresia results from failure of resorption of the bucconasal membrane, which normally disappears during embryogenesis to connect the nasal and oral cavities.

 

 

 

Key Points: Choanal Atresia

  • Definition: Congenital obstruction of the posterior nasal aperture (choana) due to failure of recanalization of the bucconasal membrane.
  • Types:
    • Unilateral (most common, often undiagnosed until later childhood)
    • Bilateral (presents neonatally with respiratory distress)
    • Bony (90%)
    • Membranous (10%)
  • Etiology:
    • Can be sporadic or associated with CHARGE syndrome
    • Also linked to maternal use of methimazole/carbimazole during pregnancy
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Bilateral: Respiratory distress in neonates relieved by crying (obligate nasal breathers)
    • Unilateral: Chronic unilateral nasal discharge, often discovered later
  • Diagnosis:
    • Failure to pass catheter from nose to nasopharynx
    • Absence of air bubbles in nasal secretions
    • Methylene blue dye test, flexible nasal endoscopy
    • CT scan (axial plane) – gold standard for defining anatomy
  • Management:
    • McGovern’s technique: Feeding nipple with a large hole provides temporary airway
    • Surgical correction is definitive

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Persistence of Rathke’s pouch: Incorrect. Rathke’s pouch is involved in pituitary gland development, not nasal structures.

 

Option C. Failure of nasal placode fusion: Incorrect. This affects external nasal development, not posterior nasal aperture.

 

Option D. Defective development of Meckel’s cartilage: Incorrect. This cartilage contributes to mandibular development, not the nasal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choanal atresia is caused by persistence of the bucconasal membrane, resulting in congenital obstruction of the posterior nasal choanae.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 178

choices.text: Nasal glioma
Intranasal dermoid
Meningoencephalocele
Antrochoanal polyp

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with a soft, compressible polypoidal mass arising from the left nostril since birth. The mass transilluminates and increases in size when the baby cries or when both internal jugular veins are compressed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Meningoencephalocele

 

Characterized by soft, compressible, transilluminant mass, with positive Furstenberg sign. Classic presentation in an infant with nasal mass.

 

Key Features of Intranasal Midline Masses in Infants:

 

  • Meningoencephalocele (Encephalocele):
    • Herniation of brain tissue + meninges through congenital skull base defect
    • Polypoidal nasal mass since birth
    • Soft, compressible, transilluminant
    • Furstenberg sign positive: mass enlarges with crying or compression of IJV (increased intracranial pressure)
    • Risk of CSF leak if biopsied or injured
    • Treatment: Surgical repair via neurosurgical approach
  • Nasal Glioma:
    • Misnomer: Not a true tumor
    • Represents ectopic glial tissue (separated from encephalocele during development)
    • Firm, non-compressible, non-transilluminant, Furstenberg sign negative
    • Does not communicate with intracranial cavity
    • MRI differentiates it from encephalocele
    • Treatment: Surgical excision

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal glioma: Incorrect. Mass is firm, non-transilluminant, and Furstenberg test is negative. This case shows all signs opposite of glioma.

 

Option B. Intranasal dermoid: Incorrect. These are midline nasal masses, often with a pore or sinus opening and may be firm, but they do not transilluminate or enlarge with pressure.

 

Option D. Antrochoanal polyp: Incorrect. Typically seen in older children/adolescents, arising from maxillary sinus, and is not congenital, nor transilluminant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A congenital, compressible, transilluminant nasal mass in an infant that enlarges on crying is likely a meningoencephalocele, confirmed by a positive Furstenberg test.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 144

choices.text: Nasal dermoid cyst
Nasolabial cyst
Mucous retention cyst
Encephalocele

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless swelling on the lateral side of her nose near the nasal ala. On examination, there is a smooth bulge in the lateral wall and floor of the nasal vestibule. There is no nasal obstruction or discharge. The lesion has been slowly growing over the past few months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasolabial cyst

 

Classic presentation with smooth bulge in lateral nasal vestibule in an adult, due to embryological entrapment of epithelium at the medial-lateral nasal process junction.

 

Key Features of Nasolabial Cyst:

 

  • A nasolabial cyst is a non-odontogenic, congenital epithelial cyst arising from entrapped epithelium at the junction of the medial and lateral nasal processes during embryogenesis.
  • Presents as a painless, smooth swelling in the lateral wall and floor of the nasal vestibule, often near the nasolabial fold or nasal ala.
  • More common in middle-aged women and usually presents late.
  • Typically extraosseous (lies outside the maxillary bone).
  • Treatment is surgical excision, usually via sub-labial approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal dermoid cyst: Incorrect. Usually presents as a midline swelling near the nasal dorsum and may have a sinus opening with hair, not a smooth lateral vestibular swelling.

 

Option C. Mucous retention cyst: Incorrect. Usually occurs in the paranasal sinuses, especially maxillary sinus, and is seen on imaging as an incidental dome-shaped lesion, not in the vestibule.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Incorrect. Presents in infants, often as a compressible midline mass that is transilluminant and associated with cranial defect; not the same as a late-presenting vestibular mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A nasolabial cyst is a late-presenting, painless swelling in the lateral nasal vestibule due to embryological entrapment of epithelium between the medial and lateral nasal processes.

 

Ref: Lk SK, Sidharthan D, Stanly B, Mathew CM. Nasolabial Cyst: a Diagnostic Dilemma. J Dent (Shiraz). 2022 Mar;23(1):72-75.
